column1:
[Some things I''ve learned from my children:

Super glue "is" forever.

No matter how much Jell-O you put in a swimming pool you still can''t walk on water. Pool filters "do not like Jell-O!"

A king size waterbed holds enough water to fill a 2000 sq. foot house 4 inches deep.

Garbage bags do not make good parachutes.

Marbles in gas tanks make lots of noise when driving.

If you hook a dog leash over a ceiling fan
column2:
the motor is not strong enough to rotate a 42 pound boy wearing Batman underwear and a superman cape. It is strong enough however to spread paint on all four walls of 20 by 20 foot room.

\n

You should not throw baseballs up when the ceiling fan is on. When using the ceiling fan as a bat
column3:
you have to throw the ball up a few times before you get a hit. A ceiling fan can hit a baseball a long way. And the glass in windows (even double pane) doesn''t stop a
baseball hit by a ceiling fan.

\n

Certain Legos will pass through the digestive tract of a four year old.

\n

VCR''s do not eject peanut butter and jelly sandwiches
column4:
even though TV commercials show they do.

\n

Always look in the oven before you turn it on. It''s been proven that plastic toys do not like ovens.
Play Dough and Microwave should never be used in the same sentence.

\n

If you spray hair spray on dust bunnies and run over them with roller blades
column5:
they can ignite.

\n

The spin cycle on the washing machine does not make earth worms dizzy. It will however make cats dizzy. Cats throw up twice their body weight when dizzy.]

column1:
[To the citizens of the United States of America:

\n

In light of your failure to elect a President of the USA and thus to govern yourselves
column2: we hereby give notice of the revocation of your independence
column3:
effective today.

\n

Her Sovereign Majesty Queen Elizabeth II will resume monarchial duties over all states
column4: commonwealths and other territories. Except Utah
column5: which she does not fancy. Your new prime minister (The Rt. Hon. Tony Blair
column6:
MP for the 97.85% of you who have until now been unaware that there is a world outside your borders) will appoint a minister for America without the need for further elections. Congress and the Senate will be disbanded. A questionnaire will be circulated next year to determine whether any of you noticed.

\n

To aid in the transition to a British Crown Dependency
column7:
the following rules are introduced with immediate effect:

\n

1. You should look up "revocation" in the Oxford English Dictionary.
Then look up "aluminium" . Check the pronunciation guide. You will be amazed at just how wrongly you have been pronouncing it. Generally
column8:
you should raise your vocabulary to acceptable levels.

Look up "vocabulary". Using the same twenty seven words interspersed with filler noises such as "like" and "you know" is an unacceptable and inefficient form of communication. Look up "interspersed".

2. There is no such thing as "US English". We will let Microsoft know on your behalf.

3. You should learn to distinguish the English and Australian accents. It really isn''t that hard.

4. Hollywood will be required occasionally to cast English actors as the good guys.

5. You should relearn your original national anthem
column9: God Save The Queen
column10:
but only after fully carrying out task 1. We would not want you to get confused and give up half way through.

\n

6. You should stop playing American football. There is only one kind of football. What you refer to as American football is not a very good game. The 2.15% of you who are aware that there is a world outside your borders may have noticed that no one else plays American" football. You will no longer be allowed to play it
column11:
and should instead play proper football.

\n

Initially
column12: it would be best if you played with the girls. It is a difficult game. Those of you brave enough will
column13: in time
column14: be allowed to play rugby (which is similar to American football
column15:
but does not involve stopping for a rest every twenty seconds or wearing full kevlar body armour like nancies). We are hoping to get together at least a US rugby sevens side by 2005.

\n

7. You should declare war on Quebec and France
column16:
using nuclear weapons if they give you any merde. The 98.85% of you who were not aware that there is a world outside your borders should count yourselves lucky. The Russians have never been the bad guys. Merde is French for "shit"

\n

8. July 4th is no longer a public holiday. November 8th will be a new national holiday
column17:
but only in England. It will be called Indecisive Day.

\n

9. All American cars are hereby banned. They are crap and it is for your own good. When we show you German cars
column18:
you will understand what we mean.

\n

10. Please tell us who killed JFK. It''s been driving us crazy.

\n

Thank you for your cooperation.]

column1: [One day
column2:
farmer Williams was in town picking up supplies for his farm.

\n

He stopped at the hardware store and picked up a bucket and an anvil. Then he stopped by the livestock dealer to buy a couple of chickens and a goose.

\n

However
column3: he now had a problem
column4:
how to carry all his purchases home.

\n

The livestock dealer said: "Why don''t you put the anvil in the bucket
column5: carry the bucket in one hand
column6:
put a chicken under each arm and carry the goose in your other hand?"

"Hey thanks!" the farmer said and off he went. While walking he met a little old lady who told him she was lost.

She asked: "Can you tell me how to get to 123 Township Road?"

The farmer said: "Well
column7: as a matter of fact
column8:
I live at 132 Township Road. Let''s take my shortcut and go down this alley; we''ll be there in no time."

column11:
and ravish me?"

The farmer said: "Holy smokes lady

column13: an anvil
column14: two chickens
column15:
and a goose. How in the world could I possibly hold you up against the wall and do that?"

The lady said: "Set the goose down
column16: cover him with the bucket
column17:
put the anvil on top of the bucket and I''ll hold the chickens...."

column1:
[Customer: "Your sound card is defective and I want a new one."
Tech Support: "What seems to be the problem?"
Customer: "The balance is backwards. The left channel is coming out of the right speaker and the right channel is coming out the left.
It''s defective!"
Tech Support: "You can solve the problem by moving the left speaker to the right side of the machine and vice versa."
Customer: (sputter) (click)
Tech Support: (snicker)

\n

****************

\n

I had been doing Tech Support for Hewlett-Packard''s DeskJet division for about a month when I had a customer call with a problem I just couldn''t solve. She could not print yellow. All the other colors would print fine
column2: which truly baffled me because the only true colors are cyan
column3: magenta
column4: and yellow. For instance
column5: green is a combination of cyan and yellow
column6:
but green printed fine.

\n

Every color of the rainbow printed fine except for yellow. I had the customer change ink cartridges. I had the customer delete and reinstall the drivers. Nothing worked. I asked my co-workers for help; they offered no new ideas.

\n

After over two hours of troubleshooting
column7: I was about to tell the customer to send the printer in to us for repair when she asked quietly
column8:
"Should I try printing on a piece of white paper instead of this "yellow" construction paper?"

*******************

A man attempting to set up his new printer called the printer''s tech support number
column9:
complaining about the error message: "Can''t find the printer."

On the phone

but the computer still couldn''t find it! (YEE-HAW!)

\n

*****************

\n

Customer: "Hello? I''m trying to dial in. I installed the software okay
column12: and it dialed fine. I could hear that. Then I could hear the two computers connecting. But then the sound all stopped
column13: so I picked up the phone to see if they were still connected
column14: and I got the message
column15: ''No Carrier
column16:
'' on my screen. What''s wrong?"

*****************

An unfailingly polite lady called to ask for help with a Windows installation that had gone terribly wrong.

Customer: "I brought my Windows disks from work to install them on my
home computer." (Training stresses that we are "not the Soft-ware Police
column17:
so I let the little act of piracy slide.)
Tech Support: Umm-hmm. What happened?"
Customer: "As I put each disk in it turns out they weren''t initialized."

\n

Tech Support: "Do you remember the message exactly
column18:
ma''am?"
Customer:(proudly) "I wrote it down. ''This is not a Macintosh disk. Would you like to initialize it''?"
Tech Support: "Er
column19:
what happened next?"
Customer: "After they were initialized all the disks appeared to be blank. And now I brought them back to work
column20:
and I can''t read them in the A: drive; the PC wants to format them. And this is our only set of Windows disks for the whole office. Did I do something wrong?"

\n

******************

For a computer programming class
column21: I sat directly across from someone
column22:
and our computers were facing away from each other.

\n

A few minutes into the class
column23:
she got up to leave the room. I reached between our computers and switched the inputs for the keyboards. She came back and started typing and immediately got a distressed look on her face.

\n

She called the teacher over and explained that no matter what she typed
column24:
nothing would happen. The teacher tried everything. By this time I was hiding behind my monitor and quaking red-faced.

\n

I started to type
column25:
"Leave me alone!"

\n

They both jumped back
column26:
silenced. "What the . . . " the teacher said.
I typed
column27:
"I said leave me alone!"

\n

The kid got real upset. "I didn''t do anything to it
column28:
I swear!"
It was all I could do to keep from laughing out loud. The conversation between them and HAL 2000 went on for an amazing five minutes.

\n

Me: "Don''t touch me!"

\n

Her: "I''m sorry
column29:
I didn''t mean to hit your keys that hard."

\n

Me: "Who do you think you are anyway?!" Etc. Finally
column30:
I couldn''t contain myself any longer and fell out of my chair laughing.

\n

After they had realized what I had done
column31: they both turned beet red. Funny
column32:
I never got more than a C- in that class.

\n

***************

\n

I have a friend who just bought a computer and was instructed to load a program by typing "A:" and then the name of the program. My friend told me it would not work because his keyboard was no good. He said he couldn''t type the "dot over dot thingie" and that every time he tried to type the "dot over dot thingie" he kept getting the "dot over comma thingie" no matter how careful he was to press only on the very top of
the key.

column36:
I only have capital letters on my keyboard."

[The other day I went to the local religious book store where I saw a "HONK IF YOU LOVE JESUS" bumper sticker. I bought it and put it on my back bumper and I''m glad I did.

What an uplifting experience followed. That bumper sticker really worked!!

I found lots of people who loved Jesus.

I was stopped at the light at a busy intersection
column2: just lost in thought about the Lord. Why
column3:
the guy behind me started to honk like crazy.

\n

He must REALLY love Jesus because pretty soon he leaned out of his window and yelled "JESUS CHRIST!" as loud as he could.

\n

It was like a football game with him shouting
column4: "GO!...JESUS CHRIST!...GO!" Everyone else started honking too
column5:
so I leaned out the window and smiled and waved to all those loving people.

There must have been a guy from Florida back there because I heard him yell something about a sunny beach and saw him waving with only his middle finger.

I asked my kids what he meant by that and they laughed and said it was the Hawaiian good luck sign. So I leaned out of the window and gave him the good luck sign back.

A couple of people were so caught up in the joy of the moment that they got out of their cars and started running towards me!

I bet they wanted to pray
column6:
but just then I noticed that the light had changed so I stepped on the gas.

It''s a good thing that I did because I was the only driver to get across the intersection.

I looked back and everyone was still standing there so I leaned way out the window and held up the Hawaiian good luck sign as I drove away.

Praise the Lord for such wonderful people!]

column1:
[The five toughest questions women ask - and their answers:
1. `What are you thinking?''
2. `Do you love me?''
3. `Do I look fat?''
4. `Do you think she''s prettier than me?''
5. `What would you do if I died?''

\n

What makes these questions so bad is that every one is guaranteed to explode into a major argument and/or divorce if the man does not answer properly
column2:
which is to say dishonestly. For example:

\n

1. `What are you thinking?''
The proper answer to this question
column3: of course
column4: is: ''I''m sorry if I''ve been pensive
column5: dear. I was just reflecting on what a warm
column6: wonderful
column7: caring
column8: thoughtful
column9: intelligent
column10: beautiful woman you are and what a lucky guy I am to have met you.'' Obviously
column11: this statement bears no resemblance whatsoever to what the guy was really thinking at the time
column12:
which was most likely one of five things:
a - football.
b - baseball.
c - How fat you are.
d - How much prettier she is than you.
e - How he would spend the insurance money if you died.

\n

The best answer to this stupid question came from Al Bundy
column13: of Married with Children
column14: who was asked it by his wife
column15:
Peg. His answer: ''If I wanted you to know I''d be talking instead of thinking''

\n

The other questions also have only one right answer but many wrong answers:

\n

2. ''Do you love me?''
The correct answer to this question is
column16:
''Yes.''
For those guys who feel the need to be more elaborate
column17:
you may answer. ''Yes dear.''

\n

Wrong answers include:
a - I suppose so.
b - Would it make you feel better if I said yes?
c - That depends on what you mean by ''love''.
d - Does it matter?
e - Who
column18:
me?

\n

3. ''Do I look fat?''
The correct male response to this question is to confidently and emphatically state
column19: ''No
column20:
of course not'' and then quickly leave the room.

\n

Wrong answers include:
a - I wouldn''t call you fat
column21:
but I wouldn''t call you thin either.
b - Compared to what?
c - A little extra weight looks good on you.
d - I''ve seen fatter.
e - Could you repeat the question? I was thinking about your insurance policy.

\n

4. ''Do you think she''s prettier than me?''
The ''she'' in the question could be an ex-girlfriend
column22:
a passerby you were staring at so hard that you almost caused a traffic accident or an actress in a movie you just saw.
In any case
column23: the correct response is: ''No
column24:
you are much prettier.''

\n

Wrong answers include:
a - Not prettier
column25:
just pretty in a different way.
b - I don''t know how one goes about rating such things.

column1:
[Dear Tech Support:

I am desperate for some help. I recently upgraded from Girlfriend 7.0 to Wife 1.0 and found that the new program began unexpected child processing and also took up a lot of space and valuable resources. This wasn''t mentioned in the product brochure.

In addition Wife 1.0 installs itself into all other programs and launches during system initialisation where it monitors all other system activity.

Applications such as Boys Night Out 2.5
column2:
and Golf 5.3 no longer run and crash the system whenever selected. Attempting to operate Sunday Football 6.3 always fails but Saturday Shopping 7.1 runs instead. I cannot seem to keep Wife 1.0 in the background whilst attempting to run any of my favourite applications. I am thinking about going back to Girlfriend 7.0 but de-install doesn''t work on this program.

\n

Can you please help!
Joe.

\n

Dear Joe
column3:
This is a very common problem resulting from a basic misunderstanding.

Many men upgrade from Girlfriend 7.0 to Wife 1.0 thinking that Wife 1.0 is merely a UTILITIES & ENTERTAINMENT program. Whereas Wife 1.0 is an OPERATING SYSTEM designed by its creator to run everything.

You are unlikely to be able to purge Wife 1.0 and still convert back to Girlfriend 7.0 as Wife 1.0 is not designed to do this and it is impossible to de-install
column4:
delete or purge the program files from the system once installed.

\n

Some people have tried to install Girlfriend 8.0 or Wife 2.0
column5:
but have
ended up with even more problems. (See in manual under Alimony/Child Support and Solicitors Fees). Having Wife 1.0 installed myself I recommend you keep it installed and deal with the difficulties as best you can.

\n

When any faults or problems occur
column6: whatever you think has caused them
column7: you must run the C: IAPOLOGISE program and avoid attempting to use the *Esc-key. It may be necessary to run C: I APOLOGISE a number of times
column8:
but hopefully eventually the operating system will return to normal.

Wife 1.0 although a very high maintenance program can be very rewarding. To get the most out of it consider buying additional software such as Flowers 2.0 and Chocolates 5.0.

Do not under any circumstances install Secretary (Short Skirt version) as this is not a supported application for Wife 1.0 and the system will almost certainly crash.

Best of luck!
Tech Support]

column5:
there was my wife''s golf ball--stuck right in the middle of the cow''s butt. That''s when I made my mistake."

\n

"What did you do?" asks the doctor.

"Well
column6: I lifted the tail and yelled to my wife
column7: ''Hey
column8: this looks like yours!''"]

column1: [According to today''s regulators and bureaucrats
column2: those of us who were kids in the 60''s
column3: 70''s and early 80''s probably shouldn''t have survived
column4:
because our baby cots were covered with brightly coloured lead-based paint which was promptly chewed and licked.

\n

We had no childproof lids on medicine bottles
column5:
or latches on doors or cabinets and it was fine to play with pans.

\n

When we rode our bikes
column6: we wore no helmets
column7:
just flip flops and fluorescent ''spokey dokey''s on our wheels.�酶惟

\n

As children
column8: we would ride in cars with no seat belts or airbags
column9:
riding in the passenger seat was a treat.

\n

We drank water from the garden hose and not from bottles and it tasted the same.

\n

We ate chips
column10: bread and butter pudding and drank fizzy pop with sugar in it
column11:
but we were never overweight because we were always outside playing.

\n

We shared one drink with four friends
column12:
from one bottle or can and no-one actually died from this.

\n

We would spend hours building go-carts out of scraps and then went top speed down the hill
column13:
only to find out we forgot the brakes.

\n

After running into stinging nettles a few times
column14:
we learned to solve the problem.

\n

We would leave home in the morning and could play all day
column15:
as long as we were back before it got dark. No one was able to reach us and no one minded.

\n

We did not have Play stations or X-Boxes
column16: no video games at all. No 99 channels on TV
column17: no videotape movies
column18: no surround sound
column19: no mobile phones
column20: no personal computers
column21:
and no Internet chat rooms. We had friends we went outside and found them.

\n

We played elastics and street rounders
column22:
and sometimes that ball really hurt.

\n

We fell out of trees
column23:
got cut and broke bones but there were no law suits.

We had full on fist fights but no prosecution followed from other parents.

We played knock-and-run and were actually afraid of the owners catching us.

We walked to friend''s homes.

We also
column24: believe it or not
column25: WALKED to school; we didn''t rely on mummy or daddy to drive us to school
column26:
which was just round the corner.

We made up games with sticks and tennis balls.

We rode bikes in packs of 7 and wore our coats by only the hood.

The idea of a parent bailing us out if we broke a law unheard of. They actually sided with the law.

This generation has produced some of the best risk-takers and problem solvers and inventors
column27:
ever.

\n

The past 50 years have been an explosion of innovation and new ideas.

\n

We had freedom
column28: failure
column29: success and responsibility
column30:
and we learned how to deal with it all.

\n

And you''re one of them. Congratulations!

\n

Pass this on to others who have had the luck to grow as real kids
column31: before lawyers and government regulated our lives
column32:
for our own good.

\n

For those of you who aren''t old enough thought you might like to read about us.

\n

This my friends
column33:
is surprisingly frightening......and it might put a smile on your face: The majority of students in universities today were born in 1983........They are called youth.

\n

They have never heard of "We are the World
column34: We are the children"
column35: and the "Uptown Girl"
column36:
they know is by Westlife not Billy Joel.

\n

They have never heard of Rick Astley
column37: Bananarama
column38:
Nena or Belinda�酶惟 Carlisle.

\n

For them
column39:
there has always been only one Germany and one Vietnam.

AIDS has existed since they were born.

CD''s have existed since they were born.

Michael Jackson has always been white.

To them John Travolta has always been round in shape and they can''t imagine how this fat guy could be a god of dance.

They believe that Charlie''s Angels and Mission Impossible are Films from last year.

They can never imagine life before computers.

They''ll never have pretended to be the A Team
column40:
Red Hand Gang or the Famous Five.

They can''t believe a black and white television ever existed and don''t even know how to switch on a TV without a remote control.

And they will never understand how we could leave he house without a mobile phone.

Now let''s check if we''re getting old...

1. You understand what was written above and you smile.

2. You need to sleep more
column41: usually until the afternoon
column42:
after a night out.

3. Your friends are getting married/already married.

4. You are always surprised to see small children playing comfortably with computers.

5. When you see teenagers with mobile phones
column43:
you shake your head.

\n

6. You meet your friends from time to time
column44: talking about the good old days
column45:
repeating again all the funny you have experienced together.

\n

7. Having read this mail
column46:
you are thinking of forwarding it to some other friends because you think they will like it too...

\n

Yes
column47:
you''re getting older!!!!

column1: [When you''re 47 years old
column2: you sometimes hear a small voice inside you that says: "Just because you''ve reached middle age
column3: that doesn''t mean you shouldn''t take on new challenges and seek new adventures. You get only one ride on this crazy carousel we call life
column4:
and by golly you should make the most of it."

\n

This is the voice of Satan.

\n

I know this because recently
column5: on a mountain in Idaho
column6: I listened to this voice
column7:
and as a result my body feels as though it has been used as a trampoline by the Budweiser Clydesdales.

I am currently on an all-painkiller diet. "I''ll have a black coffee and 250 Advil tablets" is a typical breakfast order for me these days.

This is because I went snowboarding.

For those of you who
column8: for whatever reason
column9: such as a will to live
column10: do not participate in downhill winter sports
column11:
I should explain that snowboarding is an activity that is popular with people who do not feel that regular skiing is lethal enough.

\n

These are of course young people
column12: fearless people
column13: people with 100 percent synthetic bodies who can hurtle down a mountainside at 50 miles per hour and knock down mature trees with their faces and then spring to their feet and go
column14:
"Cool."

\n

People like my son. He wanted to try snowboarding
column15: and I thought it would be good to learn with him
column16:
because we can no longer ski together.

\n

We have a fundamental difference in technique: He skis via the Downhill Method
column17: in which you ski down the hill; whereas I ski via the Breath-Catching Method
column18: in which you stand sideways on the hill
column19:
looking as athletic as possible without actually moving muscles (this could cause you to start sliding down the hill).

\n

If anybody asks if you''re OK
column20: you say
column21: "I''m just catching my breath!" in a tone of voice that suggests that at any moment you''re going to swoop rapidly down the slope; whereas in fact you''re planning to stay right where you are
column22: rigid as a statue
column23:
until the spring thaw.

\n

At night
column24: when the Downhillers have all gone home
column25: we Breath-Catchers will still be up there
column26: clinging to the mountainside
column27:
chewing on our parkas for sustenance.

\n

So I thought I''d take a stab at snowboarding
column28:
which is quite different from skiing.

\n

In skiing
column29: you wear a total of two skis
column30: or approximately one per foot
column31: so you can sort of maintain your balance by moving your feet
column32:
plus you have poles that you can stab people with if they make fun of you at close range.

\n

Whereas with snowboarding
column33: all you get is one board
column34: which is shaped like a giant tongue depressor and manufactured by the Institute of Extremely Slippery Things. Both of your feet are strapped firmly to this board
column35: so that if you start to fall
column36:
you can''t stick a foot out and catch yourself. You crash to the ground like a tree and lie there while skiers swoop past and deliberately spray snow on you.

\n

Skiers hate snowboarders. It''s a generational thing. Skiers are (and here I am generalizing) middle-aged Republicans wearing designer space suits; snowboarders are defiant young rebels wearing deliberately drab clothing that is baggy enough to cover the snowboarder plus a major appliance. Skiers like to glide down the slopes in a series of graceful arcs; snowboarders like to attack the mountain
column37: slashing
column38: spinning
column39: tumbling
column40: going backward
column41: blasting through snowdrifts
column42: leaping off cliffs
column43: getting their noses pierced in midair
column44:
etc.

\n

Skiers view snowboarders as a menace; snowboarders view skiers as Elmer Fudd.

\n

I took my snowboarding lesson in a small group led by a friend of mine named Brad Pearson
column45:
who also once talked me into jumping from a tall tree while attached only to a thin rope.

\n

Brad took us up on a slope that offered ideal snow conditions for the novice who''s going to fall a lot: Approximately seven flakes of powder on top of an 18-foot-thick base of reinforced concrete.

\n

You could not dent this snow with a jackhammer. (I later learned
column46: however
column47:
that you COULD dent it with the back of your head.)

We learned snowboarding via a two step method:

STEP ONE: Watching Brad do something.

STEP TWO: Trying to do it ourselves.

I was pretty good at Step One. The problem with Step Two was that you had to stand up on your snowboard
column48:
which turns out to be a violation of at least five important laws of physics.

\n

I''d struggle to my feet
column49: and I''d be wavering there and then the Physics Police would drop a huge chunk of gravity on me
column50: and WHAM my body would hit the concrete snow
column51:
sometimes bouncing as much as a foot.

\n

"Keep your knees bent!" Brad would yell
column52:
helpfully.

\n

Have you noticed that whatever sport you''re trying to learn
column53: some earnest person is always telling you to keep your knees bent? As if THAT would solve anything. I wanted to shout back
column54:
"FORGET MY KNEES! DO SOMETHING ABOUT THESE GRAVITY CHUNKS!"

\n

Needless to say my son had no trouble at all. None. In minutes he was cruising happily down the mountain; you could actually see his clothing getting baggier. I
column55: on the other hand
column56: spent most of my time lying on my back
column58:
while space-suited Republicans swooped past and sprayed snow on me.

\n

If I hadn''t gotten out of there
column59:
they''d have completely covered me; I now realize that the small hills you see on ski slopes are formed around the bodies of 47-year-olds who tried to learn snowboarding.

\n

So I think
column61: I''ll go back to skiing. Maybe sometime you''ll see me out on the slopes
column62: catching my breath. Please throw me some food.]

[One day Bill complained to his friend that his elbow really hurt. His friend
suggested that he go to a computer at the drug store that can diagnose anything
quicker and cheaper than a doctor.
''''Simply put in a sample of your urine and the computer will diagnose your
problem and tell you what you can do about it. It only costs $10." Bill figured
he had nothing to lose
column2:
so he filled a jar with a urine sample and went to the
drug store. Finding the computer
column3:
he poured in the sample and deposited the $10.
The computer started making some noise and various lights started flashing.
After a brief pause out popped a small slip of paper on which was printed: "You
have tennis elbow. Soak your arm in warm water. Avoid heavy lifting. It will be
better in two weeks."
Later that evening while thinking how amazing this new technology was and how
it would change medical science forever
column4:
he began to wonder if this machine
could be fooled. He mixed together some tap water
column5:
a stool sample from his dog
and urine samples from his wife and daughter. To top it off
column6:
he masturbated into
the concoction. He went back to the drug store
column7: located the machine
column8:
poured in
the sample and deposited the $10. The computer again made the usual noise and
printed out the following message:
"Your tap water is too hard. Get a water softener. Your dog has worms. Get him
vitamins. Your daughter is using cocaine. Put her in a rehabilitation clinic.
Your wife is pregnant with twin girls. They aren''t yours. Get a lawyer. And if
you don''t stop jerking off
column9: your tennis elbow will never get better."]

column1:

[To the citizens of the United States of America:

\n

In light of your failure to elect a President of the USA and thus to govern yourselves
column2: we hereby give notice of the revocation of your independence
column3:
effective today.

\n

Her Sovereign Majesty Queen Elizabeth II will resume monarchial duties over all states
column4: commonwealths and other territories. Except Utah
column5: which she does not fancy. Your new prime minister (The Rt. Hon. Tony Blair
column6:
MP for the 97.85% of you who have until now been unaware that there is a world outside your borders) will appoint a minister for America without the need for further elections. Congress and the Senate will be disbanded. A questionnaire will be circulated next year to determine whether any of you  noticed.

\n

To aid in the transition to a British Crown Dependency
column7:
the following rules are introduced with immediate effect:

\n

1. You should look up "revocation" in the Oxford English Dictionary.
Then look up "aluminium" . Check the pronunciation guide. You will be amazed at just how wrongly you have been pronouncing it. Generally
column8:
you should raise your vocabulary to acceptable levels.

Look up "vocabulary". Using the same twenty seven words interspersed with filler noises such as "like" and "you know" is an unacceptable and inefficient form of communication. Look up "interspersed".

2. There is no such thing as "US English". We will let Microsoft know on your behalf.

3. You should learn to distinguish the English and Australian accents. It really isn''t that hard.

4. Hollywood will be required occasionally to cast English actors as the good guys.

5. You should relearn your original national anthem
column9: God Save The Queen
column10:
but only after fully carrying out task 1. We would not want you to get confused and give up half way through.

\n

6. You should stop playing American football. There is only one kind of football. What you refer to as American football is not a very good game. The 2.15% of you who are aware that there is a world outside your borders may have noticed that no one else plays American" football. You will no longer be allowed to play it
column11:
and should instead play proper football.

\n

Initially
column12: it would be best if you played with the girls. It is a difficult game. Those of you brave enough will
column13: in time
column14: be allowed to play rugby (which is similar to American football
column15:
but does not involve stopping for a rest every twenty seconds or wearing full kevlar body armour like nancies). We are hoping to get together at least a US rugby sevens side by 2005.

\n

7. You should declare war on Quebec and France
column16:

I sure did

I''m so sorry for skipping services today to come out here and

column1: [If you receive an email entitled "Badtimes
column2:
delete it immediately! Do not open it. Apparently, this one is pretty nasty.

\n

It will not only erase everything on your hard drive, but it will also delete anything on disks within 20 feet of your computer. It demagnetizes the stripes on ALL of your credit cards. It reprograms your ATM access code, screws up the tracking on your VCR and uses subspace field harmonics to scratch any CD''s you attempt to play. It will re-calibrate your refrigerator''s coolness settings so all your ice cream melts and your milk curdles. It will program your phone''s autodial to call only your mother-in-law''s number. This virus will mix antifreeze into your fish tank. It will drink all your beer. It will leave dirty socks on the coffee table when you are expecting company. Its radioactive emissions will cause your toe jam and bellybutton fuzz (be honest, you have some)to migrate behind your ears. It will replace your shampoo with Nair and your Nair with Rogaine, all while dating your current boy/girlfriend behind your back and billing their hotel rendezvous to your Visa card. It will cause you to run with scissors and throw things in a way that is only fun until someone loses an eye. It will give you Dutch Elm Disease and Tinea. It will rewrite your backup files, changing all your active verbs to passive tense and incorporating undetectable misspellings, which grossly change the interpretations of key sentences. If the Badtimes" message is opened in a Windows95 environment
column3: it will leave the toilet seat up and leave your hair dryer plugged in dangerously close to a full bathtub. It will not only remove the forbidden tags from your mattresses and pillows
column4: but it will also refill your skim milk with whole milk. It will replace all your luncheon meat with Spam. It will molecularly rearrange your cologne or perfume
column5: causing it to smell like dill pickles. It is insidious and subtle. It is dangerous and terrifying to behold. It is also a rather interesting shade of mauve.   These are just a few signs of infection. PLEASE FORWARD THIS MESSAGE TO EVERYONE YOU KNOW!!! LIFE IS UNCERTAIN; EAT YOUR DESSERT FIRST!]

column1: [Most diets fail because we are still thinking and eating like people. For those us who have never had any success dieting. Well now there is the new Miracle Cat Diet! This diet will also work on humans! Except for cats that eat like people -- such as getting lots of table scraps -- most cats are long and lean (or tiny and petite). the Cat Miracle Diet will help you achieve the same lean
column2: svelte figure. Just follow this diet for one week and you''ll find that you not only look and feel better
column3:
but you will have a whole new outlook on what constitutes food. Good Luck!

DAY ONE

Breakfast: Open can of expensive gourmet cat food. Any flavor as long as it cost more the .75 per can -- and place 1/4 cup on your plate. Eat 1 bite of food; look around room disdainfully. Knock the rest on the floor. Stare at the wall for awhile before stalking off into the other room.

Lunch: Four blades of grass and one lizard tail. Throw it back up on the cleanest carpet in your house.

Dinner: Catch a moth and play with it until it is almost dead. Eat one wing. Leave the rest to die.

Bedtime snack: Steal one green bean from your spouse''s or partner''s plate. Bat it around the floor until it goes under the refrigerator. Steal one small piece of chicken and eat half of it. Leave the other half on the sofa. Throw out the remaining gourmet cat food from the can you opened this morning.

DAY TWO

Breakfast: Picking up the remaining chicken bite from the sofa. Knock it onto the carpet and bat it under the television set. Chew on the corner of the newspaper as your spouse/partner tries to read it.

Lunch: Break into the fresh French bread that you bought as your part of the dinner party on Saturday. Lick the top of it all over. Take one bite out of the middle of the loaf.

Afternoon snack: Catch a large beetle and bring it into the house. Play toss and catch with it until it is mushy and half dead. Allow it to escape under the bed.

Dinner: Open a fresh can of dark-colored gourmet cat food -- tuna or beef works well. Eat it voraciously. Walk from your kitchen to the edge of the living room rug. Promptly throw up on the rug. Step into it as you leave. Track footprints across the entire room.

DAY THREE

Breakfast: Drink part of the milk from your spouse''s or partner''s cereal bowl when no one is looking. Splatter part of it on the closest polished aluminum appliance you can find.

Lunch: Catch a small bird and bring it into the house. Play with on top of your down filled comforter. Make sure the bird is seriously injured but not dead before you abandon it for someone else to have to deal with.

Dinner: Beg and cry until you are given some ice cream or milk in a bowl of your own. Take three licks/laps and then turn the bowl over on the floor.

FINAL DAY

Breakfast: Eat 6 bugs
column4: any type
column5: being sure to leave a collection of legs
column6: wings
column7:
antennae on the bathroom floor. Drink lots of water. Throw the bugs and all of the water up on your spouse''s or partner''s pillow.

\n

Lunch: Remove the chicken skin from last night''s chicken-to-go leftovers your spouse or partner placed in the trash can. Drag the skin across the floor several times. Chew it in a corner and then abandon.

\n

Dinner: Open another can of expensive gourmet cat food. Select a flavor that is especially runny

column1: [In a never-ending effort to attract the unchurched
column2:
some churches have considered translating their unfamiliar terminology into familiar football phrases:

BLITZ: The strategic play that takes place two seconds after every benediction.

BLOCKING: Talking endlessly to the pastor at the church door and keeping everyone else from exiting.

COACH: The children''s Christmas program director.

ASSISTANT COACH: Every mother who has a kid in the children''s Christmas program.

COMMERCIAL: Announcements.

DRAFT CHOICE: The decision to sit close to an air conditioning vent.

DRAW PLAY: What many children (and not a few adults) do with their bulletins during the service.

END ZONE: The pews.

EXTRA POINT: What you receive when you tell the preacher his sermon was too short.

FIRST QUARTER: What most people put into the Sunday school offering so it looks like they are giving.

FOURTH QUARTER: The amount that makes up the $1 most people put into the Sunday school offering when under peer pressure to give more.

HAIL MARY: Desperate move made by ushers in a last-ditch attempt to get people to put something in the plate.

HALFTIME: Usually during the offertory when at least 14 people decide they need to use the restroom.

HOLDING: Passing on the offering place without putting in a cent.

ILLEGAL CONTACT: What gets some church leaders into trouble and out of the ministry.

ILLEGAL MOTION: Leaving before the benediction.

INTERFERENCE: Talking during the organ prelude.

OFFSIDES: When an orchestra member accidentally walks into the choir room (severe penalty incurred).

PASS INTERFERENCE: 1. Single male usher spots single woman in audience.
2. A parent moving between two teens in the
pew to halt the flow of notes back and forth during the sermon.

QUARTERBACK SNEAK: 1. How the pastor gets from the pulpit to the rear door during the benediction.
2. Sunday school teachers entering the building five minutes after classes began.

RAIN DELAY: Baptism

RED DOG: Common strategy performed each Sunday by those who "own" their own pew.

SUDDEN DEATH: The penalty to the pastor who preaches more than twenty minutes.

TACKLE: 1. What takes place to the only eligible bachelor at the 35-and-over singles enrichment retreat.
2. Asking that "new couple" to sing in the choir
column3: work in the nursery
column4: serve on a committee
column5: join a Bible study
column6:
and teach the middle schoolers before they get away.

PASS: When the new couple says no.

TIME-OUT: Refreshment time in the Fellowship Hall.

TWO-MINUTE WARNING: The pastor''s wife looking at her watch in full view of the pastor.

UNSPORTSMANLIKE CONDUCT: Usually takes place at a committee meeting to decide on the color of carpet or some other thing.

Submitted by Admin
Edited by Calamjo]

3 - "Do I look fat?"

4 - "Do you think she is prettier than me?"

5 - "What would you do if I died?"

What makes these questions so bad is that every one is guaranteed to explode into a major argument and/or divorce if the man does not answer properly

column8: thoughtful

beautiful woman you are and what a lucky guy I am to have met you."

column1: [By Barbara Florio GrahamFrom McCall''s
column2: June
column3: 1983I read every diet I can get my hands on.  I even follow their suggestions.  But eventually
column4: inevitably
column5: I always get fat again.  Now
column6: at last
column7: I''ve found The Answer.  After living for almost 14 years with a man who never gains an ounce no matter what I serve him
column8: I''ve found out what it is that keeps him thin: He thinks differently.  The real difference between fat and thin people is that thin people:avoid eating popcorn in the movies because it gets their hands greasy;split a large combination pizza with three friends;think Oreo cookies are for kids;nibble cashews one at a time;think that doughnuts are indigestible;read books they have to hold with both hands;become so absorbed in a weekend project they forget to have lunch;fill the candy dish on their desks with paper clips;counteract the midafternoon slump with a nap instead of a cinnamon Danish;exchange the deep-fryer they received for Christmas for a clock-radio;lose their appetites when they''re depressed;think chocolate Easter bunnies are for kids;save leftovers that are too skimpy to use for another meal in order to make interesting soups;throw out stale potato chips;will eat only Swiss or Dutch chocolate
column9: which cannot be found except in a special store;think it''s too much trouble to stop at a special store just to buy chocolate;don''t celebrate with a hot-fudge sundae every time they lose a pound;warm up after skiing with black coffee instead of hot chocolate and whipped cream;try all the salads at the buffet
column10: leaving room for only one dessert;find iced tea more refreshing than an ice-cream soda;get into such interesting conversations at cocktail parties that they never quite work their way over to the hors-d''oeuvre table;have no compulsion to keep the candy dish symmetrical by reducing the jelly beans to an equal number of each color;think that topping brownies with ice cream makes too rich a dessert;bring four cookies into the TV room instead of a box;think banana splits are for kids.]

column1: [Diet for Stress How''s your stress level? This should help. It is more than a diet
column2:
so read on... This diet is designed to help you cope with the stress that builds up during the day.

Breakfast:

1/2 grapefruit 1 slice whole wheat toast 8 oz. skim milk

Lunch: 4 oz. lean broiled chicken breast 1 cup steamed spinach 1 cup herb tea 1 Oreo cookie

Mid-Afternoon snack: The rest of Oreos in the package 2 pints Rocky Road ice cream with nuts
column3:
cherries and whipped cream 1 jar hot fudge sauce

\n

Dinner: 2 loaves garlic bread 4 cans or 1 large pitcher Coke 1 large sausage
column4:
mushroom and cheese pizza 3 Snickers bars

\n

Late Evening News: Entire frozen Sara Lee cheesecake (eaten directly from freezer)

\n

Rules for this Diet
1. If you eat something and no one sees you eat it
column5:
it has no calories.
2. If you drink a diet soda with a candy bar
column6:
the calories in the candy jar are canceled out by the diet soda.
3. When you eat with someone else
column7:
calories don''t count if you do not eat more than they do.
4. Food used for medicinal purposes NEVER count
column8: such as hot chocolate
column9:
toast and Sara Lee Cheesecake.
5. If you fatten up everyone else around you
column10:
then you look thinner.
6. Movie related foods do not have additional calories because they are part of the entertainment package and not part of one''s personal fuel. Examples: Milk Duds
column11: buttered popcorn
column12: Junior Mints
column13:
Red Hots and Tootsie Rolls.
7. Cookie pieces contain no calories. The process of breaking causes calorie leakage.
8. Things licked off knives and spoons have no calories if you are in the process of preparing something.
9. Foods that have the same color have the same number of calories. Examples are: spinach and pistachio ice cream; mushrooms and mashed potatoes.
10. Chocolate is a universal color and may be substituted for any other food color.
11. Anything consumed while standing has no calories. This is due to gravity and the density of the caloric mass.
12. Anything consumed from someone else''s plate has no calories since the calories rightfully belong to the other person and will cling to his/her plate. (We ALL know how calories like to cling!)

\n

REMEMBER: STRESSED SPELLED BACKWARDS IS DESSERTS]

column1: [Dear Mom and Dad
column2:
\n

It has been three months since I left for college. I have been remiss in writing and I am very sorry for my thoughtlessness. I will bring you up to date now
column3: but before you read on
column4: please sit down. You are not to read any further unless you are sitting down
column5:
okay?

\n

Well
column6:
I am getting along pretty well now. The skull fracture and the concussion I got when I jumped out of the window of my dormitory when it caught fire shortly after my arrival are pretty well healed now. I only spent two weeks in the hospital and I now can see almost normally and I only get those sick headaches once a week.

\n

Fortunately
column7: the fire in the dormitory and my jump was witnessed by an attendant at the gas station near the dorm and he was the one who called the fire department and the ambulance. He also visited me at the hospital and since I had nowhere to live because of the burnt-out dorm
column8: he was kind enough to invite me to share his apartment with him. It''s really a basement room
column9:
but it''s kind of cute.

\n

He is a very fine boy and we have falled deeply in love and are planning to get married. We haven''t exactly set the date yet
column10: but it will be before my pregnancy begins to show. Yes
column11: Mom and Dad
column12:
I am pregnant. I know how you are looking forward to being grandparents and I know you will welcome the baby and give it the same love and devotion and tender care you gave me as a child. The reason for the delay in our marriage is that my boy friend has some minor infection which prevents us from passing our premarital blood tests and I carelessly caught it from him. This will soon clear up with the penicillin injections I am taking daily.

\n

I know you will welcome him into the family with open arms. He is kind
column13: and although not well educated
column14: has ambitions. Although he is of a different race and religion than ours
column15: I know oft-expressed tolerance will not permit you to be bothered by the fact that his skin color is somewhat darker than ours. I am sure you will love him as I do. His family background is good
column16: too
column17:
for I hear that his father is an important gun-bearer in the village in Africa from which he comes.

\n

Now that I have brought you up to date
column18: I want to tell you that there was no dormitory fire. I do not have a concussion or a skull fracture
column19: I was not in the hospital
column20: I am not pregnant
column21: I am not engaged
column22:
I do not have syphilis and there is no colored man in my life.

\n

However
column23:
I am getting a ''D'' in history and an ''F'' in science class and I wanted you to see these marks in their proper perspective.

\n

Your loving daughter
column24:
\n

Trish]

column1: [If you are not familiar with golf
column2:
you probably won''t get these. Ask your closest golf player.

\n

1. Never try to keep more than 300 separate thoughts in your mind during your swing.

\n

2. When your shot has to carry over a water hazard
column3:
you can either hit one more club or two more balls.

\n

3. If you are afraid a full shot might reach the green while the group ahead are still putting
column4: you have two options: you can immediately shank a lay-up
column5:
or you can wait until the green is clear and top a ball halfway there.

\n

4. The less skilled the player
column6:
the more likely he is to share his ideas about the golf swing.

\n

5. If it isn''t broke
column7:
try changing your grip.

6. Golfers who claim they don''t cheat also lie.

7. Everyone replaces his divot after a perfect approach shot.

8. A golf match is a test of your skill against your opponent''s luck.

9. It''s surprisingly easy to sink a 50 foot putt when you lie.

10. Counting on your opponent to inform you when he breaks a rule is like expecting him to make fun of his own haircut.

11. Nonchalant putts count the same as chalant putts.

12. It''s not a gimme putt if you''re still away.

13. The shortest distance between any two points on a golf course is a straight line that passes directly through the large tree.

14. There are two kinds of bounces: unfair bounces and bounces just the way you intended to play it.

15. You can hit a two-acre fairway 10% of the time and a 2-inch branch on a tree 90% of the time.

16. Every time a golfer makes a birdie he must subsequently make three triple bogeys to restore the fundamental equilibrium of the universe.

17. If you want to hit a 7-iron as far as Tiger Woods try to hit just short of a water hazard.

18. To calculate the speed of a player''s downswing
column8: multiply the speed of his backswing by his handicap. Example
column9: backswing 20 miles per hour
column10: handicap
column12:
downswing 300
m.p.h.

\n

19. There are two things you can learn by stopping your backswing at the top and checking the position of your hands: how many hands you have
column13:
and which hand is wearing
the golf glove.

\n

20. Hazards attract; Fairways repel.

\n

21. You can put "draw" on the ball
column14: you can put "fade" on the ball
column15:
but no golfer can put "straight" on the ball.

\n

22. A ball you can see in the rough from 50 yards away is not yours.

\n

23. If there is a ball in the fringe and a ball in the bunker
column16:
your ball is in the bunker.

\n

24. If both balls are in the sand
column17:
yours is in the footprint.

\n

25. Don''t buy a putter until you have had a chance to throw it.

\n

26. The inevitable result of any golf lesson is the instant elimination of the one critical unconscious motion that allowed you to compensate for all your errors.]

[Murphy''s Laws of Martial Arts Ten scientific principles that apply to the study of all martial arts: The wimp who made it through the eliminations on luck alone will suddenly turn into Bruce Lee when you''re up against him. The referee will always be looking the other way when you score. The day you leave work early to make it to class on time, the sensei will be sick. The sensei will only use you during demonstrations for joint-locking techniques. If you have to use your training in self-defense, your attacker''s father will be a lawyer. After a flawless demonstration, you will trip on your way back to your seat. After years of training without a single injury, you will pull a groin muscle the night before your black belt exam. In an otherwise vacant locker room, the only other person will have the locker right next to yours. No matter how many times you take care of it before your promotion exam, you will invariably have to go to the bathroom when it''s your turn.]

column3: December 24th.''We''re too late! It''s already been here.'' ''Mulder

column10: with care.'' ''You really think someone''s been here?'' ''Someone
column11: or something.'' ''Mulder
column12: over here--it''s a fruitcake.'' ''Don''t touch it! Those things can be lethal.'' ''It''s O.K. There''s a note attached: ''Gonna find out who''s naughty and nice.'''' ''It''s judging them
column13: Scully. It''s making a list.'' ''Who? What are you talking about?'' ''Ancient mythology tells of an obese humanoid entity who could travel at  great speed in a craft powered by antlered servants. Once a year
column14: near the winter solstice
column15: this creature is said to descend from the heavens to reward its followers and punish disbelievers with jagged chunks of anthracite.'' ''But that''s legend
column16: Mulder--a story told by parents to frighten children. Surely you don''t believe it?'' ''Something was here tonight
column17: Scully. Check out the bite marks on this gingerbread man. Whatever tore through this plate of cookies was massive--and in a hurry.'' ''It left crumbs everywhere. And look
column18: Mulder
column19: this milk glass has been completely drained.'' ''It gorged itself
column20: Scully. It fed without remorse.'' ''But why would they leave it milk and cookies?'' ''Appeasement. Tonight is the Eve
column21: and nothing can stop its wilding.'' ''But if this thing does exist
column22: how did it get in? The doors and windows were locked. There''s no sign of forced entry.'' ''Unless I miss my guess
column23: it came through the fireplace.'' ''Wait a minute
column24: Mulder. If you''re saying some huge creature landed on the roof and came down this chimney
column25: you''re crazy. The flue is barely six inches wide. Nothing could get down there.'' ''But what if it could alter its shape
column26: move in all directions at once?'' ''You mean
column27: like a bowl full of jelly?'' ''Exactly. Scully
column28: I''ve never told anyone this
column29: but when I was a child my home was visited. I saw the creature. It had long white shanks of fur surrounding its ruddy
column30: misshapen head. Its bloated torso was red and white. I''ll never forget the horror. I turned away
column31: and when I looked back it had somehow taken on the facial features of my father.'' ''Impossible.'' ''I know what I saw. And that night it read my mind. It brought me a Mr. Potato Head
column32: Scully. It knew that I wanted a Mr. Potato Head!'' ''I''m sorry
column33: Mulder
column34: but you''re asking me to disregard the laws of physics. You want me to believe in some supernatural being who soars across the skies and brings gifts to good little girls and boys. Listen to what you''re saying. Do you understand the repercussions? If this gets out
column35: they''ll close the X-files.'' ''Scully
column36: listen to me: It knows when you''re sleeping. It knows when you''re awake.'' ''But we have no proof.'' ''Last year
column37: on this exact date
column38: SETI radio telescopes detected bogeys in the airspace over twenty-seven states. The White House ordered a Condition Red.'' ''But that was a meteor shower.'' ''Officially. Two days ago
column39: eight prized Scandinavian reindeer vanished from the National Zoo
column40: in Washington
column41: D.C. Nobody--not even the zookeeper--was told about it. The government doesn''t want people to know about Project Kringle. They fear that if this thing is proved to exist the public will stop spending half its annual income in a holiday shopping frenzy. Retail markets will collapse. Scully
column42: they cannot let the world believe this creature lives. There''s too much at stake. They''ll do whatever it takes to insure another silent night.'' ''Mulder
column43: I--'' ''Sh-h-h. Do you hear what I hear?'' ''On the roof. It sounds like ... a clatter.'' ''The truth is up there. Let''s see what''s the matter.'']

market down 11 percent since 1993
column2:
General Motors unveiled a new instant-win
airbag contest Monday. The new airbags
column3:
which award fabulous prizes upon
violent
column4: high-speed impact with another car or stationary object
column5:
will come
standard in all of the company''s 1997 cars.

\n

"Auto accidents have never been so exciting
column6:
said GM vice-president of
marketing Roger Jenkins, who expects the contest to boost 1997 sales
significantly. When you play the new GM Instant Win Airbag Game
column7:
your next
fatal collision could mean a trip for two to Super Bowl XXXI in New Orleans. Or
a year''s worth of free Mobil gasoline."

\n

Though it does not officially begin until Jan. 1
column9:
the airbag
promotion is already being tested in select cities
column10:
with feedback overwhelmingly
positive. "As soon as my car started to skid out of control
column11:
I thought to
myself
column12: ''Oh
column13: boy
column14:
this could be it--I could be a big winner!''" said Cincinnati''s
Martin Frelks
column15:
who lost his wife but won $50 Sunday when the Buick LeSabre they
were driving hit an oil slick at 60 mph and slammed into an oncoming truck.
"When the car stopped rolling down the embankment
column16: I knew Ellen was dead
column17:
but
all I could think about was getting the blood and glass out of my eyes so I
could read that airbag!"

\n

Hartford
column18: CT
column19:
resident Jonathan Ryerson was killed Sunday when his 1997
Pontiac LeMans hit a freight train. Ryerson won $50 in the accident. "It''s
really addictive
column20:
said Sacramento, CA, resident Marjorie Kamp, speaking from
her hospital bed, where she is listed in critical condition with severe brain
hemorrhaging and a punctured right lung. I''ve already crashed four cars trying
to win those Super Bowl tickets
column21: but I still haven''t won. I swear
column22:
I''m going to
win those tickets--even if it kills me!"

\n

Kamp said that as soon as she is well enough
column23:
she plans to buy a new
Pontiac Bonneville and drive it into a tree. GM officials are not surprised the
airbag contest has been so well received. "In the past
column24:
nobody really liked car
wrecks
column25: and that''s understandable. After all
column26: they''re scary and dangerous and
column27: sometimes
column28: even fatal
column29: GM CEO Paul Offerman said. But now
column30:
when you drive a
new GM car or truck
column31:
your next serious crash could mean serious cash. Who
wouldn''t like that?"

\n

Offerman added that in the event a motorist wins a prize but is killed
column32:
that prize will be awarded to the next of kin. According to GM''s official
contest rules
column33: odds of winning the grand prize
column34:
a brand-new 1997 Cutlass
Supreme
column35: are 1 in 43
column37: 000. Statistical experts
column38: however
column39:
say the real chances
of winning are significantly worse. "If you factor in the odds of getting in a
serious car accident in the first place--approximately 1 in 720
column40:
000--the actual
odds of winning a prize each time you step in your car are more like 1 in 31
trillion." Further
column41: even if one is in an accident
column42:
there is no guarantee the
airbag will inflate. "I was recently broadsided by a drunk driver in my new

and
because it was the side of my car that got hit

my airbag didn''t even inflate.
But what really gets me is the fact that the drunk driver
column46:
who rammed my side
with the front of his 1997 Buick Regal

won a $100 Office Depot gift
certificate. That''s just wrong."]

[41 Rules Men Wish Women Knew

\n

1. If you think you''re fat
column2:
you probably are. Don''t ask us.

2. Learn to work the toilet seat: if it''s up put it down.

3 . Don''t cut your hair. Ever.

4. Birthdays
column3: Valentines
column4: and Anniversaries are not quests to see if he can find the perfect present
column5:
again!

\n

5. If you ask a question you don''t want an answer to
column6:
expect an answer you don''t want to hear.

\n

6. Sometimes
column7:
he''s not thinking about you. Live with it.

\n

7. Don''t ask him what he''s thinking about unless you are prepared to discuss such topics as navel lent
column8:
the shotgun formation and monster trucks.

\n

8. Get rid of your cat. And no
column9: it''s not different
column10:
it''s just like every other cat.

9. Dogs are better than ANY cats. Period.

10. Sunday = Sports. It''s like the full moon or the changing of the tides. Let it be.

11. Shopping is not sport.

12. Anything you wear is fine. Really.

13. You have enough clothes.

14. You have too many shoes.

15. Crying is blackmail. Use it if you must
column11:
but don''t expect us to like it.

\n

16. Your brother is an idiot
column12:
your ex-boyfriend is an idiot and your Dad probably is too.

\n

17. Ask for what you want. Subtle hints don''t work.

\n

18. No
column13:
he doesn''t know what day it is. He never will. Mark anniversaries on a calendar.

\n

19. Yes
column14:
pissing standing up is more difficult than peeing from point blank range. We''re bound to miss sometimes.

\n

20. Most guys own two to three pairs of shoes-what makes you think we''d be any good at choosing which pair
column15: out of thirty
column16:
would look good with your dress?

21. Yes and No are perfectly acceptable answers.

22. A headache that lasts for 17 months is a problem. See a doctor.

23. Your Mom doesn''t have to be our best friend.

24. Foreign films are best left to foreigners.

25. Check your oil.

26. Don''t give us 50 rules when 25 will do.

27. Don''t fake it. We''d rather be ineffective than deceived.

28. It is neither in your best interest nor ours to take the quiz together.

29. Anything we said 6 or 8 months ago is inadmissible in an argument. All comments become null and void after 7 days.

30. If you don''t dress like the Victoria''s Secret girls
column17:
don''t expect us to act like soap opera guys.

\n

31. If something we said can be interpreted two ways
column18: and one of the ways makes you sad and angry
column19:
we meant the other one.

\n

32. Let us ogle. If we don''t look at other women
column20:
how can we know how
pretty you are?

33. Don''t rub the lamp if you don''t want the genie to come out.

34. You can either ask us to do something OR tell us how you want it done not both.

35. Whenever possible
column21:
please say whatever you have to say during commercials.

\n

36. Christopher Columbus didn''t need directions
column22:
and neither do we.

\n

37. Women wearing Wonderbras and low-cut blouses lose their right to complain about having their boobs stared at.

\n

38. Consider Golf a mini-vacation from you. We need it
column23:
just like you do.

39. Telling us that the models in the men''s magazines are airbrushed makes you look jealous and petty and it''s certainly not going to deter us from reading the magazines.

40. The relationship is never going to be like it was the first two months we were going out.

41. Anyone can buy condoms.]

So

column7:

\n

For example:

column4: "I''m sorry if I''ve been pensive
column5: dear. I was just reflecting on what a warm
column6: wonderful
column7: caring
column8: thoughtful
column9: intelligent
column10: beautiful woman you are and what a lucky guy I am to have met you." Obviously
column11: this statement bears no resemblance whatsoever to what the guy was really thinking at the time
column12:
which was most likely one of five things:

\n

a - Baseball b - Football c - How fat you are d - How much prettier she is than you e - How he would spend the insurance money if you died

\n

According to the Sassy article

column14: of Married With Children
column15: who was asked it by his wife
column16: Peg. "If I wanted you to know
column17:
Al said, I''d be talking instead of thinking."

The other questions also have only one right answer but many wrong answers:

2 - "Do you love me?"

The correct answer to this question is
column18: "Yes." For those guys who feel the need to be more elaborate
column19: you may answer
column20: "Yes
column21:
dear." Wrong answers include:

\n

a - I suppose so. b - Would it make you feel better if I said yes? c - That depends on what you mean by "love". d - Does it matter? e - Who
column22:
me?

\n

3 - "Do I look fat?"

\n

The correct male response to this question is to confidently and emphatically state
column23: "No
column24:
of course not" and then quickly leave the room. Wrong answers include:

\n

a - I wouldn''t call you fat
column25:
but I wouldn''t call you thin either. b - Compared to what? c - A little extra weight looks good on you. d - I''ve seen fatter. e - Could you repeat the question? I was thinking about your insurance policy.

\n

4 - "Do you think she''s prettier than me?"

\n

The "she" in the question could be an ex-girlfriend
column26: a passer-by you were staring at so hard that you almost caused a traffic accident or an actress in a movie you just saw. In any case
column27: the correct response is
column28: "No
column29:
you are much prettier." Wrong answers include:

a - Not prettier
column30: just pretty in a different way. b - I don''t know how one goes about rating such things. c - Yes
column31:
but I bet you have a better personality. d - Only in the sense that she''s younger and thinner. e - Could you repeat the question? I was thinking about your insurance policy.

\n

5 - "What would you do if I died?"

\n

Correct answer: "Dearest love
column32: in the event of your untimely demise
column33: life would cease to have meaning for me and I would perforce hurl myself under the front tires of the first Domino''s Pizza truck that came my way." This might be the stupidest question of the lot

as is illustrated by the following stupid exchange:

"Dear

column36: dear
column37: I would be extremely upset

column40: dear" said the husband. "Don''t you like being married?" said the wife. "Of course I do
column41: dear" he said. "Then why wouldn''t you remarry?" "Alright
column42: said the husband, I''d remarry." "You would?" said the wife
column43: looking vaguely hurt. "Yes" said the husband. "Would you sleep with her in our bed?" said the wife after a long pause. "Well yes

column1:
[Murphy''s Laws Of Law Enforcement

\n

1. Bullet Proof vests aren''t.

\n

2. The bigger they are
column2: the harder they fall.  They also punch
column3:
kick and
choke harder too.

\n

3. The speed at which you respond to a fight call is inversely proportional to how long you''ve been a cop.

\n

4. Tear gas works on cops too
column4: and regardless of wind direction
column5:
will always blow back in your face.

\n

5. High speed chases will always proceed from an area of light traffic to an area of extremely heavy traffic.

\n

6. If you know someone who tortures animals and wets the bed
column6:
he is either a serial killer or he works for Internal Affairs.

7. Placing a gun back in a shoulder holster with your finger on the trigger will cause you to walk with a limp.

8. Flash hiders don''t really.

9. If you have cleared all the rooms and met no resistance
column7:
you and your entry team have probably kicked in the door of the wrong house.

\n

10. If a cop swings a baton in a fight
column8:
he will hit other cops more often than he will hit the bad guys he swings at.

\n

11. Domestic arguments will always migrate from an area of few available weapons (living room)
column9:
to an area with many available weapons (kitchen).

\n

12. If you have just punched out a handcuffed prisoner for spitting at you
column10:
you are about to become a star on Eyewitness News.

\n

13. Bullets work on veteran cops too. They also work on weight lifters
column11: martial arts experts
column12: department marksmen
column13: Vice cops
column14: S.W.A.T. jocks
column15:
and others who consider themselves immortal.

\n

14. When a civilian sees a blue light approaching at a high rate of speed
column16:
he will always pull into the lane the cop needs to use.

\n

15. If you drive your patrol car to the geometric center of the Gobi Desert
column17:
within five minutes a dumb-ass civilian will pull along side you and ask for directions.

\n

16. You can never drive slow enough to please the citizens who don''t need a cop
column18:
and you can never drive fast enough to please the ones who do.

\n

17. Any suspect with a rifle is a better shot than any cop with a pistol.

\n

18. From behind you
column19:
the bad guys can see your night sights as well as you
can.

\n

19. On any call
column20: there will always be more bad guys than there are good guys
column21: and the farther away your back-up
column22:
the more there will be.

\n

20. The longer you''ve been a cop
column23:
the shorter your flashlight and your temper gets.

\n

21. Whatever you are about to do
column24: if there is a good chance it will get you killed
column25:
you probably shouldn''t do it.

\n

22. You should never do a shotgun search of a dark warehouse with a cop whose nickname is "Boomer".

\n

23. The better you do your job
column26: the more likely you are to be shot
column27: injured
column28: complained on
column29: sued
column30: investigated
column31:
or subpoenaed on your day off.

\n

24. If a large group of drunk bikers is "holed-up" in a house
column32: the Department will send one officer in a beat car.  If there is one biker "holed-up" in a house
column33: they will send the entire S.W.A.T. Team.]

an old lady comes up to them and says

column5:
so they
asked the old lady.

\n

"Well
column6:
there''s a very secretive tribe of Aborigines in the
outback that only do this dance called the Butcher dance once a

This excited the explorers greatly. "Do you know where we can
find this tribe?"

\n

The lady replied "Yes I do
column7: and if you leave tomorrow

you
should just make it in time. First
column9:
you need to travel 2 hours

which is very treacherous.
Then
column13:
you will need to ford a river at the bottom of the

and then it is an hour walk
across a desert to a group of small hills

and over those hills

Well

the explorer knows that he must get this dance to complete

column18:
and then
after 4 hours north

so they''re forced to

2 of the

and his crewman drops because of heat

"Oh

- Soak your gloves and store them in the freezer after every use.

column2:

carrying two pairs of skis
column4:
accessory bag and poles. Pretend you are looking for
your car. Sporadically drop things.
- Place a small but angular pebble in your shoes
column5:
line them with crushed ice
and then tighten a C-clamp around your toes.
- Buy a new pair of gloves and immediately throw one away.
- Secure one of your ankles to a bed post and ask a friend to run into you at
high speed.
- Go to McDonald''s and insist on paying $8.50 for a hamburger. Be sure you are
in the longest line.
- Clip a lift ticket to the zipper of your jacket and ride a motorcycle fast
enough to make the ticket lacerate your face.
- Drive slowly for five hours - anywhere - as long as it''s in a snowstorm and
you''re following an 18 wheeler.
- Fill a blender with ice
column6:
hit the pulse button and let the spray blast your
face. Leave the ice on your face until it melts. Let it drip into your clothes.
- Dress up in as many clothes as you can and then proceed to take them off
because you have to go to the bathroom.
- Slam your thumb in a car door. Don''t go see a doctor.
- Repeat all of the above every Saturday and Sunday until it''s time for the
real thing.]

column1:
[French-Bashing to Be Olympic Sport

\n

2/18/2003 - William Grim

\n

Geneva - At its annual meeting
column2:
the International Olympic Committee has decided to add French-Bashing to its roster of medal sports in both the Summer and Winter Games.

\n

"We thought it was about time
column3: said Jesus de Manuel y Corazon, Chairman of the IOC and the 1968 European French-Bashing Champion. Everbody hates those little lying
column4: cowardly
column5: collaborating
column6: garlic-eating
column7: never-bathing
column8: nose-picking French bastards. It''s time that French-Bashing was recognized for the truly international sport that it is
column9: one
column10: I might add
column11:
that is much more popular than soccer."

\n

In Summer French-Bashing the Basher runs along a 25 meter path to the Bashee (or the Pierre as it is sometimes called)
column12: a typical French sissy picked randomly from the Paris phone book. The first phase of the Bash is called Verbal Bashing in which the Basher has 20 seconds to hurl insults at the Bashee until he starts to cry like a little girl. Then comes the second phase
column13: or Physical Bashing in which the Basher whacks the Bashee over the head with a baseball bat. Play continues until the Bashee surrenders
column14: which in most cases happens immediately because the Bashee is a scairdy-cat Frog after all. Scoring is similar to that in diving in which points are awarded on style
column15:
technique and degree of

difficulty.

Winter French-Bashing resembles its Summer counterpart with the exception that the Basher approaches the Bashee on skis.

Sports writers are predicting French-Bashing to be the biggest spectator sport of all time
column16:
with the potential of billions of dollars in TV revenues and hundreds of millions of dollars in endorsement contracts for world-class bashers.

\n

The United States and Great Britain are already being touted as gold medal contenders for the 2006 Games
column17: with Canada (the only country to produce both world-class bashers and bashees) a very serious challenger.]

[Good afternoon. I''m Al Gore
column2:
and I''d like to tell you about myself.
I know a lot about hardship
column3:
because I came into this world as a poor black
child in a tiny town in the backwoods of Tennessee. I was born in a log cabin
that I built with my own hands. I taught myself to read by candlelight and
helped support my 16 brothers and sisters by working summers as a deck hand on a
Mississippi River steamboat.
My mother taught me the value of education
column4:
so every day; I would walk 5 miles
to a one-room schoolhouse. I was a mischievous
column5: fun-loving scamp
column6:
thought I
never dreamed that one-day
column7:
my youthful escapades would serve as the inspiration
for "Huckleberry Finn."
Back then
column8: black folks in the south were second-class citizens. One day
column9:
a
traveling minister came through town
column10:
and I asked him if anyone was ever going
to do something to guarantee civil rights for all Americans. Well
column11:
I guess I
made an impression. You see
column12: the minister''s name was Martin Luther King
column13:
Jr.
My father was a United States Senator. He once perched me on his knee and
said
column14: "Son
column15: if you work hard and listen to your mama
column16:
someday you can live in a
hotel in Washington
column17: D.C.
column18:
and go to an exclusive prep school."
But life of privilege was not for me. After getting my high school diploma
column19:
I
took a job in a hot
column20:
dirty textile mill. I was so appalled at the treatment of
the workers there that I organized a union. Later
column21:
that experience inspired a
movie - which is why
column22: to this day
column23:
my close friends at the AFL-CIO call me
"Norma Rae."
When word got out what an 18 year old factory worker had done
column24:
Harvard called
and offered me a scholarship. I captained the hockey team to four consecutive
national championships
column25:
but I also played football and was good enough to win
the Heisman Trophy.
During my college years
column26:
I lived in a housing project and moonlighted playing
lead guitar for a little rock band. You may have heard of it-the Rolling

But there was a war going on

column1: [Dilberted To be exploited and oppressed by your boss. Derived from the experiences of Dilbert
