column1:
[Dear Technical Support:

\n

I''m currently running the latest version of GirlFriend and I''ve
been having some problems lately. I''ve been running the same
version of DrinkingBuddies 1.0 forever as my primary
application
column2:
and all the GirlFriend releases I''ve tried have
always conflicted with it. I hear that DrinkingBuddies won''t
crash if GirlFriend is run in background mode and the sound is
turned off. But I''m embarrassed to say I can''t find the switch
to turn the sound off. I just run them separately
column3:
and it works
okay.

\n

Girlfriend also seems to have a problem co-existing with my Golf
program
column4:
often trying to abort Golf with some sort of timing
incompatibility.

\n

I probably should have stayed with GirlFriend 1.0
column5:
but I thought
I might see better performance from GirlFriend 2.0. After months
of conflicts and other problems
column6:
I consulted a friend who has
had experience with GirlFriend 2.0. He said I probably didn''t
have enough cache to run GirlFriend 2.0
column7:
and eventually it would
require a Token Ring to run properly. He was right - as soon as
I purged my cache
column8:
it uninstalled itself.

\n

Shortly after that
column9:
I installed GirlFriend 3.0 beta. All the
bugs were supposed to be gone
column10: but the first time I used it
column11:
it
gave me a virus anyway. I had to clean out my whole system and
shut down for a while. I very cautiously upgraded to GirlFriend
4.0. This time I used a SCSI probe first and also installed a
virus protection program. It worked okay for a while until I
discovered that GirlFriend 1.0 was still in my system. I tried
running GirlFriend 1.0 again with GirlFriend 4.0 still
installed
column12:
but GirlFriend 4.0 has a feature I didn''t know about
that automatically senses the presence of any other version of
GirlFriend and communicates with it in some way
column13:
which results
in the immediate removal of both versions.

\n

The version I have now works pretty well
column14:
but there are still
some problems. Like all versions of GirlFriend
column15:
it is written in
some obscure language I can''t understand
column16:
much less reprogram.
Frankly I think there is too much attention paid to the look and
feel rather than the desired functionality. Also
column17:
to get the
best connections with your hardware
column18:
you usually have to use
gold-plated contacts. And I''ve never liked how GirlFriend is
totally "object-oriented." A year ago
column19:
a friend of mine upgraded
his version of GirlFriend to GirlFriendPlus 1.0
column20:
which is a
Terminate and Stay Resident version of GirlFriend. He discovered
that GirlFriendPlus 1.0 expires within a year if you don''t
upgrade to Fiancee 1.0. So he did
column21: but soon after that
column22:
he had
to upgrade to Wife 1.0
column23:
which he describes as a huge resource
hog. It has taken up all his space
column24:
so he can''t load anything
else. One of the primary reasons he decided to go with Wife 1.0
was because it came bundled with FreeSexPlus. Well
column25:
it turns out
the resource allocation module of Wife 1.0 sometimes prohibits
access to FreeSexPlus
column26:
particularly the new Plug-Ins he wanted
to try. On top of that
column27:
Wife 1.0 must be running on a well
warmed-up system before he can do anything. Although he did not
ask for it
column28:
Wife 1.0 came with MotherInLaw which has an
automatic pop-up feature he can''t turn off.

\n

I told him to try installing Mistress 1.0
column29:
but he said he heard
if you try to run it without first uninstalling Wife 1.0
column30:
Wife
1.0 will delete MSMoney files before doing the uninstall itself.
Then Mistress 1.0 won''t install anyway because of insufficient
resources. Any Ideas???]

column1: [Our story begins at the Olympics
column2: specifically the wrestling event. It is narrowed down to the Russian or the American for the gold medal. Before the final match
column3: the American wrestler''s trainer came to him and said
column4: "Now don''t forget all the research we''ve done on this Russian. He''s never lost a match because of this "pretzel" hold he has. Whatever you do
column5: don''t let him get you in this hold! If he does
column6:
you''re finished!"

\n

The wrestler nodded in agreement.

\n

Now
column7: to the match: The American and the Russian circled each other several times looking for an opening. All of a sudden the Russian lunged forward
column8: grabbing the American and wrapping him up in the dreaded pretzel hold! A sigh of disappointment went up from the crowd
column9: and the trainer buried his face in his hands for he knew all was lost. He couldn''t watch the ending. Suddenly there was a scream
column10: a cheep from the crowd
column11: and the trainer raised his eye just in time to see the Russian flying up in the air. The Russian''s back hit the mat with a thud
column12: and the American weakly collapsed on top of him
column13:
getting the pin and winning the match. The trainer was astounded!

\n

When he finally got the American wrestler alone
column14: he asks
column15:
"How did you ever get out of that hold? No one has ever done it before!"

\n

The wrestler answered
column16: "Well
column17: I was ready to give up when he got me in that hold
column18: but at the last moment
column19: I opened my eyes and saw this pair of balls right in front of my face. I thought I had nothing to lose
column20: so with my last ounce of strength I stretched out my neck and bit those babies just as hard as I could. "You''d be amazed how strong you get when you bite your own balls!"]

column1: [After Christmas break
column2:
the teacher asked her small pupils how they spent their holidays.

\n

One small boy''s reply went like this:

\n

We always spent Christmas with Grandpa and Grandma. They used to live here in a big brick house
column3:
but Grandpa got retarted and they moved to Arizona.

\n

They go to a big building they call a wrecked hall. But if it was wrecked
column4: it is fixed now. They play games there and do exercises
column5:
but they don''t do them very well.

\n

There is a swimming pool and they go to it and just stand in the water with their hats on. I guess they don''t know how to swim. My Grandma used to bake cookies and stuff
column6:
but I guess she forgot how. Nobody cooks there. They all go to fastfood restaurants.

\n

As you come into the park
column7:
there is a doll house with a man sitting in it. He watches all day so they can''t get out without him seeing them. They wear badges with their names on them. I guess they don''t know who they are.

\n

My Grandma said Grandpa worked hard all his life and earned his retardment. I wish they would move back home
column8: but I guess the man in the doll house won''t let them out.]

it gave me a virus anyway.

but GirlFriend 4.0 has

it is written in some obscure
language I can''t understand

much less reprogram. Frankly I think there is

so he can''t load anything else. One of the primary

column26:
it turns out the resource allocation module of Wife 1.0 often

Wife
1.0 came with MotherInLaw 1.0

3 Snickers bars.

Diet Rules
1. If no one sees you eat something
column12:
it has no calories.

\n

2. When drinking a diet Coke with a chocolate bar
column13:
the fat in the chocolate is cancelled out by the diet Coke.

\n

3. When you eat with someone else
column14:
calories don''t count if you do not eat more than they do.

\n

column15: toast
column16: cheesecake
column17:
vodka...)

\n

column19: Minties
column20: Maltesers
column21:
Jaffas and frozen Cokes.

7. Biscuit pieces have no calories because breaking the biscuits up causes calorie leakage.

8. Food licked from knives and spoons has no fat if you are in the process of cooking something.

9. Foods that are the same color have the same amount of fat. Examples are: spinach and peppermint ice cream
column22:
apples and red jelly snakes.

10. Chocolate is like a food-color wildcard and may be substituted for any other color.

11. Anything eaten while standing has no calories due to gravity and the density of the calorie mass.

12. Food consumed from someone else''s plate has no fat as it rightfully belongs to the other person and will cling to his/her plate. (Oh
column23:
how fat likes to cling!)

\n

And remember: ''STRESSED'' SPELT BACKWARDS IS ''DESSERTS''!]

column1: [YOU KNOW YOU''RE DRINKING TOO MUCH COFFEE WHEN . .    Juan Valdez named his donkey after you   You ski uphill   You get a speeding ticket even when you''re parked   You speed walk in your sleep   You have a bumper sticker that says: ''Coffee drinkers are good in           the sack.'' You''re the employee of the month at the local coffeehouse and you          don''t even work there   You''ve worn out your third pair of tennis shoes this week   Your eyes stay open when you sneeze   You chew on other people''s fingernails   The nurse needs a scientific calculator to take your pulse   Your T-shirt says
column2: ''Decaffeinated coffee is the devil''s coffee.''    Your so jittery that people use your hands to blend their margaritas   You can type sixty words per minute with your feet   You can jump-start your car without cables   Cocaine is a downer   All your kids are named ''Joe.''    You don''t need a hammer to pound in nails   Your only source of nutrition comes from ''Sweet & Low.''    You don''t sweat
column3: you percolate   You buy milk by the barrel   You''ve worn out the handle on your favorite mug   You go to AA meetings just for the free coffee   You walk twenty miles on your treadmill before you realize it''s not         plugged in   You forget to unwrap candy bars before eating them   Charles Manson thinks you need to calm down   You''ve built a miniature city out of little plastic stirrers   People get dizzy just watching you   When you find a penny
column4: you say

column7: I''ll have a cup.''    You''ve worn the finish off your coffee table   The Taster''s Choice couple wants to adopt you   Starbucks owns the mortgage on your house   Your taste buds are so numb you could drink your lava lamp   You''re so wired
column8: you pick up AM radio   People can test their batteries in your ears   Your life''s goal is to amount to a hill of beans   Instant coffee takes too long   You channel surf faster without a remote   When someone says. ''How are you?''
column9: you say

You get drunk just so you can sober up   You speak perfect Arabic without ever taking a lesson   Your Thermos is on wheels   Your lips are permanently stuck in the sipping position   You have a picture of your coffee mug on your coffee mug   You can outlast the Energizer bunny   You short out motion detectors   You have a conniption over spilled milk   You don''t even wait for the water to boil anymore   Your nervous twitch registers on the Richter scale   You think being called a ''drip'' is a compliment   You don''t tan

column1:
[The College Food Chain:

The Dean
Leaps tall buildings in a single bound. Is more powerful than a locomotive. Is faster than a speeding bullet. Walks on water. Gives policy to God.

The Department Head
Leaps short buildings in a single bound. Is more powerful than a switch engine. Is just as fast as a speeding bullet. Talks with God.

Professor
Leaps short buildings with a running start and favorable winds. Is almost as powerful as a switch engine. Is faster than a speeding BB. Walks on water in an indoor swimming pool. Talks with God if a special request is honored.

Associate Professor
Barely clears a Quonset hut. Loses tug of war with a locomotive. Can fire a speeding bullet. Swims well. Is occasionally addressed by God.

Assistant Professor
Makes high marks on the walls when trying to leap tall buildings. Is run over by locomotives. Can sometimes handle a gun without inflicting self-injury. Treads water. Talks to animals.

Instructor
Climbs walls continually. Rides the rails. Plays Russian Roulette. Walks on thin ice. Prays a lot.

Graduate Student
Runs into buildings. Recognizes locomotives two out of three times. Is not issued ammunition. Can stay afloat with a life jacket. Talks to walls.

Undergraduate Student
Falls over doorstep when trying to enter buildings. Says "Look at the choo-choo". Wets himself with a water pistol. Plays in mud puddles. Mumbles to themselves.

Department Secretary
Lifts buildings and walks under them. Kicks locomotives off the tracks. Catches speeding bullets in their teeth and eats them. Freezes water with a single glance. they ARE God.]

column3:
000.

Further
column4: she said that since such a large sum was involved

she would deal only with the president of the bank to make the necessary arrangements.

column6: in fact
column7: full of cash. He called upstairs and explained the situation to the bank president
column8:
who agreed to see the woman.

\n

The teller escorted her to the presidents office
column9: and the president invited her to have a seat

which she accepted.

\n

She repeated her request to open an account. The president said he would take care of it personally
column11:
but his curiosity was killing him.

\n

He said
column12:
"Mind if I ask how you happened to come into such a large sum of cash?"

\n

"Not at all
column13:
was her reply.

I bet."

"You bet?" he countered.

"At the racetrack
column14: or on professional sports
column15:
or in casinos...?"

\n

"Nothing like that
column16:
she said.

\n

I just ... bet. For example
column17: I''ll bet you $50
column18:
000 that by tomorrow morning your balls will be square."

The president chuckled but
column19: seeing that the lady had the funds to back up such a wild bet
column20:
agreed.

\n

They shook hands on it
column21: and she promised to return at nine the next morning to follow up
column22:
and left.

As the day wore on
column23: the president found himself frequently checking to make sure that all was in order. It was

but just as a precaution he cancelled his regular Tuesday-afternoon golf match and went home early.

\n

The next morning when he showered

he was actually quite relieved to find that nothing had changed drastically while he slept.

He confidently headed for the bank

laughing all the way at the unexpected windfall that was about to become his.

The little old lady showed up promptly at the appointed hour
column27: accompanied by a young man. When the president asked who he was
column28: she replied that he was her lawyer
column29:
who she always brought along when payoffs involving significant sums were involved.

The president told her that sorry
column30: she had lost that particular bet

column1: [Dear Sanju baba
column2:
\n

I''m writting this slow because I know you can''t read fast. We don''t live where
we did when you left home.

\n

Your Pa read in the newspaper that most accidents happen within 20 minutes of
your home
column3:
so we moved. I won''t be able to send you the address because the last
family that lived here took the house numbers when they moved so they wouldn''t
have to change their address.

\n

This place is really nice. I even has a washing machine. I''m not sure it works
so well
column4: though
column5: Last week I put a load of clothes in and pulled the chain
column6:
we
haven''t seen it since. The weather isn''t bad here.

\n

It only rained twice last week; the first time for three days and the second
time for fourdays. About that coat you wanted me to send; your Uncle said it
would be too heavy to send in the mail with the buttons on
column7:
so we cut them off
and put them in the pockets.

\n

Bablu locked his keys in the car yesterday. We were really worried because it
took him two hours to get me and your father out. Your sister had a baby this
morning
column8:
but I haven''t found out what it is yet so I don''t know if you are an
aunt or uncle.

\n

The baby looks just like your brother. Uncle Rakesh fell into a swimming pool
last week. Some men tried to pull him out but he fought them off and drowned. We
had him cremated; he burned for three days.

\n

Three of your friends went off a bridge in a pickup truck. Bablu was driving.
He rolled down the window and swam to safety. Your other two friends were in the
back
column9:
they drowned because they couldn''t get the tailgate down.

\n

I am now closing this letter and will share more good news with you again next
time. Your Favorite Aunt
column10:
\n

P.S...If this letter does not reach you
column11: please let me know
column12:
I will send u
another.]

column1:
[This quiz consists of four questions that tell you whether or not you are
qualified to be a professional.

\n

There is no need to cheat. The questions are not that difficult. You just
need to think like a professional.
1.How do you put a giraffe into a refrigerator?
2.How do you put an elephant into a refrigerator?
3.The Lion King is hosting an animal conference. All the animals attend except
one. Which animal does not attend?
4.There is a river filled with crocodiles. How do you cross it?
SCROLL DOWN FOR THE ANSWERS.

\n

Answers
1.Open the refrigerator put in the giraffe and closes the door. This question
tests whether or not you are doing simple things in a complicated way.
2.Open the refrigerator remove the giraffe and put in the elephant and close
the door. This question tests your foresight.
3.The elephant. The elephant is in the refrigerator! This tests if you are
capable of comprehensive thinking. Okay
column2:
if you did not answer the last three
questions correctly
column3:
this one may be your last chance to test your
qualifications to be a professional.
4.Simply swim through it. All the crocodiles are attending the animal meeting!
This question tests your reasoning ability.
If you answered four out of four questions correctly
column4:
you are a true
professional. Wealth and success await you. If you answered three out of four
column5:
you have some catching up to do but there''s hope for you. If you answered two
out of four
column6:
consider a career as a hamburger flipper in a fast food joint. If
you answered one out of four
column7:
try selling some of your organs. It''s the only way
you will ever make any money. If you answered none correctly
column8:
consider a career
that does not require any higher mental functions at all
column9:
such as law or
politics.]

column1: [The opening credits of "The Simpsons" shows Bart Simpson writing on the school chalk board the same sentence over and over again
column2: (the ole "write it 100 times" punishment). Each episode however the sentence is different. Someone (not me
column3: thank you) went to the trouble to tape the shows
column4: watch and copy down the sentences that Bart writes on the chalk board. The following are the collected writings of Bart Simpson from the opening credits. Even if you''re not a fan
column5:
you''ll like these:

I will not carve gods.

I will not spank others.

I will not aim for the head.

I will not barf unless I''m sick

I will not expose the ignorance of the faculty.

I saw nothing unusual in the teacher''s lounge.

I will not conduct my own fire drills.

Funny noises are not funny.

I will not snap bras.

I will not fake seizures.

This punishment is not boring and pointless.

My name is not Dr. Death.

I will not defame New Orleans.

I will not prescribe medication.

I will not bury the new kid.

I will not teach others to fly.

I will not bring sheep to class.

A burp is not an answer.

Teacher is not a leper.

Coffee is not for kids.

I will not eat things for money.

I will not yell "She''s Dead" at roll call.

The principal''s toupee is not a Frisbee.

I will not call the principal "spud head".

Goldfish don''t bounce.

Mud is not one of the 4 food groups.

No one is interested in my underpants.

I will not sell miracle cures.

I will return the seeing-eye dog.

I do not have diplomatic immunity.

I will not charge admission to the bathroom.

The cafeteria deep fryer is not a toy.

All work and no play makes Bart a dull boy.

I will not say "Springfield" just to get applause.

I am not authorized to fire substitute teachers.

My homework was not stolen by a one-armed man.

I will not go near the kindergarten turtle.

I am not deliciously saucy.

Organ transplants are best left to professionals.

The Pledge of Allegiance does not end with "Hail Satan".

I will not celebrate meaningless milestones.

There are plenty of businesses like show business.

Five days is not too long to wait for a gun.

I will not waste chalk.

I will not skateboard in the halls.

Underwear should be worn on the inside.

I will never win an emmy.

The Christmas Pageant does not stink.

I will not torment the emotionally frail.]

column1:
[The 5 questions most feared by men are:
1. What are you thinking about?
2. Do you love me?
3. Do I look fat in this?
4. Do you think she is prettier than me?
5. What would you do if I died?

\n

What makes these questions so difficult is that every one is guaranteed to explode into a major argument if the man answers incorrectly (i.e.
column2: tells the truth). Therefore
column3: as a public service
column4: each question is analyzed below
column5:
along with possible responses.

\n

Question # 1: What are you thinking about? The proper answer to this
column6: of course
column7: is: " I''m sorry if I''ve been pensive
column8: dear. I was just reflecting on what a warm
column9: wonderful
column10: thoughtful
column11: caring
column12: intelligent woman you are
column13: and how lucky I am to have met you." This response obviously bears no resemblance to the true answer
column14:
which most likely is one of the following:
a. Football.
b. Golf.
c. How fat you are.
d. How much prettier she is than you
e. How I would spend the insurance money if you died.

\n

Perhaps the best response to this question was offered by Al Bundy
column15: who once told Peg
column16: "If I wanted you to know what I was thinking
column17:
I would be talking to you!"

\n

Question # 2: Do you love me? The proper response is: "YES!" or
column18: if you feel a more detailed answer is in order
column19: "Yes
column20:
dear."

Inappropriate responses include:
a. Oh Yeah
column21:
sh@*-loads.
b. Would it make you feel better if I said yes?

d. Does it matter?
e. Who
column22:
me?

\n

Question # 3: Do I look fat?
The correct answer is an emphatic: "Of course not!" Among the incorrect answers are:
a. Compared to what?
b. I wouldn''t call you fat
column23:
but you''re not exactly thin.
c. A little extra weight looks good on you.
d. I''ve seen fatter.
e. Sorry what did you say? I was just thinking about how I would spend the insurance money if you died.

\n

Question # 4: Do you think she''s prettier than me?
Once again
column24:
the proper response is an emphatic: "Of course not!" Incorrect responses include:
a. Yes
column25:
but you have a better personality
b. Not prettier
column26:
but definitely thinner
c. Not as pretty as you when you were her age
d. Define pretty
e. Sorry what did you say ? I was just thinking about how I would spend the insurance money if you died.

\n

Question # 5: What would you do if I died? A definite no-win question.(The real answer
column27: of course
column28:
is "Buy a Lotus and a Boat").

\n

No matter how you answer this

MAN: Okay
column31:
I''d get married again.

MAN: (makes audible groan)
WOMAN: Would you sleep with her in our bed?
MAN: Where else would we sleep?
WOMAN: Would you put away my pictures
column32:
and replace them with pictures of her?
MAN: That would seem like the proper thing to do.
WOMAN: And would you let her use my golf clubs?
MAN: She can''t use them; she''s left-handed.
WOMAN: - - - silence - - -
MAN: Sh&%.]

column2: who would actually choose to be Republican?)                     By Daniel MendelsohnThe startling discovery that affiliation with the Republican Party is genetically determined
column3: announced by scientists in the current issue of the journal Nurture
column4: threatens to overshadow the announcement by scientists that there might be a gene for homosexuality in men. Reports of the gene that codes for political conservatism
column5: discovered after a long study of quintuplets in Orange County
column6: Calif.
column7: has sent shock waves through the medical
column8: political and golfing communities. Psychologists and psychoanalysts have long believed that Republicans'' unnatural and frequently unconstitutional tendencies result from unhealthy family life -- a remarkable high percentage of Republicans had authoritarian
column9: domineering fathers and emotionally distant mothers who didn''t teach them how to be kind and gentle. But biologists have long suspected that conservatism in inherited. "After all
column10: said on author of the Nurture article, it''s quite common for a Republican to have a brother or sister who is a Republican." The finding has been greeted with relief by parents and friends of Republicans
column11: who have tended to blame themselves for the political views of otherwise lovable people -- their children
column12: friends and unindicted co-conspirators. One mother
column13: a long time Democrat
column14: clasped her hands in ecstasy on hearing of the findings: "I just knew it was genetic
column15: she said, seated beside her two sons, both avowed Republicans. I just knew nobody would actually choose that lifestyle!" When asked what the Republican lifestyle was
column16: she said
column17: "Well
column18: you can just tell from watching TV
column19: like at the convention in Houston: the loud outfits
column20: the flaming xenophobia
column21: the flamboyant demagogy -- you know." Both sons said they had suspected their Republicanism from an early age but did not confirm it until they were in college
column22: when they became convinced it wasn''t just a phase they were going through. Despite the near certainty of the medical community about Republicanism''s genetic origins
column23: troubling issues remain. The Nurture article offered no response to the suggestion that the startling high incidence of Republicanism among siblings could result from the fact that they hare not only genes but also psychological and emotional attitudes
column24: being the products of the same parents and family dynamics. And it remains to be explained why so many avowed Democrats are known to vote Republican occasionally -- or at least to fantasize about doing so. Polls show that three out of five adult Democrats admit to having had a Republican experience. In well-adjusted people
column25: however
column26: this experimentation rarely outlasts adolescence. Surprisingly
column27: some Republican activists hail the findings as a step forward rather that as an invitation to more conservophobia. They agree than since Republicans didn''t "choose" their unwholesome lifestyle any more that someone "chooses" to have a ski-jump nose
column28: they shouldn''t be denied civil rights to which normal people are entitled. Other Republicans
column29: recalling 19th century studies that "proved" the mental inferiority of blacks
column30: find the frenzied search for the biological cause of Republicanism pointless
column31: if not downright sinister. But for most real Americans
column32: the discovery opens a window on a brighter tomorrow. In a few years
column33: gene therapy could eradicate Republicanism altogether. If conservatism is not the result of sheer orneriness (as many suspect) but is something Republicans can''t help and probably even don''t like
column34: there''s no reason why we shouldn''t tolerate Republicans in the military or even high elected office -- provided they don''t flaunt their political beliefs.]

column1:
[A little corporate humor
----------------------
I took some friends out to dinner last week
column2: and I noticed a spoon in the shirt pocket of our waiter as he handed us the menus. It seemed a little  odd
column3: but I dismissed it as a random thing. Until our busboy came with  water & tableware; he too
column4: sported a spoon in his breast pocket. I looked  around the room
column5: and all the waiters
column6: waitresses
column7: busboys
column8:
etc. had spoons in their pockets.

\n

When our waiter returned to take our order
column9: I just had to ask
column10:
"Why the spoons?"

\n

"Well
column11:
he explained, our parent company recently hired some Andersen
Consulting efficiency experts to review all our procedures
column12:
and after
months of statistical analyses
column13:
they concluded that our patrons drop
spoons on the floor 73% more often than any other utensil; at a frequency of 3 spoons per hour per workstation. By preparing all our workers for this contingency in advance
column14:
we can cut our trips to the kitchen down and save time...nearly 1.5 extra man-hours per shift.
Just as he concluded
column15: a "ch-ching" came from the table  behind him
column16:
and he quickly replaced a fallen spoon with the one from his pocket.
"I''ll grab another spoon the next time I''m in the kitchen instead of
making a special trip
column17:
he proudly explained.
I was impressed. Thanks. I had to ask."
"No problem
column18:
he answered, then he continued to take our orders.

\n

As the members of my dinner party took their turns, my eyes darted
back & forth from each person ordering and my menu. That''s when, out of the corner of my eye, I spotted a thin, black thread protruding from our waiter''s fly. Again, I dismissed it; yet I had to scan the room and, sure enough, there were other waiters & busboys with strings hanging out of their trousers.
My curiosity overrode discretion at this point, so before he could leave I had to ask. Excuse me
column19: but...uh...why
column20:
or what...about that string?"
"Oh
column21: yeah" he began in a quieter tone. "Not many people are that observant. That same efficiency group found we could save time in the Men''s room
column22: too." "How''s that
column23:
I asked?"
"You see
column24: by tying a string to the end of our
column25: eh. . .
column26: selves
column27:
we can
pull it out at the urinals literally hands-free and thereby eliminate
the need to wash our hands
column28:
cutting time spent in the restroom by over
93%!" "Oh
column29: that makes sense
column30:
I said, but then thinking through the
process, I asked, Hey
column31: wait a minute.  If the string helps you pull it out
column32:
how do you get it back in?"

\n

"Well
column33:
he whispered, I don''t know about the other guys; but I use
the spoon in my pocket"!]

[You know you are addicted to coffee if ...

You grind your coffee beans in your mouth.

You sleep with your eyes open.

You have to watch videos in fast-forward.

The only time you''re standing still is during an earthquake.

You can take a picture of yourself from ten feet away without using the timer.

You''ve worn out your third pair of tennis shoes this week.

Your eyes stay open when you sneeze.

You chew on other people''s fingernails.

The nurse needs a scientific calculator to take your pulse.

You''re so jittery that people use your hands to blend their margaritas.

You can type sixty words per minute with your feet.

You can jump-start your car without cables.

You don''t sweat
column2:
you percolate.

You walk twenty miles on your treadmill before you realize it''s not plugged in.

You forget to unwrap candy bars before eating them.

You''ve built a miniature city out of little plastic stirrers.

People get dizzy just watching you.

Instant coffee takes too long.

You channel surf faster without a remote.

You have a picture of your coffee mug on your coffee mug.

You can outlast the Energizer bunny.

You short out motion detectors.

You don''t even wait for the water to boil anymore.

Your nervous twitch registers on the Richter scale.

You help your dog chase its tail.

You soak your dentures in coffee overnight.

Your first-aid kit contains two pints of coffee with an I.V. hookup.

You ski uphill.

You get a speeding ticket even when you''re parked.

You answer the door before people knock.

You haven''t blinked since the last lunar eclipse.]

column1: [An optimist sees the best in the world
column2: while a pessimist sees only the worst. An optimist finds the positive in the negative
column3:
and a pessimist can only find the negative in the positive.

\n

For example
column4: an avid duck hunter was in the market for a new bird dog. His search ended when he found a dog that could actually walk on water to retrieve a duck. Shocked by his find
column5:
he was sure none of his friends would ever believe him.

\n

He decided to try to break the news to a friend of his
column6: a pessimist by nature
column7:
and invited him to hunt with him and his new dog.

\n

As they waited by the shore
column8: a flock of ducks flew by. they fired
column9: and a duck fell. The dog responded and jumped into the water. The dog
column10: however
column11: did not sink but instead walked across the water to retrieve the bird
column12: never getting more than his paws wet. This continued all day long; each time a duck fell
column13:
the dog walked across the surface of the water to retrieve it.

\n

The pessimist watched carefully
column14: saw everything
column15:
but did not say a single word.

\n

On the drive home the hunter asked his friend
column16:
"Did you notice anything unusual about my new dog?"

\n

"I sure did
column17: responded the pessimist. Your dog can''t swim!"]

[Coach Bobby Ross had put together the perfect Lions team. The only thing he was missing was a good quarterback. He had scouted all the colleges
column2: and even the high schools
column3:
but he couldn''t find a ringer quarterback who could ensure a Super Bowl win.

\n

Then one night
column4: while watching CNN
column5: he saw a war-zone scene in Bosnia. In one corner of the background
column6: he spotted a young Bosnian soldier with a truly incredible arm. He threw a hand grenade straight into a 15th-story window 200 yards away -- ka-boom! He threw another hand grenade into a group of 10 soldiers 100 yards away -- ka-blooey! Then a car passed
column7:
going 90 mph -- bulls-eye!

\n

"I''ve got to get this guy!" Ross said to himself. "He has the perfect arm!"

\n

So
column8: he brings him to the States and teaches him the great game of football
column9:
and the Lions go on to win the Super Bowl for the first time in history.

\n

The young Bosnian is lionized as the Great Hero of football
column10: and when Ross asks him what he wants
column11: all the young man wants to do is to call his mother. "Mom
column12:
he says into the phone, I just won the Super Bowl."

\n

"I don''t want to talk to you
column13:
the old woman says. You deserted us. You are not my son."

\n

"I don''t think you understand
column14:
Mother!" the young man pleads. "I just won the greatest sporting event in the world. I''m here among thousands of my adoring fans."

\n

"No
column15: let me tell you
column16: the mother retorts. At this very moment
column17: there are gunshots all around us. The neighbourhood is a pile of rubble. Your two brothers were beaten within an inch of their lives last week
column18:
and this week your sister was raped in broad daylight."

\n

The old lady pauses
column19:
and then tearfully says:

\n

"...I''ll never forgive you for making us move to Detroit."]

column1: [Little Johnny was 7 years old
column2: and like other boys his age
column3:
rather curious. He had been hearing quite a bit about courting from other boys and he wondered what it was and how it was done.

\n

One day he took his questions to his mother
column4: and she became flustered. Instead of explaining things to Johnny she told him to hide behind the curtains one night and watch his older sister and her boyfriend. This he did
column5:
and the following morning Johnny described everything to his mother:

\n

"Sis and her boyfriend sat and talked for awhile
column6: then he turned off most of the lights. Then he started to kiss and hug her
column7: I figured sis must be getting sick because her face started looking funny. He must have thought so too because he put his hand inside her blouse to feel her heart
column8: just like the doctor would. Except he''s not as good as the doctor
column9:
because he seemed to have trouble finding her heart.

\n

He was getting sick too
column10: because pretty soon both of them started panting and getting all out of breath. His other hand must have been getting cold because he put it under her skirt. About this time
column11:
sis got toward the end of the couch.

\n

This was when the fever started. I know it was a fever because sis told him she was really HOT.

\n

Finally
column12:
I found out what was making them so sick.... a big eel had gotten inside his pants somehow. It just jumped out of his pants and stood there about 9 inches long. HONEST!

\n

Anyway
column13:
he grabbed it in one hand to keep it from getting away.

\n

When sis saw it she got really scared. Her eyes got big and her mouth fell open
column14:
and she started calling out to God and stuff like that. I should tell her about the ones I saw at the lake!

\n

Sis got brave and tried to kill the eel by bitting its head off. All of a sudden
column15:
she made a noise and let the eel go... I guess it bit her back.

Then she grabbed it with both hands and held it tight while he took a muzzle out of his pocket and slipped it over the eels head to keep it from biting again.

Sis lay back and spread her legs so she could get a scissor lock on it. And he helped by laying on the top of the eel. The eel put up a hell of a fight. Sis started groaning and squealing and her boyfriend almost upset the couch. I guess they wanted to kill the eel by squishing it between them.

After a while they both quit moving and gave a great sigh. Her boyfriend sat up and sure enough they had killed the eel...

I knew it was dead because it just hung there limp and some of its insides were hanging out. Sis and her boyfriend were a little tired from the battle
column16:
but they went on courting anyway.

\n

He started hugging and kissing her again. And by golly
column17:
the eel wasn''t dead after all. It jumped straight up and started to fight again.

\n

I guess eels are like cats.... they have nine lives or something.

\n

This time sis jumped up and tried to kill the eel by sitting on it. After about 35 minutes of struggle
column18:
they finally killed the eel. I know it was dead this time because I saw sis''s boyfriend peel off the skin and flush it down the toilet."

\n

Mother fainted.]

column1: [On a recent weekend in Atlantic City
column2:
a woman won a bucketful of
quarters at a slot machine. She took a break from the slots for
dinner with her husband in the hotel dining room. But first she
wanted to stash the quarters in her room. "I''ll be right back
and we''ll go to eat
column3:
she told her husband and she carried the
coin-laden bucket to the elevator.

\n

As she was about to walk into the elevator she noticed two men
already aboard. Both were black. One of them was big...very
big...an intimidating figure. The woman froze. Her first thought
was: These two are going to rob me. Her next thought was: Don''t
be a bigot, they look like perfectly nice gentlemen. But racial
stereotypes are powerful, and fear immobilized her.

\n

She stood and stared at the two men. She felt anxious,
flustered, ashamed. She hoped they didn''t read her mind, but
knew they surely did; her hesitation about joining them on the
elevator was all too obvious. Her face was flushed. She couldn''t
just stand there, so with a mighty effort of will she picked up
one foot and stepped forward and followed with the other foot
and was on the elevator. Avoiding eye contact, she turned around
stiffly and faced the elevator doors as they closed. A second
passed, and then another second, and then another. Her fear
increased! The elevator didn''t move. Panic consumed her. My
God"
column4: she thought
column5:
"I''m trapped and about to be robbed!" Her
heart plummeted. Perspiration poured from every pore.

\n

Then...one of the men said
column6:
"Hit the floor." Instinct told her:
Do what they tell you. The bucket of quarters flew upwards as
she threw out her arms and collapsed on the elevator carpet. A
shower of coins rained down on her. "Take my money and spare
me"
column7:
she prayed.

\n

More seconds passed. She heard one of the men say politely
column8: "Ma''am
column9: if you''ll just tell us what floor you''re going to
column10:
we''ll
push the button." The one who said it had a little trouble
getting the words out. He was trying mightily to hold in a belly
laugh. She lifted her head and looked up at the two men. They
reached down to help her up. Confused
column11:
she struggled to her
feet.

\n

"When I told my man here to hit the floor
column12:
said the average
sized one, I meant that he should hit the elevator button for
our floor. I didn''t mean for you to hit the floor
column13:
ma''am." He
spoke genially. He bit his lip. It was obvious he was having a
hard time not laughing.

\n

She thought: "My God
column14:
what a spectacle I''ve made of myself." She
was too humiliated to speak. She wanted to blurt out an apology
column15:
but words failed her. How do you apologize to two perfectly
respectable gentlemen for behaving as though they were going to
rob you? She didn''t know what to say.

\n

The 3 of them gathered up the strewn quarters and refilled her
bucket. When the elevator arrived at her floor they insisted on
walking her to her room. She seemed a little unsteady on her
feet
column16:
and they were afraid she might not make it down the
corridor. At her door they bid her a good evening.

\n

As she slipped into her room she could hear them roaring with
laughter while they walked back to the elevator. The woman
brushed herself off. She pulled herself together and went
downstairs for dinner with her husband.

\n

The next morning flowers were delivered to her room--a dozen
roses. Attached to EACH rose was a crisp one hundred dollar
bill. The card said: "Thanks for the best laugh we''ve had in
years." It was signed
column17: Eddie Murphy & Michael Jordan]

[UPI, Portland, OR] Doctors at Portland''s University Hospital said Wednesday an Oregon man shot through the skull by a hunting arrow is lucky to be alive, and will be released soon from the hospital.

Tony Roberts, 25, lost his right eye last weekend during an initiation into a men''s rafting club, Mountain Men Anonymous, in Grants Pass, Ore. A friend tried to shoot a beer can off his head, but the arrow entered Roberts'' right eye. Doctors said had the arrow gone 1 millimeter to the left, a major blood vessel would have cut and Roberts would have died instantly.

Neurosurgeon Dr. Johnny Delashaw at the University Hospital in Portland said the arrow went through 8 to 10 inches of brain, with the tip protruding at the rear of his skill, yet somehow managed to miss all major blood vessels. Delashaw also said had Robert tried to pull the arrow out on his own he surely would have killed himself.

Roberts admitted afterwards he and his friends had been drinking that afternoon. Said Roberts, I feel so dumb about this."

No charges have been filed but the Josephine County district attorney''s office said the initiation stunt is under investigation.]

column1: [Just in case you weren''t feeling too old today
column2:
this will certainly change things.

Each year the staff at Beloit College in Wisconsin puts together a list to try to give the Faculty a sense of the mind set of this year''s incoming freshman.

Here is this year''s list:

The people who are starting college this fall across the nation were born in 1982.

They have no meaningful recollection of the Reagan Era and probably did not know he had ever been shot.

They were prepubescent when the Persian Gulf War was waged. Black Monday
column3:
1987 is as significant to them as the Great Depression.

There has been only one Pope.

They were 11 when the Soviet Union broke apart and do not remember the Cold War.

They have never feared a nuclear war.

They are too young to remember the space shuttle blowing up.

Tianamen Square means nothing to them.

Bottle caps have always been screw off and plastic.

Atari predates them
column4:
as do vinyl albums.

The expression (you sound like a broken record) means nothing to them.

They have never owned a record player.

They have likely never played Pac Man and have never heard of Pong.

They may have never heard of an 8 track. The Compact Disc was introduced when they were 1 year old.

As far as they know
column5:
stamps have always cost about 33 cents.

\n

They have always had an answering machine.

\n

Most have never seen a TV set with only 13 channels
column6:
nor have they seen a black and white TV.

\n

They have always had cable.

\n

There have always been VCRs
column7:
but they have no idea what BETA was.

\n

They cannot fathom not having a remote control
column8:
let alone one with a cord.

\n

They don''t know what a cloth baby diaper is
column9: or know about the ''Help me
column10:
I''ve fallen and I can''t get up'' commercial.

Feeling old Yet? There''s more:

They were born the year that the Walkman was introduced by Sony.

Roller skating has always meant inline for them.

Jay Leno has always been on the Tonight Show.

They have no idea when or why Jordache jeans were cool.

Popcorn has always been cooked in the microwave.

They have never seen Larry Bird play.

They never took a swim and thought about Jaws.

The Vietnam War is as ancient history to them as WWI
column11:
WWII and the Civil War.

They have no idea that Americans were ever held hostage in Iran.

They can''t imagine what hard contact lenses are.

They don''t know who Mork was or where he was from.

They never heard: ''Where''s the beef?''
column12: ''I''d walk a mile for a Camel
column13: '' or ''De plane
column14:
de plane!''.

They do not care who shot J. R. and have no idea who J.R. was.

The Titanic was found? They thought we always knew.

Michael Jackson has always been white.

Kansas
column15: Chicago
column16: Boston
column17: America
column18: and Alabama are places
column19:
not rock bands.

McDonalds never came in styrofoam containers.

There has always been MTV.

They don''t have a clue how to use a typewriter.]

Got a call from a woman said that her laser printer was having problems: the bottom half of her printed sheets were coming out blurry. It seemed strange that the printer was smearing only the bottom half. I walked her through the basics
column2: then came over and printed out a test sheet. It printed fine. I asked her to print a sheet

\n

************

\n

I had been doing Tech Support for Hewlett-Packard''s DeskJet division for about a month when I had a customer call with a problem I just couldn''t solve. She could not print yellow. All the other colors would print fine
column5: which truly baffled me because the only true colors are cyan
column6: magenta
column7: and yellow. For instance
column8: green is a combination of cyan and yellow
column9:
but green printed fine. Every color of the rainbow printed fine except for yellow.

I had the customer change ink cartridges. I had the customer delete and reinstall the drivers. Nothing worked. I asked my co-workers for help; they offered no new ideas. After over two hours of troubleshooting

************

column1: [Dear Tech Support

Last year I upgraded from Boyfriend 5.0 to Husband 1.0 and noticed a slow down in the performance of flower and jewelry applications that had operated flawlessly under Boyfriend 5.0. In addition

column4: but installed undesirable programs such as NFL 5.0 and NBA 3.0. Conversation 8.0 no longer runs and Housecleaning 2.6 crashes the system. I''ve tried running Nagging 5.3 to fix these problems

Desperate

---

Dear Desperate
column6:
\n

First
column7: keep in mind
column8: Boyfriend 5.0 is an entertainment package
column9: while Husband 1.0 is an operating system. Try to enter the command C:/I THOUGHT YOU LOVED ME and install Tears 6.2. Husband 1.0 should automatically run the applications Guilty 3.0 and Flowers 7.0. But remember

column11: Happy Hour 7.0
column12:
or Beer 6.1. Beer 6.1 is a very bad program that will create SnoringLoudly.WAV files. DO NOT install Mother-In-Law 1.0 or reinstall another Boyfriend program. These are not supported applications and will crash Husband 1.0.

In summary
column13: Husband 1.0 is a great program
column14:
but it does have a limited memory and cannot learn new applications quickly. You might consider buying additional software to improve performance. I personally recommend Hot Food 3.0 and Lingerie 6.9.

Tech Support]

column1: [After a very successful career
column2:
a former Human Relations guru found herself at the pearly gates.

\n

"Welcome to Heaven
column3: said St.Peter. Before you get settled in though
column4: it seems we have a problem. You see
column5: strangely enough
column6: we''ve never once had a Human Resources Director make it this far
column7: and we''re not really sure what to do with you
column8:
so what we''re going to do is let you have a day in Hell and a day in Heaven and then you can choose whichever one you want to spend an eternity in."

\n

With that St. Peter put the executive in an elevator and went down to hell. The doors opened
column9: and she found herself stepping out onto the putting green of a beautiful golf course. In the distance was a country club
column10: and standing in front of her were all her friends - fellow executives that she had worked with - and they were all dressed in evening gowns and cheering for her. They ran up
column11:
kissed her and talked about old times.

\n

They played an excellent round of golf
column12: and at night went to the country club
column13: where she enjoyed an excellent steak and lobster dinner. She met the Devil
column14:
who was

\n

actually a really nice guy (kinda cute) and she had a great time telling jokes and dancing. She was having such a good time that before she knew it
column15:
it was time to leave. Everybody shook her hand and

\n

waved goodbye as she got on the elevator.

\n

The elevator went up and opened back up at the Pearly Gates
column16: and she found St. Peter waiting for her. "Now it''s time to spend a day in heaven
column17:
he said. So she spent the next 24 hours lounging around on clouds and playing the harp and singing. She had a

\n

great time, and before she knew it, her 24 hours were up and St. Peter came and got her and asked her to choose.

\n

The woman paused for a second and then replied, Well
column18: I never thought I''d say this
column19: I mean
column20: Heaven has been really great and all
column21:
but I think I had a better time in Hell." So St. Peter escorted her to the elevator and again she went down-down-down back to Hell.

\n

When the doors of the elevator opened
column22:
she found herself standing in a desolate wasteland covered in garbage and filth. She

\n

saw her friends were dressed in rags and were picking up the garbage and putting it in sacks. The Devil came up to her and put his arm around her.

\n

"I don''t understand
column23:
stammered the woman, yesterday I was here and there was a golf course and a country club and we ate

\n

lobster and we danced and had a great time. Now
column24:
all there is is a wasteland of garbage and all my friends look miserable."

\n

The Devil looked at her and smiled. "Yesterday
column25: we were recruiting you
column26: today you''re staff."]

column1:
[Worst Analagies Written By High Schoolers

\n

He spoke with the wisdom that can only come from experience
column2:
like a guy who went blind because he looked at a solar eclipse without one of those boxes with a pinhole in it and now goes around the country speaking at high schools about the dangers of looking at a solar eclipse without one of those boxes with a pinhole in it.

She caught your eye like one of those pointy hook latches that used to dangle from screen doors and would fly up whenever you banged the door open again.

The little boat gently drifted across the pond exactly the way a bowling ball wouldn''t.

McBride fell 12 stories
column3:
hitting the pavement like a Hefty Bag filled with vegetable soup.

\n

From the attic came an unearthly howl. The whole scene had an eerie
column4: surreal quality
column5:
like when you''re on vacation in another city and "Jeopardy" comes on at 7 p.m. instead of 7:30.

Her hair glistened in the rain like nose hair after a sneeze. Her eyes were like two brown circles with big black dots in the center.

Bob was as perplexed as a hacker who means to access T:flw.quid55328.comaaakk/ch@ung but gets T:flw.quidaaakk/ch@ung by mistake.

Her vocabulary was as bad as
column6: like
column7:
whatever.

\n

He was as tall as a six-foot-three-inch tree.

\n

The hailstones leaped from the pavement
column8:
just like maggots when you fry them in hot grease.

\n

Her date was pleasant enough
column9:
but she knew that if her life was a movie this guy would be buried in the credits as something like "Second Tall Man."

\n

Long separated by cruel fate
column10: the star-crossed lovers raced across the grassy field toward each other like two freight trains
column11: one having left Cleveland at 6:36 p.m. traveling at 55 mph
column12:
the other from Topeka at 4:19 p.m. at a speed of 35 mph.

\n

The politician was gone but unnoticed
column13:
like the period after the Dr. on a Dr Pepper can.

They lived in a typical suburban neighborhood with picket fences that resembled Nancy Kerrigan''s teeth.

John and Mary had never met. They were like two hummingbirds who had also never met.

The thunder was ominous-sounding
column14:
much like the sound of a thin sheet of metal being shaken backstage during the storm scene in a play.

\n

His thoughts tumbled in his head
column15:
making and breaking alliances like underpants in a dryer without Cling Free.

\n

The red brick wall was the color of a brick-red Crayola crayon.]

column1:
[1. The citrus soda 7-UP was created in 1929; "7" was selected because the original containers were 7 ounces. "UP" indicated the direction of the bubbles.

2. Mosquito repellents don''t repel. They hide you. The spray blocks the mosquito''s sensors so they don''t know you''re there.

3. Dentists have recommended that a toothbrush be kept at least 6 feet away from a toilet to avoid airborne particles resulting from the flush.

4. The liquid inside young coconuts can be used as substitute for blood plasma.

5. American car horns beep in the tone of F.

6. No piece of paper can be folded more than 7 times.

7. Donkeys kill more people annually than plane crashes.

8. 1 in every 4 Americans has appeared on television.

9. You burn more calories sleeping than you do watching television.

10. Oak trees do not produce acorns until they are fifty years of age or older.

11. The first product to have a bar code was Wrigley''s gum.

12. The king of hearts is the only king without a mustache.

13. A Boeing 747s wingspan is longer than the Wright brother''s first flight.

14. American Airlines saved $40
column2:
000 in 1987 by eliminating 1 olive from each salad served in first-class.

15. Venus is the only planet that rotates clockwise.

16. The first CD pressed in the US was Bruce Springsteen''s "Born in the USA."

17. Apples
column3: not caffeine
column4:
are more efficient at waking you up in the morning.

18. The 57 on the Heinz ketchup bottle represents the number of varieties of pickles the company once had.

19. The plastic things on the end of shoelaces are called aglets.

20. Most dust particles in your house are made from dead skin.

21. The first owner of the Marlboro company died of lung cancer.

22. Barbie''s full name is Barbara Millicent Roberts.

[One day, a man had an accident at work, which resulted in him getting his eye gouged out. column23: "there is a severe shortage on blue eyes. We had to give you a brown one. If somehow you can get hold of a blue eye
column24: and bring it here to the hospital

column1: [A Visitors'' Guide to Dallas
column2:
Texas
(Life in America''s fifth largest city)

\n

1. You must learn to pronounce the city name. It is DAL-LUS
column3:
or
DAA-LIS depending on if you live inside or outside LBJ Freeway.

\n

2. Forget the traffic rules you learned elsewhere. Dallas has
its own version of traffic rules....Hold on and pray. There is
no such thing as a dangerous high-speed chase in Dallas. We all
drive like that.

\n

3. All directions start with
column4:
"Go down to Beltline"...which has
no beginning and no end.

4. The Chamber of Commerce calls getting through traffic a
"scenic drive."

5. The morning rush hour is from 6:00 to 10:00. The evening rush
hour is from 3:00 to 7:00. Friday''s rush hour starts Thursday
morning.

6. If you actually stop at a yellow light
column5:
you will be rear
ended
column6:
cussed out and possibly shot. When you are the first one
on the starting line
column7:
count to five when the light turns green
before going to avoid getting into any cross-traffic''s way.

\n

7. Arapaho Road can only be pronounced by a native. The same
holds true for Wycliff Avenue
column8: Worcola Street
column9:
Sul Ross and
Routh Street.

\n

8. Construction on I-30 is a way of life and form of
entertainment.

\n

9. All unexplained sights are explained by the phrase
column10: "Oh
column11:
we''re in Fort Worth!!"

\n

10. If someone actually has their turn signal on
column12:
it is probably
a factory defect.

11. All old ladies with blue hair in pink Cadillacs have the
right of way.

12. Story Road mysteriously changes names as you cross
intersections. Unless you''re on Storey Rd......

13. If asking directions in Irving
column13:
you must have knowledge of
Spanish.

\n

14. Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport has four terminal
buildings connected by one tram that never works.

\n

15. A trip across town (east to west) will take a minimum of
four hours
column14:
although many north/south freeways have unposted
minimum speeds of 75. The minimum acceptable speed on the Dallas
North Toll Road is 85. Anything less is considered downright
sissy.

\n

16. The wrought iron on windows in and around Oak Cliff isn''t
ornamental.

\n

17. Never stare at the driver of the car with the bumper sticker
that says
column15: Keep honking. I''m reloading. In fact
column16:
don''t honk at
anyone. Concealed weapons are a jealously guarded
column17:
God-given
right.

\n

18. If you are in the left lane
column18:
and only going 70 in a 60 mph
zone...people are not waving when they go by.

19. The North Dallas Toll way is our daily version of NASCAR.

20. LBJ is called "The Death Trap" for two reasons: "death" and
"trap."

21. If it''s 100 degrees
column19:
Thanksgiving must be next weekend.

\n

22. If it''s 10 degrees and sleeting/snowing
column20:
the Fort Worth Live
Stock show is going on.

\n

23. If it''s rained 6 inches in the last hour
column21:
the Byron Nelson
Golf Classic is in the second round.

\n

24. Amusement parks
column22: stadiums
column23: arenas
column24: race tracks
column25: airports
column26:
etc. are conveniently located as far away from EVERYTHING as
possible so as to allow for ample parking on grassy areas.]

column1:
[Dear Mr. Johnson:
Ann Landers wouldn''t print this. I have nowhere else to turn. I have to get the word out. Warn other parents. I must be rambling on. Let me try and explain.

\n

It''s about my son
column2: Billy. He''s always been a good
column3: normal 10 year old boy. Well
column4:
last spring we sat down after dinner to select a summer camp for Billy.

\n

We sorted through the camp brochures. There were the usual camps with swimming
column5: canoeing
column6: games
column7: singing by the campfire -- you know. There were sports camps and specialty camps for weight reduction
column8: music
column9:
military camps and camps that specialized in Tibetan knot tying.

\n

I tried to talk him into Camp Winnepoopoo. It''s where he went last year. Billy would have none of it. Billy pulled a brochure out of his pocket. It was for a COMPUTER CAMP! We should have put our foot down right there
column10:
if only we had known. He left three weeks ago.

I DON''T KNOW WHAT HAS HAPPENED. He''s changed. I can''t explain it. See for yourself.

These are some of my little Billy''s letters: -----------------------------------

Letter # 1 ---------- The kids are dorky nerds. The food stinks. The computers are the only good part. We''re learning how to program. Late at night is the best time to program
column11: so they let us stay up. Love
column12:
Billy.

\n

Letter # 2 ------------- Dear Mom
column13:
\n

Camp is O.K. Last night we had pizza in the middle of the night. We all get to choose what we want to drink. By the way
column14: can you make Szechwan food? I''m getting used to it now. Gotta go
column15: it''s time for the flowchart class. Love
column16:
Billy.

\n

P.S. This is written on a word processor. Pretty swell
column17:
huh? It''s spell checked too.

\n

Letter # 3 ------------- Dear Mom
column18:
\n

Don''t worry. We do regular camp stuff. We told ghost stories by the glow of the green computer screens. It was real neat. I don''t have much of a tan cause we don''t go outside very often. You can''t see the computer screen in the sunlight anyway. That wimp camp I went to last year fed us weird food too. Lay off
column19: Mom. I''m okay
column20:
really.

\n

Love
column21:
Billy.

\n

Letter # 4 ------------- Dear Mom
column22:
\n

I''m fine. I''m sleeping enough. I''m eating enough. This is the best camp ever. We scared the counselor with some phony worm code. It was real funny. He got mad and yelled. Can you send more money? I''ve got to chip in on the phone bill. Did you know that you can talk to people on a computer? Give my regards to Dad.

\n

Love
column23:
Billy.

\n

Letter # 5 ------------- Dear Mother
column24:
\n

Forget the money for the telephone. We''ve got a way to not pay. Sorry I haven''t written. I''ve been learning a lot. I''m real good at getting onto any computer in the country. It''s really easy! I got into the university''s in less than fifteen minutes. Frederick did it in five
column25: he''s going to show me how. Frederick is my bunk partner. He''s really smart. He says that I shouldn''t call myself Billy anymore. So
column26:
I''m not.

\n

Signed
column27:
William.

\n

Letter # 6 ------------- Dear Mother
column28:
\n

How nice of you to come up on Parents Day. Why''d you get so upset? I haven''t gained that much weight. The glasses aren''t real. Everybody wears them. I was trying to fit in. Believe me
column29: the tape on them is cool. I thought that you''d be proud of my program. After all
column30: I''ve made some money on it. A publisher is sending a check for $30
column31: 000. Anyway
column32:
I''ve paid for the next six weeks of camp. I won''t be home until late August.

\n

Regards
column33:
William.

\n

Letter # 7 ------------- Mother
column34:
\n

Stop treating me like a child. True -- physically I am only ten years old. It was silly of you to try to kidnap me. Do not try again. Remember
column35: I can make your life miserable (i.e. - the bank
column36: credit bureau
column37:
and government computers). I am not kidding. O.K.? I won''t write again and this is your only warning. The emotions of this interpersonal communication drain me.

\n

Sincerely
column38:
William.

\n

What can I do
column39: Mr. Johnson? See what I mean? It''s been two weeks since I''ve heard from my little boy. I know that it''s probably too late to save my little Billy. But
column40: if by printing these letters you can save JUST ONE CHILD from a life of programming
column41: please
column42:
I beg of you to do so. Thank you very much.

\n

Sally Gates
column43: Concerned Parent]

Q: What is a volcano?
A: A mountain with the hiccups.

Q: What do you find at the end of everything?
A: The letter "g".

Q: What did the elephant do when he hurt his toe?
A: He called a toe truck.

Q: Why do two skunks argue?
A: Because they like to kick up a stink.

Q: What did the adding machine say to the cashier?
A: You can count on me.

Q: What is the best way to keep dogs out of the street?
A: Put them in a barking lot.

Q: Why did the cat sleep with a fan on?
A: He wanted to be a cool cat.

Q: What did the painter say to the wall?
A: One more crack and I''ll plaster you.

Q: Why is baseball like a cake?
A: They both need batters.

Q: What did one dandelion say to the other dandelion?
A: Take me to your weeder.

Q: What kind of shoes do you make with banana skins?
A: Slippers!

Q: What did the rug say to the floor?
A: I''ve got you covered!

Q: How do you make antifreeze?
A: You steal her blanket.

Q: Why does a cow wear a bell?
A: Because her horns don''t work.]

column1:
[What''s the difference between David Beckham and a new Airfix model?

\n

One''s a glueless kit...

\n

Submitted by Curtis
Edited by calamjo]
[The setting is Disneyland
column2: "The Happiest Place on Earth
column3:
where I had joined a couple of friends for a day of fun and adventure. After paying something approaching $30 each to get in, we wanted to conserve what little was left of our cash for important things like rubber lizards and the air hockey tables, so when it came time to eat we opted for a quick-n-cheap lunch rather than fine dining in one of their numerous restaurants.

Lunch consisted of one of those burritos in a plastic bag, and a can of cola. I could go into great detail here, but why bother. You know precisely what I''m getting at here: INTESTINAL GAS!

Funny thing is, lunch didn''t seem to give me any problem. I don''t think I flatulated once the whole afternoon. More junk food was consumed. Many violent games of air hockey were played. Little did I know what my bowels had in store.

So late in the afternoon we step in line for the Jungle Cruise ride (you''ll also find rubber lizards for sale in this area). The lines at Disneyland are densely packed in a serpentine configuration such that it''s pretty much impossible to bail out from the middle. As I shuffle around a bend deep into the line, I notice there''s a little girl right behind me who it would seem has been genetically engineered to be just the height that would place her nose precisely in line for problems.

Wouldn''t it be funny
column4:
I think to myself, if I had to flatulate right now?"

\n

We continue shuffling through the densely-packed line
column5: and just as we come to the exact center of the line
column6: with the small
column7: innocent child mere inches away and at least 20 feet of human bodies in all directions and nowhere to run
column8:
I did just that. I passed gas.

\n

However
column9: this was no ordinary flatus. Nothing like this has crept from my bowels before or since. This was ... The Doomsday Fart! You know the expression
column10: "silent but deadly"? You couldn''t have heard this one with a stethoscope
column11: but Landsat 4 probably picked it up in the thermal band. It was simply unholy. A fart that could melt diamond. The oil fires of Kuwait couldn''t hold a candle to this thing. Chernobyl? Child''s play! Weather patters were disrupted. LAX was "fogged in." The world knew a new evil on this day. A voluminous
column12: hot
column13: humid
column14:
painfully burning fart that makes the greenhose effect look like a pleasant alternative. It probably knocked down a couple local trailer parks just for good measure.

\n

I farted only once on this day
column15: but it was more than most people will manage in a lifetime. The line started moving. I did not look back
column16: for fear that I might see a live action replay of the scene in "Raiders of the Lost Ark" where people were melting and shriveling up (or would it be more like the ash bodies in Terminator 2?). We go around one of the bends in the line
column17:
headed back toward The Mushroom Cloud.

\n

My friends both choke
column18: look back at me
column19: and give the best glabe they can manage with their eyes watering like that. I''ve just got this big grin on my face. They do not need to ask where "It" came from (brave souls
column20: these folks - they still joined me on the submarine ride later). Rounding the corner myself
column21:
I get a glimpse of what''s left of the small child behind me.

\n

Her face is scrunched in pain
column22: her hands violently waving the air in front of her. I don''t think she needs to ask either. Except for the complete depilatation
column23:
it''s nothing a good plastic surgeon can''t fix.

\n

That evening
column24: we ate dinner in a restaurant.]

this

often at great sacrifice.

2) Of

or

column1:
[(A way to explain the Clinton situation to your kids)

\n

The Bubba of Scuz
And the Bimbo of Loo
column2:
were sharing a pizza
with nothing to do.

\n

They sat and they talked
column3:
Although little was said.
So they dabbled in
bumblefunumpus instead.

\n

(Which cannot be explained
and is never polite)
Whether done in the daylight
or darkness of night.

\n

But the Bubba of Scuz
was a Loyalty Scout.
Which meant that with Bimbos
column4:
funumping was out.

The Loyalty Scouts
(an unusual breed)
thought that telling the truth
was the best of good deeds.

If ever you slipped
into trouble so deep
that you thought that a lie
was the best way to keep

your brains in your head
and your seat in your pants
column5: a Loyalty Scout would say
column6:
"Don''t take the chance!"

\n

A Splonger named Ken
had been watching the glade
column7:
where the Bubba and Bimbo
funumped in the shade.

\n

"At last
column8:
said the Splong
(a responsible guy)
I now have what I need
to entice him to lie."

The Bubba of Scuz
was then pressured to tell
of the things he had done
in the glade by the dell.

"Did you yert with palookas?
Or miff some goopats?
I heard that you fleegered
a blooper with gnats!"

"I have done no such thing
column9:
said the Bubba of Scuz.
Those things aren''t the things
that a Scuz Bubba does."

\n

"But what about Bimbos?"
Inquired the Splong.
"Funumping with Bimbos
is equally wrong!"

\n

"I never funumped
with the Bimbo of Loo.
If you say that I did
column10:
what you say isn''t true."

\n

Except that it was
column11: bringing Bubba up short
column12:
when the Splonger named Ken
made his final report.

So take this advice
when you''re feeling ashamed.
Stick to the truth
or you''ll wind up defamed.

The Loyalty Scouts
will muster you out.
Your good friends will wonder
what you are about.

And history''s scribes
column13:
remembering you
will skip all the good
you endeavored to do.

\n

Like the Bubba of Scuz
who
column14: ''til history''s end
column15:
will be linked to his Bimbo
and the Splonger named Ken.]

column1:
[Election update from http://www.aaronsjokes.com/

\n

NOTICE OF REVOCATION OF INDEPENDENCE

\n

To the citizens of the United States of America
column2:
\n

In the light of your failure to elect a President of the USA and thus to govern yourselves
column3:
we hereby give notice of the revocation of your
independence
column4:
effective today.

\n

Her Sovereign Majesty Queen Elizabeth II will resume monarchial duties over all states
column5: commonwealths and other  territories.  Except Utah
column6:
which she does not fancy.

\n

Your new prime minister (The rt. hon. Tony Blair
column7:
MP for the 97.85%
of you who have until now been unaware that there is a world outside your borders) will appoint a minister for America without the need for further elections.

\n

Congress and the Senate will be disbanded. A questionnaire will be
circulated next year to determine whether any of you noticed.

\n

To aid in the transition to a British Crown Dependency
column8:
the following rules are introduced with immediate effect:

\n

1. You should look up "revocation" in the Oxford English Dictionary.
Then look up "aluminum". Check the pronunciation guide. You will be amazed at just how wrongly you have been pronouncing it. Generally
column9:
you should raise your vocabulary to acceptable levels. Look "vocabulary". Using the same twenty seven words interspersed with filler noises such as "like" and "you know" is an unacceptable and inefficient form of communication. Look up "interspersed".

2. There is no such thing as "US English". We will let Microsoft know on your behalf.

3. You should learn to distinguish the English and Australian accents.
It really isn''t that hard.

4. Hollywood will be required occasionally to cast English actors as the good guys.

5. You should relearn your original national anthem
column10: "God Save The Queen"
column11:
but only after fully carrying out task 1. We would not want you to get confused and give up half way through.

\n

6. You should stop playing American "football". There is only one kind of football. What you refer to as American "football" is not a very good game. The 2.15% of you who are aware that there is a world outside your borders may have noticed that no one else plays "American" football. You will no longer be allowed to play it
column12: and should instead play proper football. Initially
column13: it would be best if you played with the girls. It is a difficult game. Those of you brave enough will
column14: in time
column15:
be allowed
to play rugby (which is similar to American "football"
column16:
but does not involve stopping for a rest every twenty seconds or wearing full kevlar body armour like nancies). We are hoping to get together at least a US rugby sevens side by 2005.

\n

7. You should declare war on Quebec and France
column17:
using nuclear weapons if they give you any merde. The 98.85% of you who were not aware that there is a world outside your borders should count yourselves lucky. The Russians have never been the bad guys. "Merde" is French for "sh!t".

\n

8. July 4th is no longer a public holiday. November 8th will be a new
national holiday
column18:
but only in England. It will be called "Indecisive Day".

\n

9. All American cars are hereby banned. They are crap and it is for your own good. When we show you German cars
column19:
you will understand what we mean.

\n

10. Please tell us who killed JFK. It''s been driving us crazy.

\n

Thank you for your cooperation.]

column1: [A professor stood before his philosophy class and had some items in front of him.   When the class began
column2: wordlessly
column3:
he picked up a very large and empty mayonnaise jar and proceeded to fill it with golf balls.

He then asked the students if the jar was full. They agreed that it was.

So the professor then picked up a box of pebbles and poured them into the jar. He shook the jar lightly. The pebbles rolled into the open areas between golf balls.

He then asked the students again if the jar was full. They agreed it was.

The professor next picked up a box of sand and poured it into the jar. Of course
column4:
the sand filled up everything else.

\n

He asked once more if the jar was full. The students responded with a unanimous "yes."

\n

The professor then produced two cans of beer from under the table and poured the entire contents into the jar
column5:
effectively filling the empty space between the sand. The students laughed.

\n

"Now
column6: said the professor, as the laughter subsided, I want you to recognize that this jar represents your life.  The golf balls are the important things--your family
column7: your children
column8: your health
column9: your friends
column10: your favorite passions--things that if everything else was lost and only they remained
column11:
your life would still be full.

\n

"The pebbles are the other things that matter like your job
column12: your house
column13:
your car.

\n

The sand is everything else--the small stuff.

\n

"If you put the sand into the jar first
column14: he continued, there is no room for the pebbles or the golf balls.  The same goes for life.  If you spend all your time and energy on the small stuff
column15: you will never have room for the things that are important to you.  Pay attention to the things that are critical to your happiness.  Play with your children.  Take time to get medical checkups.  Take your partner out to dinner.  Play another 18.  There will always be time to clean the house
column16:
and fix the disposal.

\n

"Take care of the golf balls first
column17:
the things that really matter. Set your priorities. The rest is just sand."

\n

One of the students raised her hand and inquired what the beer represented.

\n

The professor smiled. "I''m glad you asked. It just goes to show you that no matter how full your life may seem
column18: there''s always room for a couple of beers."]
