Jesse James - I can list among my experience and skills: leadership, extensive travel, logistical organization, intimate understanding of firearms, and a knowledge of security measures at numerous banks.

Marie Antoinette - My management style has been criticized, but I''d like to think of my self as a people person.

Joseph Guillotine - I can give your company a head start on the competition.

Hamlet - My position was eliminated in a hostile takeover.

Lucretia Borgia - My greatest accomplishment? after I took over the department, our competition just seemed to drop out of sight one by one.

Pandora - I can bring a lot to your company. I like discovering new things.

Genghis Khan - My primary talent is downsizing. On my last job I downsized my staff, my organization, and the populations of several countries.

MacBeth - Would I go after my boss''s job? Do I look like the kind of guy who would knock off his boss for a promotion.

Lady Godiva - What do mean this isn''t business casual?

Elvis - My last boss and I...say, are you going to eat those fries] [There is a new virus going around, called ''work''. If you receive any sort of ''work'' at all, whether via email, internet or simply handed to you by a colleague...DO NOT OPEN IT.

Work has been circulating around our building for months and those who have been tempted to open ''work'' or even look at ''work'' have found that their social life is deleted and their brain ceases to function properly.

If you do encounter ''work'' via email or are faced with any ''work'' at all, then to purge the virus, send an email to your boss with the words ''Sorry...I''m off to the pub''. The ''work'' should automatically be deleted from your brain.

If you receive ''work'' in paper-document form, simply lift the document and drag the ''work'' to your garbage can. Put on your coat and skip to the nearest bar with two friends and order three pints of beer.

After repeating this action 14 times, you will find that ''work'' will no longer be of any relevance to you.

Send this message to everyone in your address book. If you do not have anyone in your address book, then I''m afraid the ''work'' virus has already corrupted your life.] [One sunny day Jesus, Moses and a small, elderly man were playing golf.

Jesus was the first to tee off and he hit the ball a little left and it ended
up in the water hazard. Because it was Jesus, his ball floated and when he got
down to the hazard he walked upon the water and hit the ball onto the green.

Moses was the next to tee off, and like Jesus he hit the ball into the water
hazard. When he got down to the hazard, he parted the waters and hit the ball
onto the green.

The little old man was next, and he too hit into the water hazard. Just then a
big fish swallowed the ball and began to swim away. A hawk swooped down and
grabbed the fish in its talons and started to fly off. As the hawk passed over
the green, it tightened its grip on the fish which caused the ball to pop out of
the fish. The ball landed on the green and rolled into cup.

Jesus then turned to the old man and said, Look Dad
column19: if you''re going to play
column20: play fair."]

column11:
000 a year just to play ball? It wouldn''t surprise me if

column1: [The Seven Deadly Sins of Gilligan''s Island theory is quite simple.Each of the seven characters on the island represents each of the seven deadly sins. Now
column2: this theory seems to fit upon initial inspection
column3: there are technical difficulties when you get down to THE MAN himself
column4: Gilligan. Run with me on this one...Most obvious is the Professor
column5: who fits PRIDE to a T. Any man who can make a ham radio out of some wire and two coconuts has to be pretty cocky. (His character was later revised and given a series of his own
column6: called MacGyver''.)For the sin of ENVY we need look no further than Maryann
column7: who may have worn those skimpy little tops
column8: but could never achieve Ginger''s glamour. (As an interesting and completely irrelevant side note
column9: a nationwide survey of college students a few years ago revealed that the professor and Maryann were voted the most likely couple to have ''done it'' on the island.)And who could doubt for a moment that Ginger is LUST incarnate? Sure
column10: the kids were supposed to think she was ACTING
column11: but we all know what being deprived episode after episode was doing to her. You know and I know that glazed look wasn''t boredom
column12: my friends.What kind of person takes a trunk full of money on a three-hour cruise? Mr Howell gets my vote for GREED.We are now left with three characters and three Deadly Sins. We have Gilligan
column13: the Skipper and Mrs Howell to whom we must match GLUTTONY
column14: SLOTH and ANGER. As you can see
column15: there is a Gilligan problem here. Certainly we can further eliminate Mrs Howell from this equation by connecting her with SLOTH. She did jack shit during her many years on the island and everybody knows it.This leaves ANGER and GLUTTONY
column16: either of which the Skipper had no shortage. He was
column17: after all
column18: a big guy with the tendency to hit Gilligan with his hat at least once an episode. After much consideration
column19: I have decided that he can easily do double-duty
column20: covering the two remaining Deadly Sins.So here we have the Seven Deadly Sins trapped in an endlessly recurring Hell of hope followed by denial and despair
column21: forced to live with each other in our TVs until the last re-run ends.And who is their captor? What keeps them trapped there? Gilligan. Gilligan is SATAN. Think about it.]

column1: [=> NAME: *Expecteria Trouserius* (Trouser Snake) => LOCATION: Throughout the world=> DESCRIPTION: One-eyed
column2: with mushroom-shaped head (other types come with extra layers of skin) Varying from pink to black. Fang-less with a highly venomous spit. (Spit can reach distances up to 2-3 feet) *Size varies from 3 to 12 inches
column3: depending on its mood & sub-species.=> SYMPTOMS: This snake attacks mainly women in the lower front abdomen
column4: resulting in an inconspicuous bump. Then a severe swelling followed by excruciating pain after nine months. The attack is not usually fatal. Beware: It has been known to attack men in the rear lower abdomen!=> HABITAT: Usually found in bedrooms
column5: but has been known to appear in the most unusual places.=> ANTIDOTE: Various types of vaccine available for women. However
column6: once the venom is injected into the body only drastic measures will ensure complete recovery. There is no known antidote for men.=> WHAT TO DO WHEN ATTACKEDTOURNIQUET: Do not apply a tourniquet as the venom is too deep in the body to be affected.CUTTING THE WOUND: This would be completely unnecessary and ineffective as the bleeding will stop after a few weeks anyhow.SUCKING THE WOUND: This method is the most popular with the victim
column7: but so far has not been reported to have led to any success.=> CONCLUSION: This snake
column8: although it is very aggressive and active
column9: is not necessarily a vermin
column10: and treated with the right respect
column11: makes a wonderful pet.]

column1: [One summer
column2: on a Friday afternoon
column3: a young man was being trained by his supervisor on his first day as a salesperson at a large department store. His supervisor was trying to show him the amount of things he could sell to customers by making them feel they needed the items. "Watch this
column4: he said and approached a man who has just entered the store. May I help you
column5: sir?" The man replied
column6: "I just moved into my first house and I need some fertiliser for my lawn."So the supervisor said
column7: "Well
column8: we have five- and ten-pound bags of fertiliser. I recommend you go with the ten pound bag.""Why is that?""The ten-pound bag will get you through most of the summer
column9: but the five-pound bag won''t
column10: the supervisor answered.Fine
column11: the man agreed, I''ll take the ten-pounder." "Very good sir. And would you like the stiff rake or the spring-rake with that?""Rake? What do I need that for?""Well sir
column12: said the supervisor authoritatively, if you don''t rake up the old dead grass before you spread the fertiliser
column13: it won''t all reach the soil.""All right then. I''ll get the stiff rake.""Very good sir. And would you like the fixed sprinkler or the oscillating sprinkler with that?"The man started to get a bit steamed and asked harshly
column14: "Sprinkler? Look
column15: I just came in here for some fertiliser. What do I need a sprinkler for?" Calmly
column16: the supervisor responded
column17: "Well sir
column18: if you water your lawn immediately after fertilising
column19: the fertiliser will sink into the soil more quickly and in no time at all
column20: you''ll have the greenest lawn in your neighbourhood."This sounded pretty good to the man so he picked up the fixed sprinkler. "OK
column21: then. I''ll take all this.""Very good sir. And would you like the electric or gas mower with that
column22: asked the supervisor.Now the customer had about had it and he all but blew up at the supervisor. LAWNMOWER? Look
column23: all I wanted when I came here was a bag of fertiliser. You''ve already managed to sell me a rake and a sprinkler besides. Give me one good reason why I should get a lawnmower
column24: too!"Calm as ever
column25: the supervisor said
column26: "Well sir
column27: if you get a lawnmower now
column28: then you''ll be all ready to start trimming your beautiful green grass the minute it starts getting too long. Your lawn will look like a golf course and you''ll be the envy of all your neighbours! Besides
column29: they are on sale this week only
column30: and you''re going to need it either way."Well
column31: the man figured that sounded OK and he really wanted to get out of there before he bought anything else so at last he relented. "Fine. I''ll get the electric mower
column32: but that''s it!""Very good sir. I''ll ring that up for you."After the man had left the store with all his new purchases
column33: the supervisor turned to the trainee and said
column34: "So
column35: do you think you could do that?" The trainee said that he thought he could and the supervisor directed him towards another customer.The trainee approached the puzzled-looking man and asked
column36: "May I help you sir?"The man replied
column37: "Yes. I need some tampons for my wife." Well
column38: the trainee is totally thrown off by this request. He can''t imagine what he could offer the man to go along with that. However
column39: he wanted to impress his boss so he thought hard. Suddenly
column40: he had it! "Very good sir. And would you like the electric or gas mower with that?""Mower? What the hell is wrong with you? I came in here looking for tampons. Why the hell should I get a lawnmower
column41: too?""Well sir
column42: the trainee answered, I figure your weekend is shot
column43: so you might as well cut the grass."]

These men were considered some of the worlds most successful of their days.

Now

if we know what ultimately became of them.

column8:
went insane.

column9: Richard Whitney
column10:
was released from prison to die at home.
4. The greatest wheat speculator

column13:
penniless.

column14:
shot himself.

also committed suicide.

However

column19: the PGA Champion and the winner of the most important golf tournament

was Gene Sarazen. What became of him?

\n

He played golf until he was 92
column22:
died in 1999 at the age of 95. He was financially secure at the time of his death.

\n

The Moral: Screw work. Play golf.]

column6: and belch
column7: however
column8: have been proven to add absolutely nothing to the wilderness experience.Lint from your navel makes a handy fire starter. Warning: Remove lint from navel before applying the match.You''ll never be lost if you remember that moss always grows on the north side of your compass.You can duplicate the warmth of a down-filled bedroll by climbing into a plastic garbage bag with several geese.The canoe paddle
column9: a simple device used to propel a boat
column10: should never be confused with a gnu paddle
column11: a similar device used by Tibetan veterinarians.When camping
column12: always wear a long-sleeved shirt. It gives you something to wipe your nose on.Take this simple test to see if you qualify for solo camping. Shine a flashlight into one ear. If the beam shines out the other ear
column13: do not go into the woods alone.A two-man pup tent does not include two men or a pup.A potato baked in the coals for one hour makes an excellent side dish. A potato baked in the coals for three hours makes an excellent hockey puck. In emergency situations
column14: you can survive in the wilderness by shooting small game with a slingshot made from the elastic waistband of your underwear.The guitar of the noisy teenager at the next campsite makes excellent kindling.The sight of a bald eagle has thrilled campers for generations. The sight of a bald man
column15: however
column16: does absolutely nothing for the eagle.It''s entirely possible to spend your whole vacation on a winding mountain road behind a large motor home.Bear bells provide an element of safety for hikers in grizzly country. The tricky part is getting them on the bears.In an emergency
column17: a drawstring from a parka hood can be used to strangle a snoring tent mate]

column1:
[Dilberted
To be exploited and oppressed by your boss. Derived from the
experiences of Dilbert
column2:
the geek-in-hell comic strip character.
"I''ve been dilberted again. The old man revised the specs for
the fourth time this week."

\n

Link Rot
The process by which links on a web page became obsolete as the
sites they''re connected to change location or die.

\n

Chip Jewelry
Euphemism for old computers destined to be scrapped or turned
into decorative ornaments. "I paid three grand for that Mac SE
column3:
and now it''s nothing but chip jewelry."

\n

Crapplet
A badly written or profoundly useless Java applet. "I just
wasted 30 minutes downloading this stinkin'' crapplet!"

\n

Plug-and-Play
A new hire who doesn''t need any training. "The new guy
column4: John
column5:
is
great. He''s totally plug-and-play."

World Wide Wait
The real meaning of WWW.

CGI Joe
A hard-core CGI script programmer with all the social skills and
charisma of a plastic action figure.

Dorito Syndrome
Feelings of emptiness and dissatisfaction triggered by addictive
substances that lack nutritional content. "I just spent six
hours surfing the Web
column6:
and now I''ve got a bad case of Dorito
Syndrome."

Under Mouse Arrest
Getting busted for violating an online service''s rule of
conduct. "Sorry I couldn''t get back to you. AOL put me under
mouse arrest."

Glazing
Corporate-speak for sleeping with your eyes open. A popular
pastime at conferences and early-morning meetings. "Didn''t he
notice that half the room was glazing by the second session?"

404
Someone who''s clueless. From the World Wide Web message "404
column7: URL Not Found
column8:
meaning that the document you''ve tried to access
can''t be located. Don''t bother asking him...he''s 404
column9:
man."

\n

Dead Tree Edition
The paper version of a publication available in both paper and
electronic forms
column10:
as in: "The dead tree edition of the San
Francisco Chronicle..."

\n

Egosurfing
Scanning the net
column11: databases
column12: print media
column13:
or research papers
looking for the mention of your name.

\n

Graybar Land
The place you go while you''re staring at a computer that''s
processing something very slowly (while you watch the gray bar
creep across the screen). "I was in graybar land for what seemed
like hours
column14:
thanks to that CAD rendering."

Open-Collar Workers
People who work at home or telecommute.

Squirt The Bird
To transmit a signal up to a satellite. "Crew and talent are
ready...what time do we squirt the bird?"

Brain Fart
A biproduct of a bloated mind producing information
effortlessly. A burst of useful information. "I know you''re busy
on the Microsoft story
column15:
but can you give us a brain fart on the
Mitnik bust?" Variation of old hackerslang that had more
negative connotations.

Keyboard Plaque
The disgusting buildup of dirt and crud found on computer
keyboards. "Are there any other terminals I can use? This one
has a bad case of keyboard plaque."

Career-Limiting Move (CLM)
Used among microserfs to describe an ill-advised activity.
Trashing your boss while he or she is within earshot is a
serious CLM.

Alpha Geek
The most knowledgeable
column16:
technically-proficient person in an
office or work group. "Ask Larry
column17:
he''s the alpha geek around
here."

Adminisphere
The rarified organizational layers beginning just above the rank
and file. Decisions that fall from the adminisphere are often
profoundly inappropriate or irrelevant to the problems they were
designed to solve.

Tourists
People who are taking training classes just to get a vacation
from their jobs. "We had about three serious students in the
class; the rest were tourists."

Blowing Your Buffer
Losing one''s train of thought. Occurs when the person you are
speaking with won''t let you get a word in edgewise or has just
said something so astonishing that your train gets derailed.
"Damn
column18:
I just blew my buffer!"

\n

Gray Matter
Older
column19:
experienced business people hired by young
entrepreneurial firms looking to appear more reputable and
established.

Bookmark
To take note of a person for future reference (a metaphor
borrowed from web browsers). "I bookmarked him after seeing his
cool demo at Siggraph."

Nyetscape
Nickname for AOL''s less-than-full-featured Web browser.

Beepilepsy
The brief seizure people sometimes suffer when their beepers go
off
column20:
especially in vibrator mode. Characterized by physical
spasms
column21: goofy facial expressions
column22:
and stopping speech in
mid-sentence.]

column1:
[Little Johnny was about 10 years old and curious as only a boy
should be. He had been hearing a lot about courting from other
boys so he asked his mother how it was done. She told him to
hide behind the curtains some night and watch his sister and her
boyfriend. So Johnny did and this is what happened (or at least
his version).

\n

"Sis and her boyfriend sat and talked awhile
column2:
then turned out
all the lights except the blue one
column3: then he started kissing her
column4:
and for some reason he put his hand inside her blouse. She
started giggling and ooing
column5: then he put his hand up her skirt
column6:
when he did this she began to moan and sigh.

\n

Then she slowly moved to the other end of the couch till she was
lying down. I think she had a backache
column7:
then he rolled over and
unzipped his pants and pulled out a Texas Eel. I don''t know what
it was doing in there but it was 8" long and 2" wide. He held it
in his hands so it wouldn''t get away. Sis tried to help him
column8:
so
she got a tight grip on it
column9:
she spread her legs far apart and
stuck this eel between her legs and got a good scissors hold on
it. He helped by lying on top of Sis to keep the eel from moving.

\n

The eel put up a hell of a fight though. Sis squalled and her
boyfriend nearly up set the couch. For a minute there I thought
the damn thing was getting away but Sis grabbed it just as it
was slipping out and stuck it back in.

\n

Soon they both gave a large sigh and stopped moving. First they
let the eel move but it didn''t. It tried to get away but her
boyfriend got up and the thing was dead. It just hung there
limber as a hot water bottle and its end was dripping. Sis and
her boyfriend were all tired out from the battle. They started
kissing and loving again and by God if that damn thing didn''t
come back to life again
column10:
so the battle started again.

\n

Well it sure was the best wrestling match I ever saw. This time
they really killed the eel. I saw her boyfriend pull its skin
off and flush it down the toilet."]

column1: [HAMMER: Originally employed as a weapon of war
column2:
the hammer nowadays is used as a kind of divining rod to locate expensive car parts not far from the object we are trying to hit.

\n

MECHANIC''S KNIFE: Used to open and slice through the contents of cardboard cartons delivered to your front door; works particularly well on boxes containing convertible tops or tonneau covers.

\n

ELECTRIC HAND DRILL: Normally used for spinning steel Pop rivets in their holes until you die of old age
column3:
but it also works great for drilling rollbar mounting holes in the floor of a sports car just above the brake line that goes to the rear axle.

\n

PLIERS: Used to round off bolt heads.

\n

HACKSAW: One of a family of cutting tools built on the Ouija board principle. It transforms human energy into a crooked
column4: unpredictable motion
column5: and the more you attempt to influence its course
column6:
the more dismal your future becomes.

\n

VISE-GRIPS: Used to round off bolt heads. If nothing else is available
column7:
they can also be used to transfer intense welding heat to the palm of your hand.

OXYACETELENE TORCH: Used almost entirely for lighting those stale garage cigarettes you keep hidden in the back of the Whitworth socket drawer (What wife would think to look in _there_?) because you can never remember to buy lighter fluid for the Zippo lighter you got from the PX at Fort Campbell.

ZIPPO LIGHTER: See oxyacetelene torch.

WHITWORTH SOCKETS: Once used for working on older British cars and motorcycles
column8:
they are now used mainly for hiding six-month old Salems from the sort of person who would throw them away for no good reason.

\n

DRILL PRESS: A tall upright machine useful for suddenly snatching flat metal bar stock out of your hands so that it smacks you in the chest and flings your beer across the room
column9:
splattering it against the Rolling Stones poster over the bench grinder.

\n

WIRE WHEEL: Cleans rust off old bolts and then throws them somewhere under the workbench with the speed of light. Also removes fingerprint whorls and hard-earned guitar callouses in about the time it takes you to say
column10:
"Django Reinhardt".

\n

HYDRAULIC FLOOR JACK: Used for lowering a Mustang to the ground after you have installed a set of Ford Motorsports lowered road springs
column11:
trappng the jack handle firmly under the front air dam.

EIGHT-FOOT LONG DOUGLAS FIR 2X4: Used for levering a car upward off a hydraulic jack.

TWEEZERS: A tool for removing wood splinters.

PHONE: Tool for calling your neighbor Chris to see if he has another hydraulic floor jack.

SNAP-ON GASKET SCRAPER: Theoretically useful as a sandwich tool for spreading mayonnaise; used mainly for getting dog-doo off your boot.

E-Z OUT BOLT AND STUD EXTRACTOR: A tool that snaps off in bolt holes and is ten times harder than any known drill bit.

TIMING LIGHT: A stroboscopic instrument for illuminating grease buildup on crankshaft pulleys.

TWO-TON HYDRAULIC ENGINE HOIST: A handy tool for testing the tensile strength of ground straps and hydraulic clutch lines you may have forgotten to disconnect.

CRAFTSMAN 1/2 x 16-INCH SCREWDRIVER: A large motor mount prying tool that inexplicably has an accurately machined screwdriver tip on the end without the handle.

BATTERY ELECTROLYTE TESTER: A handy tool for transferring sulfuric acid from a car battery to the inside of your toolbox after determining that your battery is dead as a doornail
column12:
just as you thought.

\n

AVIATION METAL SNIPS: See hacksaw.

\n

TROUBLE LIGHT: The mechanic''s own tanning booth. Sometimes called a drop light
column13: it is a good source of vitamin D
column14: "the sunshine vitamin"
column15: which is not otherwise found under cars at night. Health benefits aside
column16: its main purpose is to consume 40-watt light bulbs at about the same rate that 105-mm howitzer shells might be used during
column17: say
column18: the first few hours of the Battle of the Bulge. More often dark than light
column19:
its name is somewhat misleading.

\n

PHILLIPS SCREWDRIVER: Normally used to stab the lids of old-style paper-and-tin oil cans and splash oil on your shirt; can also be used
column20: as the name implies
column21:
to round off Phillips screw heads.

\n

AIR COMPRESSOR: A machine that takes energy produced in a coal-burning power plant 200 miles away and transforms it into compressed air that travels by hose to a Chicago Pneumatic impact wrench that grips rusty suspension bolts last tightened 40 years ago by someone in Abingdon
column22: Oxfordshire
column23: and rounds them off.]

Redneck Dining Out

Redneck Entertaining in Your Home

Redneck Etiquette for All Occasions

column9: she finds that she cannot maneuver the step

column1:
[The Darwin awards are given to people who have done their best to aid humanity in eliminating (their own) undesirable genes from the human gene pool.

\n

More Darwin Award Nominees:

\n

Doctors at Portland''s University Hospital said Wednesday an Oregon man shot through the skull by a hunting arrow is lucky to be alive
column2: and will be released soon from the hospital. Tony Roberts
column4: lost his right eye last weekend during an initiation into a men''s rafting club
column5: Mountain Men Anonymous
column6: in Grants Pass
column7: Ore. A friend tried to shoot a beer can off his head
column8: but the arrow entered Roberts'' right eye. Doctors said had the arrow gone 1 millimeter to the a major blood vessel would have cut and Roberts would have died instantly. Neurosurgeon Dr. Johnny Delashaw at the University Hospital in Portland said the arrow went through 8 to 10 inches of brain
column9: with the tip protruding at the rear of his skill
column10:
yet somehow managed to miss all major blood vessels. Delashaw also said had Robert tried to pull the arrow out on his own he surely would have killed himself. Roberts admitted afterwards he and his friends had been drinking that afternoon. Said Roberts "I feel so dumb about this." No charges have been filed but the Josephine Court District attorney''s office said the initiation stunt is under investigation.

\n

Robert Puelo
column12: was apparently being disorderly in a St. Louis market. When the clerk threatened to call police
column13: Puelo grabbed a hot dog shoved it in his mouth
column14: and walked out without paying for it. Police found him unconscious in front of the store: paramedics removed the six-inch wiener from his throat
column15:
where it had choked him to death.

\n

Blasting Cap Explodes in Man''s Mouth at Party

\n

A man at a party popped a blasting cap into his mouth and bit down
column16: triggering an explosion that blew off his lips
column17: teeth and tongue
column18: state police said Wednesday. Jerry Stromyer
column20: of Kincaid
column21: bit the blasting cap as a prank during a party late Tuesday night
column22: said Cpl. M.D. Payne. "Another man had it in an aquarium
column23: hooked to a battery
column24: and was trying to explode it
column25: Payne said. It wouldn''t go off and this guy said
column26: ''I''ll show you how to set it off. "He put it in his mouth and bit down. It blew all his teeth off
column27: his tongue and his lips
column28: Payne said. Stromyer was listed in guarded condition Wednesday, with extensive facial injuries, according to a spokesman at Charleston Area Medical Division. I just can''t imagine anyone doing something like that
column29:
Payne said.

O.K.... one more, but that''s it:

Another true story of a guy in L.A. who was afraid of heights, and had to go up on his roof to adjust his TV antenna. So he tied a rope around himself, and tied the other end to the bumper of his car. Well, he should have told his wife . She went out and got in the car to go to the store. The man was pulled off the roof and dragged down the street before someone alerted the wife to the fact that she had some extra cargo. The man was rushed to the hospital where he spent a couple of weeks recovering, more or less.

Unfortunately, the story does not end there. To make amends, the wife planned a little surprise party for her husband the day he returned home. She invited several couples over to enjoy the festivities, most of them smokers. Since the wife and husband smoked too, they had several lighters around the house, and the wife decided to fill them before the guests arrived. To be safe, she took them all into the bathroom and filled them over the toilet.

Have you guessed yet? Yes, the husband used the bathroom immediately afterward, and threw his cigarette into the toilet while sitting.] [Clarification Of Corporate Lingo

column9: of course

wails.

Now Mr. Jones is convulsing and sobbing uncontrollably and beginning to wither off the bench into a sobbing pitiful mass.

dude...
You don''t have to do all that stuff - she''s dead!"]

column1:
[Dear Tech Support:
Last year I upgraded from Boyfriend 5.0 to Husband 1.0 and
noticed a slow down in the overall performance
column2:
particularly in the flower and jewellery applications that
had operated flawlessly under Boyfriend 5.0. In addition
column3: Husband 1.0 uninstalled many other valuable programs
column4:
such
as Romance 9.5 and Personal Attention 6.5
column5:
but installed
undesirable programs such as NFL 5.0 and NBA 3.0. and now
Conversation 8.0 no longer runs and Housecleaning 2.6
simply crashes the system. I''ve tried running Nagging 5.3
to fix these problems
column6:
but to no avail. What can I do?

Desperate

********************************************

Dear Desperate:
First keep in mind
column7:
Boyfriend 5.0 is an entertainment
package
column8:
while Husband 1.0 is an operating system. Try to
enter the command: C:/I THOUGH! T YOU LOVED ME and download
Tears 6.2 to install Guilt 3.0.If all works as designed
column9:
Husband 1.0 should then automatically run the applications
Jewellery 2.0 and Flowers 3.5. But remember
column10:
overuse can
cause Husband 1.0 to default to Grumpy Silence 2.5
column11:
Happy
Hour 7.0
column12:
or Beer 6.1. Beer 6.1 is a very bad program that
will create Snoring Loudly. WAV files. Whatever you do
column13:
DO
NOT install Mother-in-law 1.0 or reinstall another
Boyfriend program.
These are not supported applications and will crash Husband
1.0.
In summary
column14: Husband 1.0 is a great program
column15:
but it does have a limited
memory and cannot learn new applications quickly. You might consider buying
additional software to improve memory and performance. I personally recommend
Hot Food 3.0 and Lingerie 7.7.

\n

Good Luck

column1:
[. . . life in America''s fifth largest city.

\n

1. You must learn to pronounce the city name. It is DAL-LUS
column2:
or DAA-LIS depending on if you live inside or outside LBJ Freeway.

\n

2.Forget the traffic rules you learned elsewhere. Dallas has its own version of traffic rules....Hold on and pray. There is no such thing as a dangerous high-speed chase in Dallas. We all drive like that.

\n

3.All directions start with
column3:
"Go down to Beltline"...which has no beginning and no end.

4.The Chamber of Commerce calls getting through traffic a "scenic drive."

5.The morning rush hour is from 6:00 to 10:00. The evening rush hour is from 3:00 to 7:00. Friday''s rush hour starts Thursday morning.

6.If you actually stop at a yellow light
column4: you will be rear ended
column5: cussed out and possibly shot. When you are the first one on the starting line
column6:
count to five when the light turns green before going to avoid getting into any cross-traffic''s way.

\n

7. Arapaho Road can only be pronounced by a native. The same holds true for Wycliff Avenue
column7: Worcola Street
column8: Sul Ross
column9:
Pokolodi and Routh Street.

\n

8.Construction on I-30 is a way of life and form of entertainment.

\n

9.All unexplained sights are explained by the phrase
column10: "Oh
column11:
we''re in Fort Worth!!"

\n

10.If someone actually has their turn signal on
column12:
it is probably a factory defect.

11.All old ladies with blue hair in Cadillacs have the right of way.

12. Story Road mysteriously changes names as you cross intersections. Unless you''re on Storey Rd......

13.If asking directions in Irving
column13:
you must have knowledge of Spanish.

\n

14.Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport has four terminal buildings connected by one tram that never works.

\n

column7: "Go
column8: Jesus Christ
column9: Go"! Everyone else started honking too
column10: so I leaned out my window and waved and smiled to all those loving people. There must have been a guy from Florida back there because I could hear him yelling something about a sunny beach

column14: so I leaned out the window and gave him the good luck sign back. A couple of the people were so caught up in the joy of the moment that they got out of their cars and were walking towards me. I bet they wanted to pray
column15: but just then I noticed that the light had changed

[The Week Before Christmas

\n

''Twas the week before Christmas and all through the school
Not a pupil was silent
column2:
no matter what rule.
The children were busy with paper and paste
The mess that they made with it couldn''t be faced.

\n

The teacher half frantic and almost in tears
column3: Had just settled down to work with her dears
column4:
When out in the hall there arose such a clatter
up sprang the kids to see what was the matter!

\n

Away to the door they all flew like a flash
The one who was leading went down with a crash.
Then what to their wondering eyes did appear
But a green Christmas tree! (To decorate I fear!)

\n

When the teacher saw this
column5:
she almost grew sick.
She knew in a moment it must be Old Nick!
She ran to the door (all her efforts were vain)
But she shouted
column6: and stamped
column7:
and she called them by name

\n

''''Now Tommy! Now Sandy
column8:
Now Judy and Harry!
Stop Billy! Stop Robert! Stop Donny and Sherry!
Now get to your places get away from the hall
Now get away! Get away! Get away all!

\n

As leaves that before the wild hurricane fly
The pupils
column9: pell mell
column10:
started scurrying by.
They ran to the blackboard and skipped down the aisle
Their faces were shining and each had a smile.

\n

First came a basket of popcorn to string
-Then came the Christmas tree (menacing thing).
As the tree was brought in there arose a great shout
The pupils were merrily romping about.

\n

The state they were in could lead to a riot
The teacher was sure
column11: if allowed
column12:
they would try it.
Her nerves how they jangled! Her temples were throbbing!
The rush of her breath sounded almost like sobbing!

\n

The lines of her face were as fixed as a mask
It was plain that she didn''t feel up to her task.
The look in her eye would have tamed a wild steer
column13:
But the children ignored it they did every year.

\n

A tear from her eye and a shake of her head
Soon led me to think that she wished she were dead.
She spoke not a word but went straight to her work
column14:
Strung all the popcorn which broke with a jerk.

\n

But at last it was finished and placed on the tree
Then came the bell and the children were free.
Their shrill little voices soon faded away
And peace was restored at the end of the day.
As she looked at the Christmas tree glistening and tall

column16: Merry Christmas to all!]

column1: [I. DOORS: Do not allow closed doors in any room. To get door opened
column2: stand on hind legs and hammer with forepaws. Once door is opened

column8: get to a chair quickly. If you cannot manage in time
column9: get to an Oriental rug. If there is no Oriental rug
column10: shag is good. When throwing up on the carpet
column11:
make sure you back up so that it is as long as the human''s bare foot.

\n

III. BATHROOMS: Always accompany guests to the bathroom. It is not necessary to do anything -- just sit and stare.

\n

IV. HAMPERING: If one of your humans is engaged in some close activity and the other is idle
column12: stay with the busy one. This is called "helping"
column13:
otherwise known as "hampering". Following are the rules for "hampering":
a) When supervising cooking
column14:
sit just behind the left heel of the cook. You cannot be seen and thereby stand a better chance of being stepped on and then picked up and comforted.
b) For book readers
column15: get in close under the chin
column16: between eyes and book
column17:
unless you can lie across the book itself.
c) For knitting projects or paperwork
column18: lie on the work in the most appropriate manner so as to obscure as much of the work or at least the most important part. Pretend to doze
column19: but every so often reach out and slap the pencil or knitting needles. The worker may try to distract you; ignore it. Remember
column20:
the aim is to hamper work. Embroidery and needlepoint projects make great hammocks in spite of what the humans may tell you.
d) For people paying bills (monthly activity) or working on income taxes or Christmas cards (annual activity)
column21: keep in mind the aim -- to hamper! First
column22: sit on the paper being worked on. When dislodged
column23: watch sadly from the side of the table. When activity proceeds nicely
column24: roll around on the papers
column25: scattering them to the best of your ability. After being removed for the second time
column26: push pens
column27: pencils
column28: and erasers off the table
column29:
one at a time.
e) When a human is holding the newspaper in front of him/her
column30:
be sure to jump on the back of the paper. They love to jump.

\n

V. WALKING: As often as possible
column31: dart quickly and as close as possible in front of the human
column32: especially: on stairs
column33: when they have something in their arms
column34: in the dark
column35:
and when they first get up in the morning. This will help their coordination skills.

\n

column1:
[Here''s Martha Stewart''s Etiquette Guide for Rednecks!

\n

1. Never take a beer to a job interview.
2. Always identify people in your yard before shooting at them.
3. It''s considered tacky to take a cooler to church.
4. If you have to vacuum the bed
column2:
it is time to change the sheets.
5. Even if you''re certain that you are included in the will
column3:
it is still considered tacky to drive a U-Haul to the funeral home.
***************************

\n

DINING OUT

\n

1. When decanting wine
column4: make sure that you tilt the paper cup
column5:
and pour slowly so as not to "bruise" the fruit of the vine.
2. If drinking directly from the bottle
column6:
always hold it with your fingers covering the label.
**********************

ENTERTAINING IN YOUR HOME

1. A centerpiece for the table should never be anything prepared by a taxidermist.
2. Do not allow the dog to eat at the table...no matter how good his manners are.
***********************

PERSONAL HYGIENE

1. While ears need to be cleaned regularly
column7:
this is a job that should be done in private using one''s OWN truck keys.
2. Proper use of toiletries can forestall bathing for several days. However
column8: if you live alone
column9:
deodorant is a waste of good money.
3. Dirt and grease under the fingernails is a social no-no
column10:
as they tend to detract from a woman''s jewelry and alter the taste of finger foods.
****************

\n

DATING (Outside the Family)

\n

1. Always offer to bait your date''s hook
column11:
especially on the first date.
2. Be aggressive. Let her know you''re interested: "I''ve been wanting to go out with you since I read that stuff on the bathroom wall two years ago."
3. Establish with her parents what time she is expected back.Some will say 10:00 PM; Others might say "Monday." If the latter is the answer
column12:
it is the man''s responsibility to get her to school on time.
**********************

THEATER ETIQUETTE

1. Crying babies should be taken to the lobby and picked up immediately after the movie has ended.
2. Refrain from talking to characters on the screen. Tests have proven they can''t hear you.
***********************

WEDDINGS

1. Livestock
column13: usually
column14:
is a poor choice for a wedding gift.
2. Kissing the bride for more than 5 seconds may get you shot.
3. For the groom
column15: at least
column16:
rent a tux. A leisure suit with a cummerbund and a clean bowling shirt can create a tacky appearance.
4. Though uncomfortable
column17:
say "yes" to socks and shoes for this special occasion.
*******************

\n

DRIVING ETIQUETTE

\n

1. Dim your headlights for approaching vehicles; Even if the gun is loaded
column18:
and the deer is in sight.
2. When approaching a four-way stop
column19:
the vehicle with the largest tires always has the right of way.
3. Never tow another car using panty hose and duct tape.
4. When sending your wife down the road with a gas can
column20:
it is impolite to ask her to bring back beer.
5. Do not lay rubber while traveling in a funeral procession.]

the man said with some obvious pride. I work for the Minnesota Twins baseball team."

\n

The nurse returned in a little while and turned to the second man
column6: "You sir
column7:
are the father of triplets."

\n

"Wow
column8:
That''s really an incredible coincidence " he answered. "I work for the 3M Corporation. My buddies at work will never let me live this one down!"

\n

An hour later
column9: while the other two men were passing cigars around
column10: the nurse came back
column11:
this time she turn to the third man -- who had been quiet in the corner. She announced that his wife had just given birth to quadruplets.

\n

Stunned
column12: he barely could reply. "Don''t tell me! Another coincidence?" asked the nurse. After finally regaining his composure
column13: he said "I don''t believe it
column14:
I work for the Four Seasons Hotel!"

\n

After hearing this
column15: everybody''s attention turned to the fourth guy
column16: who had just fainted
column17:
flat out on the floor.

\n

The nurse rushed to his side and after some time
column18: he slowly regained consciousness. When he was finally able to speak
column19:
you could hear him repeatedly muttering the same phrase over and over again:

\n

"I should have never taken the job at Millennium Computers... "I should have never taken the job at Millennium Computers... "I should have never taken the job at Millennium Computers...!!!"]

column1: [When you''re 47 years old
column2: you sometimes hear a small voice inside you that says: "Just because you''ve reached middle age
column3: that doesn''t mean you shouldn''t take on new challenges and seek new adventures. You get only one ride on this crazy carousel we call life
column4:
and by golly you should make the most of it."

\n

This is the voice of Satan.

\n

I know this because recently
column5: on a mountain in Idaho
column6: I listened to this voice
column7:
and as a result my body feels as though it has been used as a trampoline by the Budweiser Clydesdales.

I am currently on an all-painkiller diet. "I''ll have a black coffee and 250 Advil tablets" is a typical breakfast order for me these days.

This is because I went snowboarding.

For those of you who
column8: for whatever reason
column9: such as a will to live
column10: do not participate in downhill winter sports
column11:
I should explain that snowboarding is an activity that is popular with people who do not feel that regular skiing is lethal enough.

\n

These are of course young people
column12: fearless people
column13: people with 100 percent synthetic bodies who can hurtle down a mountainside at 50 miles per hour and knock down mature trees with their faces and then spring to their feet and go
column14:
"Cool."

\n

People like my son. He wanted to try snowboarding
column15: and I thought it would be good to learn with him
column16:
because we can no longer ski together.

\n

We have a fundamental difference in technique: He skis via the Downhill Method
column17: in which you ski down the hill; whereas I ski via the Breath-Catching Method
column18: in which you stand sideways on the hill
column19:
looking as athletic as possible without actually moving muscles (this could cause you to start sliding down the hill).

\n

If anybody asks if you''re OK
column20: you say
column21: "I''m just catching my breath!" in a tone of voice that suggests that at any moment you''re going to swoop rapidly down the slope; whereas in fact you''re planning to stay right where you are
column22: rigid as a statue
column23:
until the spring thaw.

\n

At night
column24: when the Downhillers have all gone home
column25: we Breath-Catchers will still be up there
column26: clinging to the mountainside
column27:
chewing on our parkas for sustenance.

\n

So I thought I''d take a stab at snowboarding
column28:
which is quite different from skiing.

\n

In skiing
column29: you wear a total of two skis
column30: or approximately one per foot
column31: so you can sort of maintain your balance by moving your feet
column32:
plus you have poles that you can stab people with if they make fun of you at close range.

\n

Whereas with snowboarding
column33: all you get is one board
column34: which is shaped like a giant tongue depressor and manufactured by the Institute of Extremely Slippery Things. Both of your feet are strapped firmly to this board
column35: so that if you start to fall
column36:
you can''t stick a foot out and catch yourself. You crash to the ground like a tree and lie there while skiers swoop past and deliberately spray snow on you.

\n

Skiers hate snowboarders. It''s a generational thing. Skiers are (and here I am generalizing) middle-aged Republicans wearing designer space suits; snowboarders are defiant young rebels wearing deliberately drab clothing that is baggy enough to cover the snowboarder plus a major appliance. Skiers like to glide down the slopes in a series of graceful arcs; snowboarders like to attack the mountain
column37: slashing
column38: spinning
column39: tumbling
column40: going backward
column41: blasting through snowdrifts
column42: leaping off cliffs
column43: getting their noses pierced in midair
column44:
etc.

\n

Skiers view snowboarders as a menace; snowboarders view skiers as Elmer Fudd.

\n

I took my snowboarding lesson in a small group led by a friend of mine named Brad Pearson
column45:
who also once talked me into jumping from a tall tree while attached only to a thin rope.

\n

Brad took us up on a slope that offered ideal snow conditions for the novice who''s going to fall a lot: Approximately seven flakes of powder on top of an 18-foot-thick base of reinforced concrete.

\n

You could not dent this snow with a jackhammer. (I later learned
column46: however
column47:
that you COULD dent it with the back of your head.)

We learned snowboarding via a two step method:

STEP ONE: Watching Brad do something.

STEP TWO: Trying to do it ourselves.

I was pretty good at Step One. The problem with Step Two was that you had to stand up on your snowboard
column48:
which turns out to be a violation of at least five important laws of physics.

\n

I''d struggle to my feet
column49: and I''d be wavering there and then the Physics Police would drop a huge chunk of gravity on me
column50: and WHAM my body would hit the concrete snow
column51:
sometimes bouncing as much as a foot.

\n

"Keep your knees bent!" Brad would yell
column52:
helpfully.

\n

Have you noticed that whatever sport you''re trying to learn
column53: some earnest person is always telling you to keep your knees bent? As if THAT would solve anything. I wanted to shout back
column54:
"FORGET MY KNEES! DO SOMETHING ABOUT THESE GRAVITY CHUNKS!"

\n

Needless to say my son had no trouble at all. None. In minutes he was cruising happily down the mountain; you could actually see his clothing getting baggier. I
column55: on the other hand
column56: spent most of my time lying on my back
column58:
while space-suited Republicans swooped past and sprayed snow on me.

\n

If I hadn''t gotten out of there
column59:
they''d have completely covered me; I now realize that the small hills you see on ski slopes are formed around the bodies of 47-year-olds who tried to learn snowboarding.

\n

So I think
column61: I''ll go back to skiing. Maybe sometime you''ll see me out on the slopes
column62: catching my breath. Please throw me some food.]

SA.

The earthquake decimated the area causing approximately $30 worth of damage.

Several priceless collections of mementos from the Torana Appreciation Society and the Port Adelaide Progress Hall were damaged beyond repair.

Three areas of historic burnt out cars were disturbed.

Many locals were woken well before their welfare cheques arrived. one resident - Tracy Sharon Smith

my little Chardonnay Mercedes came running into my bedroom crying.

PLEASE do not send tents for shelter

column3: he had decided to call it a day - when an armless man approached him and announced that he was there to apply for the bell ringer''s job.The bishop was incredulous.  "You have no arms!""No matter

column12: "Bishop

Noon -  Fire gun for help - eat wild berries. 12:15 pm - Ran out of bullets - eight deer come back. 12:20 pm - Strange feeling in stomach. 12:30 pm - Realize you ate poison berries. 12:45 pm - Rescued. 12:55 pm - Rushed to hospital to have stomach pumped. 3:00 pm - Arrived back in camp. 3:30 pm - leave camp to kill deer. 4:00 pm - Return to camp for bullets. 4:01 pm - Load gun - leave camp again. 5:00 pm - Empty gun on squirrel that''s bugging you. 6:00 pm - Arrive at camp - see deer grazing in camp. 6:01 pm - Load gun. 6:02 pm - Fire gun. 6:03 pm - One dead pickup truck. 6:05 pm - Hunting partner returns to camp dragging deer. 6:06 pm - Repress strong desire to shoot partner. 6:07 pm - Fall into fire. 6:10 pm - Change clothes - throw burned ones into fire. 6:15 pm - Take pickup - leave partner and his deer in the woods. 6:25 pm - Pickup boils over - hole shot in block. 6:26 pm - Start walking. 6:30 pm - Stumble and fall - drop gun in the mud. 6:35 pm - Meet bear. 6:36 pm - Take aim. 6:37 pm - Fire gun - blow up barrel plugged with mud. 6:38 pm - Make mess in pants. 6:39 pm - Climb tree. 9:00 pm - Bear departs - wrap %&*$#@ gun around tree. Midnight - Home at last. Next day - Watch football games on TV

column1: [Forwarded from a guy at MIT who knows this guy at WPI. Story confirmed by a co-employee who graduated from MIT. Unfortunately we don''t have an e-dress for Mikey to  REALLY confirm this
column2: but then
column3: who would make THIS up?   ;-)                       -------------------------And so I get back to school
column4: start my senior year
column5: two research projects
column6: grad school applications
column7: GRE preparation
column8: and the like. The year started off good
column9: but that all changed about two months ago. Some of you (especially those at Berkeley) may have heard rumors of some bizarre accident that I was involved in. So here is the truth
column10: unabridged
column11: for those of you who actually want to know...Around the second week of school
column12: the society of physics students held a roughly annual welcome back party
column13: and
column14: as tradition dictates
column15: we made our own ice cream with liquid nitrogen (77 K) as a refrigerant and aerator.Things were going fine for a while. We spilled a little of the nitrogen onto a table
column16: and watched tiny little drops of it dance around. Then someone asked
column17: ''why does it do that?''That may have been the point of no return. I
column18: as is traditionally my role
column19: answered that the nitrogen evaporates at the surface of the table
column20: which provides a cushion of air for the drop to sit on
column21: and thermally insulates the drop to minimize further evaporation. So you see a drop dance around without boiling away
column22: and without interacting with the table and getting slowed down or smeared out. Then
column23: I continued...I mentioned that the same principle makes it possible to dip a wet hand into molten lead
column24: or to drink liquid nitrogen without injury.I had done the latter several years earlier in a cryogenics lab
column25: and remembered the physics behind how it worked. Naturally
column26: people around me were skeptical. ''You can''t drink the stuff... it''ll freeze your whole body... remember terminator 2?'' but I was sure of myself. I had done it before
column27: and I believed in the physics behind it. So
column28: naturally
column29: I poured myself a glass and took a shot. Simple: Swallow
column30: blow smoke out nose and mouth and impress everyone at the party.Within about two seconds
column31: I had collapsed to the floor
column32: unable to breathe or feel anything other than intense pain.Ambulance arrives. Police arrive. Trip to hospital. Admission. Try to explain to ER staff exactly how something like this happens. Then I pass out.I wake up next morning connected to many machines
column33: some beeping
column34: others performing more important functions like digesting my food and breathing for me.Turns out that
column35: in accordance with popular belief
column36: you really should not drink the stuff. I eventually learned a few things about liquid nitrogen. Like... while you can safely put it in your mouth
column37: and blow neat smoke patterns
column38: you should never ever ever swallow. First off
column39: the closing of the epiglottis prevents the nitrogen gas from escaping
column40: so it is forced into your body instead. Second
column41: your esophagus naturally constricts around anything inside it
column42: so
column43: even if there is a thin protective gas layer
column44: the esophagus will find a way to make contact with the liquid nitrogen.Also turns out that my memory was flawed. When I had done it six years ago
column45: I put it into my mouth and didn''t swallow. Over time
column46: that fineline between parlor trick and near fatal accident must have blurred.So... the consequences... my entire upper GI tract
column47: from epiglottis to the bottom of the stomach was badly burned
column48: scarred
column49: and perforated. The gas also expanded quite a bit while inside my body. It filled my chest cavity with several liters of nitrogen gas
column50: which was under enough presuure to collapse a lung. So after what I''m told was a grueling all night surgery
column51: they removed part of my stomach
column52: and had my entire digestive system
column54: running on machine power for a while. I also had a breather for the first day or so
column55: until my lung was restored. There are a few details which are considerably uglier which I will spare you.So... the recovery... they were impressed with my recuperative skills. I could breathe on my own completely after a few days. I could sit up in bed after a week
column56: and was walking in two. About that time
column57: I began to eat again as well. After four weeks
column58: I was up and about again. Now
column61: with the exception of a number of unsightly scars.But.... the good news is that I am the first documented medical case of a cryogenic ingestion. Read the new england journal of medicine. Three articles are in review now
column64: my little adventure leaves me with bad jokes at physics department meetings
column65: and the occasional blurb in the school paper. ''Make Mikey drink it. Mikey likes it.'' I''ve also picked up the nickname''Nitro-Mike
column66: '' which is somehow supposed to sound cool
column67: because it conjures up images of nitro-glycerin
column68: which implies I''m a bad mother. I don''t buy it.If any of you guys have heard a variation on this story
column69: let me know. I''m always curious to hear how these things sound third and fourth hand. I was on a follow-up visit to the hospital
column70: and I mentioned to one of the nurses that I go to WPI. And he said that he heard about some kid from WPI who broke into a lab in the middle of the night and stole some liquid nitrogen to try and get high. Then
column72: by the time he gets to the hospital
column73: he''s in pretty bad shape. His lower jaw has to be amputated
column74: as well as his tongue. He can never eat solid foods again
column76: '' if you know what I mean. I didn''t have the heart to tell this guy the truth
column77: because the story was so good at that point.So
column80: is what''s happened to me. Nowadays
column81: I''m back to my normal self... school
column86: and suffering over women.So here I am.Michael]

column5:

\n

The bartender comes over to him
column6: sniffs
column7: and says that he smells kind of nerdy. He then asks him what he does for a living. The truck driver explains to him that he drives a truck
column8: and the smell is just from the computers he is hauling. The bartender serves him a beer and says
column9: "OK
column10:
truck drivers aren''t nerds."

\n

As he is sipping his beer
column11: a skinny guy walks in wearing a pair of glasses with tape around the middle
column12: a pocket protector with twelve kinds of pens and pencils
column13: and a belt that is at least a foot too long. The bartender
column14: without saying a word
column15:
pulls out a shotgun and blows the guy away. The truck driver asks him why he did that.

\n

The bartender replied
column16:
"Don''t worry. The computer nerds are in season because they are overpopulating Silicon Valley. You don''t even need a license."

\n

So the truck driver finishes his beer
column17: gets back in his truck
column18: and heads for the freeway. Suddenly
column19: he veers to avoid an accident
column20:
and the load shifts. The back door breaks open and computers spill out all over the road.

He jumps out and sees a crowd already forming
column21: snatching up all of the computers. The scavengers are comprised of engineers
column22:
accountants and programmers - computer geeks. Each of them wearing the nerdiest clothes he has ever seen.

\n

He can''t let them steal his whole load. So remembering what happened in the bar
column23: he pulls out his gun and starts blasting away
column24:
killing several of them instantly.

\n

A highway patrol officer comes zooming up and jumps out of the car screaming at him to stop.

\n

The truck driver said
column25:
"What''s wrong? I thought computer nerds were in season."

\n

"Well

SOCIOLOGY: Each claims to have been oppressed in the relationship.

RELIGION: Each prays for reconciliation and/or curses G-d

ARCHAEOLOGY: One tries to bury the past
column2:
and accuses the other of trying to dig it up.

called an end to their relationship of 2 weeks..."

\n

BUSINESS: Both decide that they''re spending way too much money together

and that it''s simply cheaper to be single.

GEOGRAPHY: Both people decide to simply move far away to avoid each other.

ANATOMY: "I never liked your body anyway."

ECONOMICS: One party demands more than the other can supply.

that doesn''t really say anything substantively intelligible.

[Twas the night before Christmas
And all through the house
There were empties and butts
Left around by some louse.
And the best quart I''d hid
By the chimney with care
Had been swiped by some creep
Who''d discovered it there!

\n

Our hung-over guests
Had been poured into bed
(They''ll wake in the morn
With a God-awful head)
My tongue
column2: cotton-coated
column3:
Hung down to my belt
And only the seasick
Could know how I felt!

\n

My wife - she had long ago
Gone up to bed
While visions of Redskins
Danced in her head.
And I in the parlor
Sat all alone
column4:
I''d unplugged the cat
And put out the phone.

\n

Just then
column5:
through a window
Came noise and smells
Like an overturned beer truck
And tinkle of bells!
I sprang from my chair
To see what was the matter
To see what was causing
The smell and the clatter.

\n

When what to my wondering
Eyes did appear
But eight drunken reindeer
And sled full of beer!
With a little old driver
column6: Nose red as a brick
column7:
I knew it was Santa
As tight as a tick!

\n

Weaving upward and downward
His reindeer they came
While he hiccoughed and burped
And called them by name:
"On Gallo! On Ripple!
We ain''t got all night!
You
column8: too
column9:
Manischevitz!
And you
column10:
Miller lite!

\n

"Ho Bud! Easy
column11:
Boh!
Give Busch there a hand!
Now now
column12:
Lowenbrau -
You can go when we land!
Head up for that roof --
Watch out for the wall!
Get going
column13:
you guys
We''ve got a long haul!"

\n

So up to my roof
Went his reindeer and sled
But my TV antenna
Hit him right in the head!
And then in a twinkling
I heard Santa swear
So hot that it melted
The snow everywhere!

\n

I could tell in a moment
This guy had no class
For he fell down my chimney
Right smack on his sack!
He was dresed all in fur
From his head to his toes.
Red were his eyeballs
column14:
His coat and his nose.

\n

He had a round face
And toy-filled sack
His breath would have blown
A freight off the track!
He was chubby and plump
And he tried to stand right
But he couldn''t fool me -
He was high as a kite!

\n

He spoke not a word
But went straight to his work
And missed half the stockings
column15:
The plastered old jerk!
Then putting five fingers
To the end of his nose
He gave me the word
As up the chimney he rose.

\n

Crossing my rooftop
He went at a run
Not seeing what one
Of his reindeer had done.
He skidded
column16:
and then
Fell flat on his face!
His remarks after this
Were a total disgrace!

\n

Then he got in his sled
And I heard Santa moan:
"Why did I stop there?
Bux''s kids are all grown!"]

column2: for a folklore project

..you have ever discussed academic matters at a sporting event.

..you have ever spent more than $50 on photocopies while researching a single paper.

..there is a microfiche reader in the library that you consider "yours."

..you actually have a preference between microfilm and microfiche.

..you can tell the time of day by looking at the traffic flow at the library.

..you look forward to summers because you''re more productive without the distraction of classes.

..you regard ibuprofen as a vitamin.

..you consider all papers to be works in progress.

..your professors don''t really care when you turn in your work anymore.

..you find the bibliographies of books more interesting than the actual text.

..you have given up trying to keep your books organized and are now just trying to keep them all in the same general area.

..you have accepted guilt as an inherent feature of relaxation.

..you reflexively start analyzing those Greeks letters before you realize that it''s just a sorority sweatshirt and not an equation.

..you find yourself explaining to young children that you are in the "20th" grade.

..you start referring to stories like "Snow White
column4:
et. al."

..you frequently wonder how long you can live on pasta without getting scurvy.

..you look forward to taking some time off to do laundry.

..you have more photocopy cards than credit cards.

..you yonder if APA style allows you to cite talking to yourself as "personal communication."]

column1:
[Dear Tech Support:

I am desperate for some help. I recently upgraded from Girlfriend 7.0 to Wife 1.0 and found that the new program began unexpected child processing and also took up a lot of space and valuable resources. This wasn''t mentioned in the product brochure.

In addition Wife 1.0 installs itself into all other programs and launches during system initialisation where it monitors all other system activity.

Applications such as Boys Night Out 2.5
column2:
and Golf 5.3 no longer run and crash the system whenever selected. Attempting to operate Sunday Football 6.3 always fails but Saturday Shopping 7.1 runs instead. I cannot seem to keep Wife 1.0 in the background whilst attempting to run any of my favourite applications. I am thinking about going back to Girlfriend 7.0 but de-install doesn''t work on this program.

\n

Can you please help!
Joe.

\n

Dear Joe
column3:
This is a very common problem resulting from a basic misunderstanding.

Many men upgrade from Girlfriend 7.0 to Wife 1.0 thinking that Wife 1.0 is merely a UTILITIES & ENTERTAINMENT program. Whereas Wife 1.0 is an OPERATING SYSTEM designed by its creator to run everything.

You are unlikely to be able to purge Wife 1.0 and still convert back to Girlfriend 7.0 as Wife 1.0 is not designed to do this and it is impossible to de-install
column4:
delete or purge the program files from the system once installed.

\n

Some people have tried to install Girlfriend 8.0 or Wife 2.0
column5:
but have
ended up with even more problems. (See in manual under Alimony/Child Support and Solicitors Fees). Having Wife 1.0 installed myself I recommend you keep it installed and deal with the difficulties as best you can.

\n

When any faults or problems occur
column6: whatever you think has caused them
column7: you must run the C: IAPOLOGISE program and avoid attempting to use the *Esc-key. It may be necessary to run C: I APOLOGISE a number of times
column8:
but hopefully eventually the operating system will return to normal.

Wife 1.0 although a very high maintenance program can be very rewarding. To get the most out of it consider buying additional software such as Flowers 2.0 and Chocolates 5.0.

Do not under any circumstances install Secretary (Short Skirt version) as this is not a supported application for Wife 1.0 and the system will almost certainly crash.

Best of luck!
Tech Support]

column1: [It was a boring Sunday afternoon in the jungle
column2:
so the Elephants decided to
challenge the Ants to a game of soccer. The game was going well with the
Elephants beating the Ants ten goals to nil
column3:
when the Ants gained possession.

\n

The Ants'' star player was dribbling the ball towards the Elephants'' goal when
the Elephants'' left back came lumbering towards him. The elephant trod on the
little ant
column4:
killing him instantly.

\n

The referee stopped the game. "What the hell do you think you''re doing? Do you
call that sportsmanship
column5:
killing another player?"

\n

The elephant replied
column6: "Well
column7:
I didn''t mean to kill him - I was just trying to
trip him up."]

[Take the following test to see how qualified you are to be a
professional.

1. How do you put a giraffe into a refrigerator?

Open the door put the giraffe in and close the door. This tests
whether you are doing simple things in a complicated way.

2. How do you put an elephant into a refrigerator?

Open the door take the giraffe out and put the elephant in then
close the door. This tests your memory.

3. The lion king is holding an animal conference. All the
animals attend except one
column2:
which one?

\n

The elephant
column3:
he is in the refrigerator! This tests your
thinking ability.

\n

4. There is a river known for its man-eating crocodiles. How do
you cross it?

\n

You swim
column4:
all the animals are at the conference. This tests all
three.

\n

If you answered all four correctly you would be perfect for a
profession. If you answered one correctly you should go into
marketing. If you answered none correctly you should play for
Man United.]

column1: [I took some clients out to dinner last week
column2: and I noticed a spoon in the shirt pocket of our waiter as he handed us the menus. It seemed a little odd
column3: but I dismissed it as a random thing. Until our busboy came with water and tableware; he too
column4: sported a spoon in his breast pocket. I looked around the room
column5: and all the waiters and busboys had spoons in their pockets. When our waiter returned to take our order
column6: I just had to ask
column7: "Why the spoons?""Well
column8: he explained, our parent company recently hired some Andersen Consulting efficiency experts to review all our procedures
column9: and after months of statistical analyses
column10: they concluded that our patrons drop spoons on the floor 73% more often than any other utensil
column11: at a frequency of 3 spoons per hour per workstation. By preparing our workers for this contingency in advance
column12: we can cut our trips to the kitchen down and save time... nearly 1.5 extra man-hours per shift." Just as he concluded
column13: a "ch-ching" came from the table behind him
column14: and he quickly replaced the fallen spoon with the one from his pocket."I''ll grab another spoon the next time I''m in the kitchen instead of making a special trip
column15: he proudly explained.I was impressed. Thanks
column16: I had to ask.""No problem
column17: he answered. Then he continued to take our orders. As the members of our dinner party took their turns, my eyes darted back and forth from each person ordering and my menu. That''s when, out of the corner of my eye, I spotted a thin black thread protruding from our waiter''s fly. Again, I dismissed it; yet I had to scan the room and, sure enough, there were other waiters and busboys with strings hanging out of their trousers. My curiosity overrode discretion at this point, so before he could leave I had to ask. Excuse me
column18: but...uh...why
column19: or what about that string?""Oh
column20: yeah
column21: he began, in a quieter tone, not many people are that observant. That same efficiency group found we could save time in the Men''s Room
column22: too.""How''s that?" I asked."You see
column23: by tying a string to the end of our
column24: uh
column25: selves
column26: we can pull it out at the urinals literally hands-free and thereby eliminate the need to wash our hands
column27: cutting time spent in the washroom by over 93%!""Hey
column28: wait a minute. If the string helps you pull it out
column29: how do you get it back in?""Well
column30: he whispered, I don''t know about the other guys
column31: but I use the spoon."]

the seven dwarfs that she was going to bed. After the usual
lengthy round of "Good Nights" she went upstairs. Immediately
all seven dwarfs rushed outside and began standing on each
other''s shoulders beneath Snow White''s bedroom window. Tonight
was Grumpy''s turn to be on the top and as he was the only one
who could see in the window. It was his duty to inform the other
dwarfs what she was doing.

\n

After a minute or two he hollered down
column2:

blouse!" and this as echoed down the stack "taking off her
blouse

column4: blouse is coming off
column5: taking off her blouse
column6:

column8:
she''s taking off
her skirt
column9: skirt''s coming off
column10: taking off her skirt
column11:
etc.

\n

Of course the next line from Grumpy was, She''s taking off her
bra!" and the echo chorus went down the line.

\n

Then
column12:
"She''s taking off her panties!" which again cascaded down

someone coming through the woods so he yelled

"Someone''s

column1:
[The opening credits of The Simpsons(tm) shows Bart Simpson writing the same sentence over and over again on the chalkboard. Here are the collected writings of Bart Simpson from the opening credits.

\n

I will not carve gods.
I will not spank others.
I will not aim for the head.
I will not barf unless I''m sick.
I saw nothing unusual in the teacher''s lounge.
I will not conduct my own fire drills.
Funny noises are not funny.
I will not snap bras.
I will not fake seizures.
This punishment is not boring and pointless.
My name is not Dr. Death.
I will not prescribe medication.
I will not bury the new kid.
I will not teach others to fly.
I will not bring sheep to class.
A burp is not an answer.
Teacher is not a leper.
I will not eat things for money.
I will not yell "She''s Dead" at roll call.
The principal''s toupee is not a Frisbee.
I will not call the principal "spud head".
Goldfish don''t bounce.
Mud is not one of the 4 food groups.
No one is interested in my underpants.
I will not sell miracle cures.
I will return the seeing-eye dog.
I do not have diplomatic immunity.
I will not charge admission to the bathroom.
The cafeteria deep fryer is not a toy.
My homework was not stolen by a one-armed man.
I will not go near the kindergarten turtle.
Organ transplants are best left to professionals.
Five days is not too long to wait for a gun.
I will not skateboard in the halls.
Underwear should be worn on the inside.
The Christmas Pageant does not stink.
I am not authorized to fire substitute teachers.]

[It''s your first time. As you lie back your muscles tighten. You put him
off for awhile searching for an excuse
column2:
but he refuses to be swayed as
he
approaches you. He asks if you''re afraid and you shake your head
bravely.
He has more experience
column3:
but it is the first time his finger has found
the
right place. He probes deeply and you shiver: your body tenses
column4:
but
he''s
gentle like he promised he''d be! He looks deeply into your eyes and
tells you to trust him ---- he''s done this many times before. His cool
smile relaxes you and you open wider to give him more room for any easy
entrance. You begin to plead and beg him to hurry
column5:
but he goes very
slowly
column6:
wanting to cause you as little pain as possible. As he presses
closer
column7: going deeper
column8:
you feel the tissue give way; pain surges through-
out your body and you feel the slight trickle of blood as he continues.
He looks concerned and asks you if it''s too painful.... Your eyes are
filled with tears but you shake your head and nod for him to go on. He
begins moving in and out with skill but you are now to numb to feel him
within you. After a few frenzied moments
column9:
you feel something bursting
within you and he pulls it out of you. You lay panting
column10:
glad to have it
over. He looks at you and smiling warmly
column11: tells you
column12: with a chuckle
column13:
that
and thank your dentist. After all
column14:
it was your first time to have a
tooth
pulled!]

column1:
[You might be a redneck if...

You refer to the time you won a free case of oil as the "day my ship came in."

Your hairdo has ever been ruined by a ceiling fan.

Your mother has been involved in a fist fight at a high school sports event.

You''ve ever barbecued Spam on the grill.

You own all the components of soap on a rope except the soap.

The best way to keep things cold is to leave''em in the shade.

You''ve ever raked leaves in your kitchen.

[1. Never take a beer to a job interview.

2. Always identify people in your yard before shooting at them.

3. It''s considered tacky to take a cooler to church.

4. If you have to vacuum the bed
column2:
it is time to change the sheets.

\n

5. Even if you''re certain that you are included in the will
column3:
it is still considered tacky to drive a U-Haul to the funeral home.

\n

DINING OUT

\n

1. When decanting wine
column4: make sure that you tilt the paper cup
column5:
and pour slowly so as not to "bruise" the fruit of the vine.

\n

2. If drinking directly from the bottle
column6:
always hold it with your fingers covering the label.

ENTERTAINING IN YOUR HOME

1. A centerpiece for the table should never be anything prepared by a taxidermist.

2. Do not allow the dog to eat from the table...no matter how good his manners are.

PERSONAL HYGIENE

1. While ears need to be cleaned regularly
column7:
this is a job that should be done in private using one''s OWN truck keys.

\n

2. Proper use of toiletries can forestall bathing for several days. However
column8: if you live alone
column9:
deodorant is a waste of good money.

\n

3. Dirt and grease under the fingernails is a social no-no
column10:
as they tend to detract from a woman''s jewelry and alter the taste of finger foods.

\n

DATING (Outside the Family)

\n

1. Always offer to bait your date''s hook
column11:
especially on the first date.

\n

2. Be aggressive. Let her know you''re interested: "I''ve been wanting to go out with you since I read that stuff on the bathroom wall two years ago."

\n

3. Establish with her parents what time she is expected back. Some will say 10:00 PM; others might say "Monday." If the latter is the answer
column12:
it is the man''s responsibility to get her to school on time.

THEATER ETIQUETTE

1. Crying babies should be taken to the lobby and picked up immediately after the movie has ended.

2. Refrain from talking to characters on the screen. Tests have proven they can''t hear you.

WEDDINGS

1. Livestock is usually a poor choice for a wedding gift.

2. Kissing the bride for more than 5 seconds may get you shot.

3. For the groom
column13: at least
column14:
rent a tux. A leisure suit with a cummerbund and clean bowling shirt can create a tacky appearance.

\n

4. Though uncomfortable
column15:
say "yes" to socks and shoes for this special occasion.

DRIVING ETIQUETTE

1. Dim your headlights for approaching vehicles; even if the gun is loaded and the deer is in sight.

2. When approaching a four-way stop
column16:
the vehicle with the largest tires always has the right of way.

\n

3. Never tow another car using panty hose and duct tape.

\n

4. When sending your wife down the road with a gas can
column17:
it is impolite to ask her to bring back beer too.

\n

5. Do not lay rubber while traveling in a funeral procession.

\n

Submitted by Glaci
Edited by Curtis]
