column1:
[The 5 toughest questions women ask - and their answers

\n

The five questions are:
1 - "What are you thinking?"
2 - "Do you love me?"
3 - "Do I look fat?"
4 - "Do you think she is prettier than me?"
5 - "What would you do if I died?"

\n

What makes these questions so bad is that every one is
guaranteed to explode into a major argument and/or divorce if
the man does not answer properly
column2:
which is to say dishonestly.
For example:

\n

1 - "What are you thinking?" The proper answer to this question
column3: of course
column4: is
column5: "I''m sorry if I''ve been pensive
column6:
dear. I was just
reflecting on what a warm
column7: wonderful
column8: caring
column9: thoughtful
column10: intelligent
column11:
beautiful woman you are and what a lucky guy I am
to have met you."
Obviously
column12:
this statement bears no resemblance whatsoever to what
the guy was really thinking at the time
column13:
which was most likely
one of five things:
a - Baseball
b - Football
c - How fat you are.
d - How much prettier she is than you.
e - How he would spend the insurance money if you died.

\n

According to the Sassy article
column14:
the best answer to this stupid
question came from Al Bundy
column15: of Married With Children
column16:
who was
asked it by his wife
column17: Peg. "If I wanted you to know
column18:
Al said,
I''d be talking instead of thinking."

\n

The other questions also have only one right answer but many
wrong answers:

\n

2 - "Do you love me?" The correct answer to this question is
column19: "Yes." For those guys who feel the need to be more elaborate
column20:
you
may answer
column21: "Yes
column22:
dear. Wrong answers include:
a - I suppose so.
b - Would it make you feel better if I said yes.
c - That depends on what you mean by "love".
d - Does it matter?
e - Who
column23:
me?

\n

3 - "Do I look fat?" The correct male response to this question
is to confidently and emphatically state
column24: "No
column25:
of course not" and
then quickly leave the room. Wrong answers include:
a - I wouldn''t call you fat
column26:
but I wouldn''t call you thin either.
b - Compared to what?
c - A little extra weight looks good on you.
d - I''ve seen fatter.
e - Could you repeat the question? I was thinking about your
insurance policy.

\n

4 - "Do you think she''s prettier than me?" The "she" in the
question could be an ex-girlfriend
column27:
a passer-by you were
starring at so hard thay you almost cause a traffic accident or
an actress in a movie you just saw. In any case
column28:
the correct
response is
column29: "No
column30:
you are much prettier." Wrong answers include:
a - Not prettier
column31:
just pretty in a different way.
b - I don''t know how one goes about rating such things.
c - Yes
column32:
but I bet you have a better personality.
d - Only in the sense that she''s younger and thinner.
e - Could you repeat the question? I was thinking about your
insurance policy.

\n

5 - "What would you do if I died?" Correct answer: "Dearest love
column33: in the event of your untimely demise
column34:
life would cease to have
meaning for me and I would perforce hurl myself under the front
tires of the first Domino''s Pizza truck that came my way." This
might be the stupidest question of the lot

"Why

dear" he said.

[Bart Simpson''s Chalkboard Archive

\n

I will not carve gods.
I will not spank others.
I will not aim for the head.
I will not barf unless I''m sick.
I will not expose the ignorance of the faculty.
I saw nothing unusual in the teacher''s lounge.
I will not conduct my own fire drills.
Funny noises are not funny.
I will not snap bras.
I will not fake seizures.
This punishment is not boring and pointless.
My name is not Dr. Death.
I will not defame New Orleans.
I will not prescribe medication.
I will not bury the new kid.
I will not teach others to fly.
I will not bring sheep to class.
A burp is not an answer.
Teacher is not a leper.
Coffee is not for kids.
I will not eat things for money.
I will not yell "She''s Dead" at roll call.
The principal''s toupee is not a Frisbee.
I will not call the principal "spud head".
Goldfish don''t bounce.
Mud is not one of the 4 food groups.
No one is interested in my underpants.
I will not sell miracle cures.
I will return the seeing-eye dog.
I do not have diplomatic immunity.
I will not charge admission to the bathroom.
I will never win an emmy.
The cafeteria deep fryer is not a toy.
All work and no play makes Bart a dull boy.
I will not say "Springfield" just to get applause.
I am not authorized to fire substitute teachers.
My homework was not stolen by a one-armed man.
I will not go near the kindergarten turtle.
I am not deliciously saucy.
Organ transplants are best left to professionals.
The Pledge of Allegiance does not end with "Hail Satan".
I will not celebrate meaningless milestones.
There are plenty of businesses like show business.
Five days is not too long to wait for a gun.
I will not waste chalk.
I will not skateboard in the halls.
I will not instigate revolution.
I will not draw naked ladies in class.
I did not see Elvis.
I will not call my teacher "Hot Cakes".
Garlic gum is not funny.
They are laughing at me
column2:
not with me.
I will not yell "Fire" in a crowded classroom.
I will not encourage others to fly.
I will not fake my way through life.
Tar is not a plaything.
I will not Xerox my butt.
It''s potato
column3:
not potatoe.
I will not trade pants with others.
I am not a 32 year old woman.
I will not do that thing with my tongue.
I will not drive the principal''s car.
I will not pledge allegiance to Bart.
I will not sell school property.
I will not burp in class.
I will not cut corners.
I will not get very far with this attitude.
I will not belch the National Anthem.
I will not sell land in Florida.
I will not grease the monkey bars.
I will not hide behind the Fifth Amendment.
I will not do anything bad ever again.
I will not show off.
I will not sleep through my education.
I am not a dentist.
Spitwads are not free speech.
Nobody likes sunburn slappers.
High explosives and school don''t mix.
I will not bribe Principal Skinner.
I will not squeak chalk.
I will finish what I sta
"Bart Bucks" are not legal tender.
Underwear should be worn on the inside.
The Christmas Pageant does not stink.
I will not torment the emotionally frail.]

column8: of course

why don''t you let me show you around?"

column11:
they come to a huge room full of clocks.

column12:
"What''s up with these clocks?"

\n

St. Peter explains
column13: "Everyone on earth has a clock that shows how much time he has left on earth. When a clock runs out of time
column14:
the person dies and comes to the Gates to be judged."

The guy thinks that this makes sense but notices that some of the clocks are going faster than others. He asks why that is?

St. Peter explains
column15: "Every time a living person tells a lie

it speeds his clock."

This also makes sense
column17: so the guy takes one last look around the room before leaving and notices one clock in the center of the ceiling. On this clock

column19:
"What''s the story with that clock?"

\n

"Oh
column20: that
column21: St. Peter replies, That''s OJ Simpson''s clock. We decided to use it as a fan."]

[25 Differences Between College And High School

\n

In high school
column2: you do homework. In college
column3:
you study.

\n

No food is allowed in the hall in high school. In college
column4:
food must be provided at an event before students will come.

\n

In high school
column5: you wear your backpack on one shoulder. In college
column6:
on both.

\n

In college
column7:
the professors can tell you the answer without looking at the teacher''s guide.

\n

In college
column8:
there are no tardy slips.

\n

In high school
column9: you have to live with your parents. In college
column10:
you get to live with your friends.

\n

In college
column11:
you don''t have to wait in a certain lunch line to be cool.

\n

Only nerds e-mailed in high school. (Cool kids hadn''t heard of it.)

\n

In high school
column12: you''re told what classes to take. In college
column13: you get to choose. That is
column14:
as long as the classes don''t conflict and you have the prerequisites and the classes aren''t closed and you''ve paid your tuition.

\n

In high school
column15: if you screw up you can usually sweet-talk your way out of it. In college
column16:
you''re lucky to ever talk with the professor.

\n

In high school
column17: fire drills are planned by the administration. In college
column18:
by the drunk frat boys on their way home when the bars close.

\n

In college
column19:
any test consists of a larger percentage of your grade than your high school final exams ever did.

\n

In high school
column20: when the teacher said
column21: "Good morning
column22: you mumbled back. In college, when the professor says, Good morning
column23:
you write it down.

In high school, freshman guys hit on senior girls. In college, senior guys hit on freshman girls.

In college, weekends start on Thursday.

In college, it''s much more difficult to figure out the course schedule of the man/woman you have a crush on, in order to figure out where he/she will be walking around campus and at what time to find them there.

Once you''ve obtained the information described in #16, it''s much more time-consuming to run between classes to that place where you know he/she will be in order to just happen to bump into him/her."

In college
column24:
there''s no one to tell you not to eat pizza three meals a day.

\n

In college
column25:
your dad doesn''t pay for dates.

\n

In high school
column26:
it never took 3 or 4 weeks to get money from Mom and Dad.

College men are cuter than high school boys (or college woman are developed).

College women are legal.

In college
column27: when you miss a class (or two or three)
column28: you don''t need a note from your parents saying you were skip....uh
column29:
sick that day.

\n

In high school
column30: you can''t go out to lunch because it''s not allowed. In college
column31:
you can''t go out to lunch because you can''t afford it.

\n

In college
column32: you can blow off studying by writing lists like this.]

column8: "Give Bubba another chance
column9: give Bubba another chance!"Pat Dye and the principal had a quick conference and afterward

column1:
[From the Geek:

\n

1. When IT say they''re coming right over
column2:
log out and go for
coffee. It''s no problem for us to remember 700 network passwords.

\n

2. When you call us to have your computer moved
column3:
be sure to
leave it buried under half a ton of postcards
column4: baby pictures
column5: stuffed animals
column6: dried flowers
column7:
bowling trophies and children''s
art. We don''t have a life
column8:
and we find it deeply moving to catch
a fleeting glimpse of yours.

\n

3. When IT send you an e-mail with high importance
column9:
delete it at
once. We''re probably just testing out the public groups.

\n

4. When an IT professional is eating lunch at his desk
column10:
walk
right in and spill your guts out and expect him to respond
immediately. We exist only to serve and are always ready to
think about fixing computers.

\n

5. When an IT professional is at the water cooler or outside
having a smoke
column11:
ask him a computer question. The only reason why
we drink water or smoke at all is to ferret out all those users
who don''t have email or a telephone line.

\n

6. Send urgent email ALL IN UPPERCASE. The mail server picks it
up and flags it as a rush delivery.

\n

7. When you call a helpdesk engineer''s direct line rather than
the helpdesk number
column12:
press 5 to skip the greeting that says he''s
on holiday for a week
column13: record your message
column14:
and wait exactly 24
hours before you send an email straight to the director because
no one ever returned your call. You''re entitled to common
courtesy.

\n

8. When the photocopier doesn''t work
column15:
call computer support.
There''s electronics in it
column16:
right?

\n

9. When you''re getting a NO DIAL TONE message at home
column17:
call the
helpdesk. We can even fix telephone problems from here.

\n

10. When something''s wrong with your home PC
column18:
dump it on a chair
in IT. Leave no name
column19: no phone number
column20:
and no description of the
problem. We love a good mystery.

\n

11. When you have a helpdesk engineer on the phone walking you
through changing a setting; read the paper. We don''t actually
mean for you to DO anything; we just love to hear ourselves talk.

\n

12. When we offer you training on the upcoming OS upgrade
column21:
don''t
bother. We''ll be there to hold your hand after it is done.

\n

13. When the printer won''t print
column22:
re-send the job at least 20
times. Print jobs frequently just disappear into the cosmos for
no reason.

\n

14. When the printer still won''t print after 20 tries
column23:
send the
job to all 68 printers in the office. One of them is bound to
work.

\n

15. Don''t use online help. Online help is for wimps.

\n

16. If you''re taking night classes in computer science
column24:
feel
free to go around and update the network drivers for yourself
and your co-workers. We''re grateful for the overtime when we
have to stay until 2:30am fixing them.

\n

17. When you have an IT bod fixing your computer at a quarter to
one
column25:
eat your lunch in his face. We function better when
slightly dizzy .

\n

18. Don''t ever thank us. We love this AND we get paid for it!

\n

19. When a helpdesk engineer asks you whether you''ve installed
any new software on this computer
column26:
lie. It''s nobody''s business
what you''ve got on your computer.

\n

20. If the mouse cable keeps knocking down the framed picture of
your dog
column27:
lift the computer and stuff the cable under it. Mouse
cables were designed to have 45 lbs. of computer sitting on top
of them.

\n

21. If the space bar on your keyboard doesn''t work
column28:
blame it on
the network/mail upgrade. Keyboards work much better with half a
pound of muffin crumbs
column29: nail clippings
column30:
and big sticky drops of
Coke under the keys.

\n

22. When you get the message saying "Are you sure?" click on
that ''Yes'' button as fast as you can. Hell
column31: if you weren''t sure
column32: you wouldn''t be doing it
column33:
would you?

\n

23. Feel perfectly free to say things like "I don''t know nothing
about that computer crap". It never bothers us to hear our area
of professional expertise referred to as crap.

\n

24. When you need to change the toner cartridge
column34:
call the
helpdesk. Changing a toner cartridge is an extremely complex
task
column35:
and Hewlett-Packard recommends that it be performed only
by a professional engineer with a master''s degree in nuclear
physics.

\n

25. When something''s the matter with your computer
column36:
ask your
secretary to call the help desk. We enjoy the challenge of
having to deal with a third party who doesn''t know anything
about the problem.

\n

26. When you receive a 30-meg movie file
column37:
send it to everyone as
a high-priority mail attachment. We''ve got plenty of disk space
and processor capacity on that mail server.

\n

27. Don''t even think of breaking large print jobs down into
smaller chunks. God forbid somebody else might get a chance to
squeeze into the queue.

\n

28. When you bump into an IT bod in the supermarket on a
Saturday
column38: ask a computer question. We work 24/7
column39:
even while at
the supermarket on weekends.

\n

29. If your son is a student in computer science
column40:
have him come
in on the weekends and do his projects on your office computer.
We''ll be there for you when his illegal copy of Visual Basic 6.0
makes your Access database flip out.

\n

30. When you bring us your own no-brand home PC to repair for
free at the office
column41:
tell us how urgently we need to fix it so
your son can get back to playing DOOM. We''ll get right on it
because we have so much free time at the office.]

column1: [Last night I played a blank tape at full blast. The mime next door went nuts. If a person with multiple personalities threatens suicide
column2: is that considered a hostage situation? Just think how much deeper the ocean would be if sponges didn''t live there. I went for a walk last night and my kids asked me how long I''d be gone. I said
column3: ''The whole time.'' So what''s the speed of dark? After eating
column4: do amphibians need to wait an hour before getting OUT of the water? Why don''t they just make mouse-flavored cat food? If you''re sending someone some Styrofoam
column5: what do you pack it in? I just got skylights put in my place. The people who live above me are furious.Why do they sterilize needles for lethal injections? Do they have reserved parking for non-handicapped people at the Special Olympics? Is it true that cannibals don''t eat clowns because they taste funny? If it''s tourist season
column6: why can''t we shoot them? Isn''t Disney World a people-trap operated by a mouse? Whose cruel idea was it for the word `lisp'' to have an ''s'' in it? How come ''abbreviated'' is such a long word? If it''s zero degrees outside today and it''s supposed to be twice as cold tomorrow
column7: how cold is it going to be? Why do you press harder on a remote control when you know the battery is dead? Why are they called buildings when they''re already finished? Shouldn''t they be called builts? Why are they called apartments when they''re all stuck together? Why do banks charge you a ''non-sufficient funds'' fee on money they already know that you don''t have? If the universe is everything
column8: and scientists say that the universe is expanding
column9: what is it expanding into? What would a chair look like if your knees bent the other way? If a tree falls in the forest and no one is around to see it
column10: do the other trees make fun of it? Why is a carrot more orange than an orange? When two aeroplanes almost collide
column11: why do they call it a near miss? It sounds like a near hit to me! Do fish get cramps after eating? Why are there five syllables in the word ''monosyllabic''? Why do scientists call it ''research'' when they are looking for something new? If vegetarians eat vegetables
column12: what do humanitarians eat? When I erase a word with a pencil
column13: where does it go? Why is it that when a door is open
column14: it''s ajar
column15: but when a jar is open
column16: it''s not a door? Tell a man that there are 400 billion stars and he''ll believe you. Tell him a bench has wet paint and he has to touch it. How come Superman could stop bullets with his chest
column17: but always ducked when someone threw a gun at him? Why is it fake lemon juice contains mostly artificial ingredients
column18: but dishwashing liquid contains real lemons?Why do we wait until a pig is dead to ''cure'' it? Why do we wash bath towels? Aren''t we clean when we use them? Why do we put suits in a garment bag and put garments in a suitcase? Why doesn''t glue stick to the inside of the bottle? Do Roman paramedics refer to IVs its ''4s''? What do little birdies see when they get knocked unconscious? Why doesn''t Tarzan have a beard? If man evolved from monkeys and apes
column19: why do we still have monkeys and apes? Should you trust a stockbroker who''s married to a travel agent? Is boneless chicken considered to be an invertebrate? Do married people live longer than single people do
column20: or does it just SEEM longer? I went to a book store and asked the saleswoman
column21: ''Where''s the self-help section?'' She said if she told me it would defeat the purpose. If all those psychics know the winning lottery numbers
column22: why are they all still working? Isn''t the best way to save face to keep the lower part shut?]

column1:
[Dear Santa: We''re worried about you.

\n

From your rosy red cheeks to your legendary girth to your all-night sleigh ride around the world
column2: you may be at risk for diseases
column3: maladies
column4: mishaps and lawsuits that send chills through our Santa-loving hearts. The latest warning comes from the National Rosacea Society in Barrington
column5:
Ill.

\n

Dermatologist Dr. Jerome Litt says you have "a clear-cut case of rosacea
column6: a skin condition that also affects millions of Americans, particularly at middle age. Unable to examine you personally, the good doctor based his finding on a well-circulated report that your cheeks were like roses
column7:
(your) nose like a cherry."

\n

Sadly
column8: many observers conclude that red-skin condition comes from hitting the Christmas-punch bowl a little too hard. Sadder still
column9: rosacea can be aggravated by holiday stress
column10: hot chocolate and overexertion -- all things you may encounter this time of year. The one bright note in Litt''s message is that certain antibiotics can help
column11:
and he advises you to see a North Pole dermatologist. But the news about you facial tint is only our latest source of concern.

\n

A careful examination of what we know about you and your lifestyle raises a host of other trouble signs:

\n

OBESITY: Frankly
column12: Santa
column13: this may be your biggest area of concern. Studies show overweight men have more than double the normal risk of heart attacks and increased chances of many other diseases. We''ve seen the pictures; we''ve noticed you in the malls. And we''ve heard that your tummy shakes "like a bowlful of jelly" when you chuckle. On this
column14: we''ll take part of the blame. All these years
column15: we''ve set out milk and cookies on Christmas Eve. With 102 million homes in the U.S. alone
column16: even if 1 in 100 homes put out two cookies and a cup of milk
column17: that would make and overnight snack of 2 million cookies and 63
column18:
750 gallons of milk. Maybe it''s time for Mrs. Claus to get you a NordicTrack or a Thighmaster. But be sure to have the old ticker checked out before you start an exercise regimen.

\n

PIPE SMOKING: You''ve been pictured with a pipe
column19: and even though an apologist in The New York Times once claimed it''s only a prop
column20: a witness who encountered you in his home said "the smoke it encircled his head like a wreath." According to the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center
column21: pipe and cigar smokers have twice a nonsmoker''s risk for lung cancer
column22: four times the risk for larynx cancer and two to three times the risk for cancers of the mouth and esophagus. Even if the pipe''s just a prop
column23: it might be a good idea to lose it. Remember
column24: you''re not just a saint
column25:
you''re a role model.

\n

STRESS: Dealing with Christmas wishes from millions of kiddies could certainly put one on the emotionsl hot seat. And anxiety can surpass even smoking as a risk for certain heart problems. On this point
column26: though
column27: we have some good news: A medical news service says laughter -- as evidenced by your trademark "Ho
column28: ho
column29:
ho" -- is one of the best stress-busters.

\n

SOOT: We admire your ability to slip up and down the average chimney
column30: an opening about 12 inches by 16 inches. But creosote flakes on the chimney walls are toxic and can lead to respiratory problems. Brent Rigby of Emerald City Chimney Sweeps in Kirkland said his people never actually go into a chimney
column31:
and wear protective masks when they reach up through the fireplace to vacuum the soot.

\n

RSI (REPETITIVE STRAIN INJURY): Cards and letters by the bagful arrive on your doorstep through regular mail
column32: but this year we''ve noticed you''re also receiving -- and answering -- e-mail on at least four Internet addresses
column33: including one based in Seattle
column34:
santa@cyberspace.com.

\n

We applaud your move onto the information superhighway
column35: with this caution: too much keyboard work can result in painful injuries to the hands
column36:
wrists and arms.

\n

DEER MITES: Close
column37: continuous contact with your trusty reindeer means if they get mites
column38: so might you
column39: says Dr. David DuClos
column40: a veterinary dermatologist in Lynnwood. Watch out for itchy rashes
column41:
and keep the deer out of your bed.

\n

FROSTBITE
column42:
HYPOTHERMI
A: You usually bundle up
column43: and that''s good. A Weather Service satelilite recently showed the temperature at the North Pole was 13 below zero
column44:
and high winds are common. Exposure to such conditions can cause frostbite in minutes.

\n

MALL THUGS: You spend a lot of time in shopping malls
column45:
so you already know things are getting a little tough out there. Try not to walk back to your sleigh at night alone.

\n

MEMORY TROUBLE: It''s been said that you make a list
column46: then check it twice. Just being careful
column47:
or developing a little memory problem?

\n

SAD (SEASONAL AFFECTIVE DISORDER): This time of year
column48: there is virtually no daylight at the North Pole
column49:
and a lack of sunlight can trigger depression in some people. Maybe a full-spectrum light would help keep you jolly.

\n

VIRAL INFECTIONS: A young witness saw you kissing Mommy underneath the mistletoe last night. You know this is colds and flu season
column50:
don''t you?

\n

SLEIGH ACCIDENTS: We''ve seen plenty of pictures of you in that sleigh
column51: but never with a seat belt
column52: and we''d sure hate to see you get hurt. By the way
column53: when you cruise through Seattle this year
column54:
be sure to cover the load.

\n

JET LAG: Fatigue
column55: dizziness and insomnia are all dangers that travelers face when they cross through several times zones. And few travelers cross all 24 of them in a night
column58:
but they''re out there.

\n

Knowing all the dangers you face makes us feel that much more fortunate that you''re still faithfully delivering the goodies to good boys and girls every Christmas.

\n

But you might want to try to reduce some of those risks before your insurance company decides to boost your rates. Which reminds us: You DO have insurance

column3:
I noticed one of the cows had something white at its rear end."

I walked over and lifted up the tail and sure enough there was my wife''s golf ball.....stuck right in the middle of the cow''s butt. That''s when I made my mistake.

column1:
[So Sven and Ole were out working in the forest one day. They had just gotten jobs as lumber jacks. Well one say they were working along cutting down all the trees that had the big red X on them.

\n

As instructed by the foreman they were to yell ''TIMBER!'' whenever the tree was about to fall. Ole was cutting down a tree and yelled ''Timber'' and all of a sudden he saw a skidder pulling a tree out of the woods drive right under where the tree was about to fall. There was nothing he could do about it.

\n

The tree fell on the cab killing poor ''ol DooDah. That was his name for his parents gave it to him. He was a young man recentley married.
Well Sven and Ole didn''t know what to do
column2:
so they called the priest and he said to go talk and comfort DooDah''s now widow.

\n

Well they walked out of the forest into town and arrived at the widows house. They were dumbfounded and didn''t know what to think or say. So quickly as the fact the tree fell.....Sven rang the doorbell.

\n

A few minutes later the widow DooDah appeared at the door. Sven says that Ole has something to say. He''s at a loss of words and all that comes out of his mouth is ''GUESS WHO DIED IN THE WOODS TODAY ....!'']

You learned to swim about the same time Jaws came out and still carry the emotional scars to this day.

You could sing "99 Red Balloons" in English and German.

You''re starting to believe that maybe having kids go to school year-round wouldn''t be such a bad idea after all.

You did the LeFreak with Chic.

"All-skate
column3:
change directions" means something to you.

In high school you and all your friends discussed elaborate plans to get together again at the end of the century and play "1999" by Prince over and over again.

You wore anything Izod

You owned a Jordache anything

You ever dressed to emulate a person you saw in either a Duran Duran
column7: Madonna
column8:
Rick Springfield or Cyndi Lauper video.

You actually know who Rick Springfield is.

You rode in the back of the station wagon and faced the cars behind you in the "tail gunner" position.

Schoolhouse Rock played a HUGE part in how you were educated.

You ever wanted to be gagged with a spoon.

You had a poster of Bo
column9:
Luke or Daisy Duke.

There was nothing to question about Bert n'' Ernie living together.

Knickers and leg warmers were cool.

You ever wanted to learn to play "Stairway to Heaven" on the guitar or you choreographed "Dancing Queen" by yourself in your room.

You were afraid of the Sleestaks on Land of the Lost.

The first time you ever kissed someone was at a dance during "Crazy for You" by Madonna.

You ever used the phrase "kiss mah grits" in conversation.

You had ringside seats for Luke and Laura''s wedding.

You know who shot J.R.

This rings a bell: "and my name is Charlie. They work for me."

You ever had a Dorothy Hammill haircut.

You sat with your friends on a Friday night and dialed "867-5309" to see if Jenny would answer.

You owned a pair of Rainbow suspenders just like Mork used to wear.

You remember when your cable TV box had the three rows of numbers and you had to move the selector switch accordingly.

Two words: feathered hair

Your jaw still aches from those "brick-sized" packages of Bazooka gum.

The phrase "Where''s the beef" still cracks you up.]

column1: [Dear Mom and Dad
column2: Our scoutmaster told us all write to our parents in case you saw the flood on TV and worried. We are OK. Only 1 of our tents and 2 sleeping bags got washed away. Luckily
column3: none of us got drowned because we were all up on the mountain looking for Chad when it happened. Oh yes
column4:
please call Chad''s mother and tell her he is OK. He can''t write because of the cast. I got to ride in one of the search & rescue jeeps. It was neat. We never would have found him in the dark if it hadn''t been for the lightning.

\n

Scoutmaster Webb got mad at Chad for going on a hike alone without telling anyone. Chad said he did tell him
column5: but it was during the fire so he probably didn''t hear him. Did you know that if you put gas on a fire
column6: the gas can will blow up? The wet wood still didn''t burn
column7:
but one of our tents did. Also some of our clothes. John is going to look weird until his hair grows back.

\n

We will be home on Saturday if Scoutmaster Webb gets the car fixed. It wasn''t his fault about the wreck. The brakes worked OK when we left. Scoutmaster Webb said that a car that old you have to expect something to break down; that''s probably why he can''t get insurance on it. We think it''s a neat car. He doesn''t care if we get it dirty
column8: and if it''s hot
column9:
sometimes he lets us ride on the tailgate. It gets pretty hot with 10 people in a car. He let us take turns riding in the trailer until the highway patrolman stopped and talked to us.

\n

Scoutmaster Webb is a neat guy. Don''t worry
column10: he is a good driver. In fact
column11:
he is teaching Terry how to drive. But he only lets him drive on the mountain roads where there isn''t any traffic. All we ever see up there are logging trucks.

\n

This morning all of the guys were diving off the rocks and swimming out in the lake. Scoutmaster Webb wouldn''t let me because I can''t swim and Chad was afraid he would sink because of his cast
column12:
so he let us take the canoe across the lake. It was great. You can still see some of the trees under the water from the flood. Scoutmaster Webb isn''t crabby like some scoutmasters. He didn''t even get mad about the life jackets.

\n

He has to spend a lot of time working on the car so we are trying not to cause him any trouble. Guess what? We have all passed our first aid merit badges. When Dave dove in the lake and cut his arm
column13: we got to see how a tourniquet works. Also Wade and I threw up. Scoutmaster Webb said it probably was just food poisoning from the leftover chicken
column14:
he said they got sick that way with the food they ate in prison. I''m so glad he got out and become our scoutmaster. He said he sure figured out how to get things done better while he was doing his time.

\n

I have to go now. We are going into town to mail our letters and buy bullets. Don''t worry about anything. We are fine.

\n

Love
column15: Cole]

column3:
and I''m really glad I did. What an uplifting experience followed!

\n

I was stopped at the light at a busy intersection
column4: just lost in thought about the Lord
column5: and didn''t notice that the light had changed. That bumper sticker really worked! I found lots of people who love Jesus. Why
column6: the guy behind me started to honk like crazy. He must REALLY love the Lord because pretty soon
column7: he leaned out his window and yelled
column8: "Jesus Christ!" as loud as he could. It was like a football game with him shouting
column9: "GO JESUS CHRIST
column10:
GO!"

Everyone else started honking
column11: too

column13: and saw him waving in a funny way with only his middle finger stuck up in the air. I asked my two kids what that meant. They kind of squirmed
column14: looked at each other
column15: giggled and told me that it was the Hawaiian good luck sign. So
column16:
I leaned out the window and gave him the good luck sign back.

\n

Several cars behind
column17: a very nice man stepped out of his car and yelled something. I couldn''t hear him very well
column18: but it sounded like
column19: "Mother trucker
column20: or Mother''s from there." Maybe he was from Florida
column21:
too. He must really love the Lord.

\n

A couple of the people were so caught up in the joy of the moment that they got out of their cars and were walking toward me. I bet they wanted to pray
column22: but just then I noticed that the light had changed to yellow
column23: and stepped on the gas. And a good thing I did
column24: because I was the only driver to get across the intersection. I looked back at them standing there. I leaned way out the window
column25: gave them a big smile and held up the Hawaiian good luck sign as I drove away.]

Q: What do you call an oboist who is deaf? A: Principal. Q: How many English horn players does it take to change a light bulb? A: One
column2: but he gyrates so much he''ll fall off the ladder. Q: What''s the difference between a bassoon and a trampoline? A: You take off your shoes when you jump on a trampoline. Q: What do a clarinet and a lawsuit have in common? A: Everyone is relieved when the case is closed. Q: What''s the definition of a nerd? A: Someone who owns his own alto clarinet. Q: What do you call a bass clarinetist with half a brain? A: Gifted. Q: What''s the difference between a lawnmower and a soprano sax? A: You can tune the lawnmower.Q: If you were lost in the woods
column3: who would you trust for directions: an in-tune tenor sax player
column4: an out-of-tune tenor sax player
column5: or Santa Claus? A: The out-of-tune tenor sax player! The other two are just hallucinations.Q: How do you make a chain saw sound like a bari-sax? A: Add vibrato. Q: How do you make a trombone sound like a French horn? A: Put your hand in the bell and miss lots of notes. Q: How many French horn players does it take to change a light bulb? A: Just one
column6: but he''ll spend two hours checking the bulb for leaks and alignment problems. Q: What do you get when you cross a French horn player with a goal post? A: A goal post that can''t march. Q: How many hornists does it take to play split lead? A: One.Q: What''s the difference between a dead snake in the road and a dead trombonist in the road? A: Skid marks in front of the snake. Q: How can you tell a trombonist''s kids at a playground? A: They don''t know how to use the slide. Q: How many bass trombone players does it take to change a light bulb? A: One
column7: but he''s going to do it too loud. Q: How do you contact a baritone player? A: You-phone-`em. Q: What''s the range of a tuba? A: Twenty yards
column8: if you''ve got a good arm. Q: What''s the difference between a 3/4 tuba and a 5/4 tuba? A: About five yards. Q: What''s a tuba for? A: 1 1/2" X 3 1/2". Q: What do you call someone who hangs around with musicians? A: A drummerQ: How many drummers does it take to change a light bulb? A: None. (They have machines to do that now.) Q: How can you tell if a drummer is knocking on your door? A: He rushes. Q: What do you call a drummer without a girlfriend? A: Homeless. Q: What''s the difference between a drummer and government bonds? A: The bonds mature. Q: What did the timpanist get on his I.Q. test? A: Drool. Q: What''s the definition of a quarter-tone? A: A harpist tuning unison strings. Q: Why are pianists'' fingers like lightening? A: They rarely strike the same spot twice. Q: How can you tell if a violin is out of tune? A: The bow is moving. Q: Why is a violinist like a Scud missile? A: Both are offensive AND inaccurate. Q: Why are violins smaller than violas? A: They''re really the same size. Violinists'' heads are larger.Q: What do you do if you''re short a violinist? A: Have a percussionist drag his fingernails across a chalkboard. Q: How do you make a violin sound like a viola? A: Sit in the back and don''t play. Q: What do violists use for birth control? A: Their personalities. Q: How do you know if a viola section is at your front door? A: No one knows when to come in.Q: What''s the difference between a violist and a dog? A: The dog knows when to stop scratching. Q: What do a bad airplane mechanic and a violist have in common? A: Both screw up Boeings. Q: What''s the difference between a cello and a viola? A: The cello burns longer. Q: Why did the bass player get mad at the timpanist? A: He turned a peg and wouldn''t tell him which one.]

[...you can analyze the significance of appliances you cannot operate.
...your office is better decorated than your apartment.
...you have ever
column2: as a folklore project
column3:
attempted to track the progress of your own joke across the Internet.
...you are startled to meet people who neither need nor want to read.
...you have ever brought a scholarly article to a bar.
...you rate coffee shops by the availability of outlets for your laptop.
...everything reminds you of something in your discipline.
...you have ever discussed academic matters at a sporting event.
...you have ever spent more than $50 on photocopying while researching a single paper.
...there is a microfilm reader in the library that you consider "yours."
...you actually have a preference between microfilm and microfiche.
...you can tell the time of day by looking at the traffic flow at the library.
...you look forward to summers because you''re more productive without the distraction of classes.
...you regard ibuprofen as a vitamin.
...you consider all papers to be works in progress.
...professors don''t really care when you turn in work anymore.
...you find the bibliographies of books more interesting than the actual text.
...you have given up trying to keep your books organized and are now just trying to keep them all in the same general area.
...you have accepted guilt as an inherent feature of relaxation.
...you reflexively start analyzing those greek letters before you realize that it''s a sorority sweatshirt
column4:
not an equation.
...you find yourself explaining to children that you are in "20th grade".
...you start refering to stories like "Snow White et al."
...you frequently wonder how long you can live on pasta without getting scurvy
...you look forward to taking some time off to do laundry
...you have more photocopy cards than credit cards
...you wonder if APA style allows you to cite talking to yourself as "personal communication"]

column1:
[Dear Mom & Dad:

\n

We are having a great time here at Lake Typhoid. Scoutmaster Webb is
making us all write to our parents in case you saw the flood on TV and
worried. We are OK. Only 1 of our tents and 2 sleeping bags got washed
away. Luckily
column2:
none of us got drowned because we were all up on the
mountain looking for Chad when it happened. Oh yes
column3:
please call Chad''s
mother and tell her he is OK. He can''t write because of the cast. I got to
ride in one of the search & rescue jeeps. It was neat. We never would have
found him in the dark if it hadn''t been for the lightning. Scoutmaster
Webb got mad at Chad for going on a hike alone without telling anyone.
Chad said he did tell him
column4:
but it was during the fire so he probably
didn''t hear him. Did you know that if you put gas on a fire
column5:
the gas can
will blow up? The wet wood still didn''t burn
column6:
but one of our tents did.
Also some of our clothes. John is going to look weird until his hair grows
back. We will be home on Saturday if Scoutmaster Webb gets the car fixed.
It wasn''t his fault about the wreck. The brakes worked OK when we left.
Scoutmaster Webb said that a car that old you have to expect something to
break down; that''s probably why he can''t get insurance on it. We think
it''s a neat car. He doesn''t care if we get it dirty
column7: and if its hot
column8:
sometimes he lets us ride on the tailgate. It gets pretty hot with 10
people in a car. He let us take turns riding in the trailer until the
highway patrolman stopped and talked to us. Scoutmaster Webb is a neat
guy. Don''t worry
column9: he is a good driver. In fact
column10:
he is teaching Terry how
to drive. But he only lets him drive on the mountain roads where there
isn''t any traffic. All we ever see up there are logging trucks. This
morning all of the guys were diving off the rocks and swimming out in the
lake. Scoutmaster Webb wouldn''t let me because I can''t swim and Chad was
afraid he would sink because of his cast
column11:
so he let us take the canoe
across the lake. It was great. You can still see some of the trees under
the water from the flood. Scoutmaster Webb isn''t crabby like some
scoutmasters. He didn''t even get mad about the life jackets. He has to
spend a lot of time working on the car so we are trying not to cause him
any trouble. Guess what? We have all passed our first aid merit badges.
When Dave dove in the lake and cut his arm
column12:
we got to see how a tourniquet
works. Also Wade and I threw up. Scoutmaster Webb said it probably was
just food poisoning from the leftover chicken. I have to go now. We are
going into town to mail our letters and buy bullets. Don''t worry about
anything. We are fine.

\n

Love
column13:
Cole

\n

P.S. How long has it been since I had a tetanus shot?]

column1: [A couple of women were playing golf one sunny Saturday morning. The first of the twosome teed off and watched in horror as her ball headed directly toward a foursome of men playing the next hole. Indeed
column2: the ball hit one of the men
column3: and he immediately clasped his hands together at his crotch

fell to the ground and proceeded to roll around in evident agony. The woman rushed down to the man and immediately began to apologize.

\n

She said
column5:
"Please allow me to help. I''m a physical therapist and I know I could relieve your pain if you''d allow."

\n

"Ummph
column6: oooh
column7: nnooo
column8: I''ll be all right...I''ll be fine in a few minutes
column9:
he replied breathlessly as he remained in the fetal position still clasping his hands together at his crotch.

But she persisted, and he finally allowed her to help him. She gently took his hands away and laid them to the side, she loosened his pants, and she put her hands inside. She began to massage him.

She then asked him, How does that feel?"

To which he replied
column10: "It feels great
column11: but my thumb still hurts like hell."]

column1:
[Doris and Fred had started their retirement years and decided to

column2:
a young attractive woman
applied for the room and explained that she was a model working
in a nearby city center studio for a few weeks and that she

but would pay for
the whole week. Doris showed her the house and they agreed to

\n

job

and I notice you don''t

replied Doris. We have a
tin bath out in the yard and we bring it in to the living room
in front of the fire and fill it with hot water." "What about

he plays darts most
weekdays
column9: so he will be out in the evenings
column10:
replied Doris.
Good
column11: said the model. Now that''s been settled

I''ll go to the
studio and see you tonight."

\n

That evening
column13:
Fred dutifully went to his darts match while Doris
prepared the bath for the model. After stripping off
column14:
the model
stepped into the bath. Doris was amazed to see that she has no
pubic hair. The model noticed Doris'' staring eyes
column15:
so she smiled
and explained that it is part of her job to shave herself
column16:
especially when modeling swimmer or underclothes.

\n

Later when Fred returned
column17:
Doris related this oddity and he does
not believe her. "It''s true
column18: I tell you!" said Doris. "Look
column19:
if
you don''t believe me
column20:
tomorrow night I''ll leave the curtains
slightly open and you can peek in and see for yourself."

\n

The next night
column21:
Fred left as usual and Doris prepared the bath
for the model. As the model stepped naked into the bath
column22:
Doris
stood behind her. Doris looked towards the curtains and pointed
towards the model''s naked pubic Area. Then she lifted up her
skirt and wearing no panties
column23:
pointed to her own hairy mass.

\n

Later Fred returned and they retired to bed. "Well
column24:
do you
believe me now?" she asked Fred. "Yes
column25:
he replied. I''ve never
seen anything like it in my life. But why did you lift up your
skirt and show yourself?"

\n

"Just to show you the difference." answered Doris. "But I guess
you''ve seen me millions of times." "Yes
column26:
said Fred, I have -
but the rest of the dart team hadn''t."]

column1: [The weather was very hot

column1: [Some of us Southerners are pretty skeptical of horoscopes and the people that read them. If we are to ever fully understand all the star signs and the people they represent
column2:
we need symbols that all true Southerners understand: See the list below...

\n

OKRA (Dec 22 - Jan 20) Are tough on the outside but tender on the inside. Okras have tremendous influence. An older Okra can look back over his life and see the seeds of his influence everywhere. You can do something good each day if you try.

\n

CHITLIN (Jan 21 - Feb 19) Chitlins come from humble backgrounds. A Chitlin
column3: however
column4: will make something of himself if he is motivated and has lots of seasoning. In dealing with Chitlins
column5:
be careful they may surprise you. They can erupt like Vesuvius. Chitlins are best with Catfish and Okra.

\n

BOLL WEEVIL (Feb 20 - March 20) You have an overwhelming curiosity. You''re unsatisfied with the surface of things
column6: and you feel the need to bore deep into the interior of everything. Needless to say
column7: you are very intense and driven as if you had some inner hunger. You love to stay busy and tend to work too much. Nobody in their right mind is going to marry you
column8:
so don''t worry about it.

\n

MOON PIE (March 21 - April 20) You''re the type that spends a lot of time on the front porch. A cinch to recognize the physical appearance of Moon Pies. Big and round are the key words here. You should marry anybody who you can get remotely interested in the idea. It''s not going to be easy. You always have a big smile and are happy. This might be the year to think about aerobics. Maybe not.

\n

POSSUM (April 21 - May 21) When confronted with life''s difficulties
column9: possums have a marked tendency to withdraw and develop a don''t-bother-me-about-it attitude. Sometimes you become so withdrawn
column10:
people actually think you''re dead. This strategy is probably not psychologically healthy but seems to work for you. You are a rare breed. Most folks love to watch you work and play. You are a night person and mind your own business.

\n

CRAWFISH (May 22 - June 21) Crawfish is a water sign. If you work in an office
column11: you''re hanging around the water cooler. Crawfish prefer the beach to the mountains
column12: the pool to the golf course
column13: and the bathtub to the living room. You tend not to be particularly attractive physically
column14: but you have very
column15:
very good heads.

\n

COLLARDS (June 22 - July 23) Collards have a genius for communication. They love to get in the melting pot of life and share their essence with the essence of those around them. Collards make good social workers
column16: psychologists
column17: and baseball managers. As far as your personal life goes
column18: if you are Collards
column19:
stay away from Crawfish. It just won''t work. Save yourself a lot of heartache.

\n

CATFISH (July 24 - Aug 23) Catfish are traditionalists in matters of the heart
column20: although one''s whiskers may cause problems for loved ones. You Catfish are never easy people to understand. You run fast. You work and play hard. Even though you prefer the muddy bottoms to the clear surface of life
column21: you are liked by most. Above all else
column22:
Catfish should stay away from Moon Pies.

\n

GRITS (Aug 24 - Sept 23) Your highest aim is to be with others like yourself. You like to huddle together with a big crowd of other Grits. You love to travel though
column23: so maybe you should think about joining a club. Where do you like to go? Anywhere they have cheese
column24: gravy
column25: bacon
column26: butter
column27: or eggs and a good time. If you can go somewhere where they have all these things
column28:
that serves you well. You are pure in heart.

\n

BOILED PEANUTS (Sept 24 - Oct 23) You have a passionate desire to help your fellow man. Unfortunately
column29: those who know you best
column30: your friends and loved ones
column31: may find that your personality is much too salty
column32: and their criticism will affect you deeply because you are really much softer than you appear. You should go right ahead and marry anybody you want to because in a certain way
column33: yours is a charmed life. On the road of life
column34:
you can be sure that people will always pull over and stop for you.

\n

BUTTER BEAN (Oct 24 - Nov 22) Always invite a Butter Bean to a party because Butter Beans get along well with everybody. You
column35: as a Butter Bean
column36: should be proud. You''ve grown on the vine of life
column37: and you feel at home no matter what the setting. You can sit next to anybody. However
column38: you
column39: too
column40:
shouldn''t have anything to do with Moon Pies.

\n

ARMADILLO (Nov 23 - Dec 21) You have a tendency to develop a tough exterior
column41: but you are actually quite gentle and kind inside. A good evening for you? Old friends
column42: a fire
column43: some roots
column44: fruit
column45: worms
column46: and insects. You are a throwback. You''re not concerned with today''s fashions and trends. You''re not concerned with anything about today. You''re almost prehistoric in your interests and behavior patterns. You probably want to marry another Armadillo
column47: but a Possum is another somewhat kinky mating possibility.]

column1: [Joys of Jogging1. For every mile you jog

column7: before my brain figures out what I''m doing.5. I like long walks

column1: [A man had to go to a strange town to be the guest speaker at a business meeting. When he arrived at the Motel in town

column5:

She replied "I''m on the 7th hole and you are a hole behind me

so you must be on the 6th hole."

She said "I''m on the 14th
column7: you are a hole behind me

So you must be on the 13th."

Once again he thanked her and returned to his play. He finished his round and went into the club house where he saw the Lady sitting at the end of the bar. He asked the bartender if he knew the Lady. The bartender said that she was a sales lady and played the course often. He approached her and said

With that

he fell on the floor and laughed so hard he almost lost his breath. She said "see I knew you would laugh."

"That''s not what I''m laughing at" he replied

column18: so I''m still a hole behind you!"]

column1:
[Mel C. walked into a bar with a pig tied to a piece of string.
"Where the hell did you pick that dirty thing up?" asked the
publican. "Won it in a raffle." said the pig.

Q: What''s the difference between a spice girl and a computer?
A: You only have to punch information into a computer once.

Q: What do you do if a spice girl hurls a grenade at you?
A: Take out the pin and throw it back

Q: What do you call a spice girl behind a steering wheel?
A: An airbag

Q. Why are jokes about Spice Girls so short?
A. So that the girls themselves understand them!

Q. How do you make the Spice Girls laugh on Friday?
A. Tell them a joke on Tuesday!

Q. What''s the difference between an intelligent Spice Girl and a
UFO?
A. Dunno - never seen either!

Q: Why do the Spice Girls smile when there is lightning out?
A: They think they are getting their photo taken

Q: A blond and the Spice Girls jumped off the Empire State
building. Who landed first?
A: The blond. The Spice Girls had to stop and ask directions!

I don''t want to say the Spice Girls are stupid
column2:
but they think
"menopause" is a button on a VCR.

\n

One day a spice girl went into the hairdresser and asked for a
haircut. She was listening to a walkman. When the hairdresser
went to take it off she cried out "no no no! Leave it on! Just
cut around it!"
column3:
so he did. 6 weeks later the same thing
happened again...the hairdresser tried to take the headphones
off
column4:
but the spice girl asked him to cut around it. This
happened again
column5:
and again until one day when the hairdresser was
cutting the Spice Girl''s hair when she keeled over dead. He
noticed he had accidentally knocked the headphones off. He
picked them up and pressed play. He heard "Breathe in...breathe
out...breathe in...breathe out"

\n

Q: How many Spice Girls does it take to screw in a light bulb?
A: None
column6:
they only screw in cars.

Q: What''s the difference between the Spice Girls and a hockey
team?
A: Hockey teams bathe after three periods

Q: Why do Spice Girls have TGIF on their shoes?
A: Toes go in first.

Q: Why don''t Spice Girls eat bananas?
A: They can''t find the zipper.

Q: How do you know when a Spice Girl has been making choc. chip
cookies?
A: You find M&M shells all over the kitchen floor.

Q: What does a Spice Girl and a beer bottle have in common?
A: They''re both empty from the neck up.

Q: Why did Mel B. get so excited after she finished her jigsaw
puzzle in only 6 months?
A: Because on the box it said From 2-4 years.]
